member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.HatchFill
member.summary: Defines a fill with a hatch style, a foreground color, and a background color.

example.para: The following example creates a rectangle filled with a hatch fill.
example.code: Function CreateRectangleWithHatchFill() As Rect Dim rectangle As Rect = New Rect(0, 0, 100, 100) Dim myFill As HatchFill = New HatchFill myFill.BackColor = Color.LightBlue myFill.ForeColor = Color.Red myFill.HatchStyle = HatchStyle.BackwardDiagonal rectangle.Fill = myFill Return rectangle End Function

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphicObject
member.summary: The base class for all graphic objects.

remarks.p: The class is the base class for all graphic objects. Graphic objects are hierarchical and can be combined to create complex drawings. The class is the base class for graphic containers, that is, graphic objects that contain other graphic objects. A can be displayed in a ILOG.Diagrammer.Windows.Forms.DiagramView for Windows applications, or ILOG.Diagrammer.Web.UI.DiagramView for ASP.NET applications.
To get or set the bounds of the GraphicObject, use the property, or the and properties.

The GraphicObject class defines several properties that can be used to change the appearance of a graphic object. The property controls the visibility of the graphic object. The property allows to add a filter effect. The property clips the drawing of the graphic object. The property controls the graphic object opacity. The property allows to set a local affine transformtion on the graphic object.
A GraphicObject may have a preferred size, given by the method. To make a graphic object automatically resized to its preferred size, use the property.

A GraphicObject is painted by calling its method. The method takes into account the appearance properties defined on the GraphicObject class such as , , , , and then it calls the method. To customize the drawing of a graphic object, overrides the method to benefit from the graphic object rendering feature.
A graphic object can receive input events. The GraphicObject class defines several events that can be used to add interactions to graphic objects. For details, see the , , , , or events.
A graphic object holds a collection of object. An represents a connection point on the graphic object, on which a can be connected.
When modifying several properties of a GraphicObject, call the and methods to reduce the number of notifications.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphicObject.BeginUpdate
member.summary: Starts an update cycle for this graphic object.

remarks.p: During an update cycle, the object will not throw its event anymore. This can be useful is you want to make several modifications on the object while keeping a single notification.
Update cycles can be nested.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphicObject.EndUpdate
member.summary: Ends an update cycle for this graphic object.

remarks.p: During an update cycle, the object will not throw its event anymore. This can be useful is you want to make several modifications on the object while keeping a single notification.
Update cycles can be nested.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Text
member.summary: Defines a graphic object that displays a text.
member.remarks: This graphic object displays the text defined by the property. The text is displayed at a position defined by the , and properties.

example.para: The following example shows how to create a Text object filled with a linear gradient.
example.code: Function CreateText() As Text Dim gradient As LinearGradientFill = _ New LinearGradientFill(New Point2D(0, 0), _ New Point2D(0, 1), _ Color.Yellow, Color.Red) Dim text As Text = New Text text.Text = "Diagram for .NET" text.TextLocation = New Point2D(70F, 100F) text.Fill = gradient text.Stroke = New Stroke(Color.Olive) text.Font = New Font("Garamond", 35F, FontStyle.Bold) text.HorizontalAlignment = HorizontalTextAlignment.Left text.VerticalAlignment = VerticalTextAlignment.Center Return text End Function

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.DefaultSelectionGraphic
member.summary: An implementation of the class that adds handles to manipulate the selected object.

remarks.para: A selection handle is a rectangular area of the selection graphic object that can be moved using the mouse. The selection handles can be accessed through the method. The default implementation of this method returns three handles to manage object rotation: The first handle allows to specify the rotation center, the second handle allows to rotate the object around the first handle, and the last one allows to move or reparent the object. To add new handles, create a subclass of DefaultSelectionGraphic and override the GetHandlePoints methods.
The graphical representation of selection handles depends on the enumeration. See the method for details.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.SelectionGraphic
member.summary: The base class for selection graphic objects.

remarks.p: The class is the base class for graphic objects representing the selection of another graphic object in a particular diagram host.
Use the property to access the selected graphic object. Use the property to access the diagram view on which this object will be displayed.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.DefaultSelectionGraphic.CreateGhostGraphic
member.summary: Is called to create the ghost graphic that will be used to render selection interactions when the view in which this object is displayed is not in selection instant editing mode.

remarks.para: when the view in which this graphic object is displayed is not in selection instant editing mode, the modifications made on the through this selection object are not instantaneous. Instead, a ghost graphic is created on which modifications will be performed. At the end of the interaction, the modifications made on the ghost graphic will be set on the SelectedObject by calling the method.
The default implemetation of this method creates of clone of the SelectedObject with a transparency of 50%.

member.returns: A reference.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.DefaultSelectionGraphic.ValidateGhostGraphic(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphicObject)
member.summary: Is called to validate the modifications made on the ghost graphic when the view in which this object is displayed is not in selection instant editing mode.
member.param: The used as a ghost for the interaction.
member.remarks: The default implementation of this method sets the local transformation of the ghost graphic to the .

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.StackPanel
member.summary: Arranges child objects into a single line that can be oriented horizontally or vertically.
member.remarks: The is a panel that layouts the child objects into a single vertical or horizontal line. Use the property to control the direction in which child objects will be arranged.

example.para: The following example creates a vertical stack panel containing 4 rectangles:
example.code:
Private Shared Function CreateStackPanelWithRectangles() As StackPanel Dim stackPanel As StackPanel = New StackPanel stackPanel.Rectangle = New Rectangle2D(0, 0, 100, 100) stackPanel.AutoSize = True stackPanel.Border = New Stroke(Color.Black) stackPanel.CornerRadius = New CornerRadius(6F) stackPanel.Orientation = Orientation.Vertical
Dim header As Rect = New Rect header.Text = "Header" header.AutoSize = True header.Fill = New LinearGradientFill(_ New Point2D(0, 0), _ New Point2D(0, 1), _ Color.Silver, _ Color.White)
Dim rect1 As Rect = New Rect rect1.Text = "Text 1" rect1.Fill = Nothing rect1.AutoSize = True
Dim rect2 As Rect = New Rect rect2.Fill = Nothing rect2.AutoSize = True rect2.Text = "Text 2"
Dim rect3 As Rect = New Rect rect3.Fill = Nothing rect3.AutoSize = True rect3.Text = "Text 3"
stackPanel.Objects.AddRange(_ New GraphicObject() {header, rect1, rect2, rect3}) Return stackPanel End Function

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Panel
member.summary: Provides the base class for all panel objects. Panels are used to layout child objects.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.ObjectsControl
member.summary: Provides the base class for all control objects that contains multiple children.
member.remarks: The property can be used to add or removed children.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Control
member.summary: Provides the base class for all control objects.

remarks.p: A is a rectangular graphic container. The control geometry is defined by the property. The control size can be constrained by setting the and properties.
The control appearance can be modified by setting the Control, and properties.
The coordinates system of a control places the upper left corner of the control as the origin (0, 0) for its children.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphicContainer.ShouldDispatchSelectionEvents(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphicObject)
member.summary: Is called by the SelectInteractor to know if the container will dispatch events to the specified child.
member.returns: if the container will dispatch events to ; Otherwise, .

remarks.p: This method is used to enhance the behavior or selected objects when a SelectInteractor has been set on a diagram view. By overriding this method, you will be able to mix the behavior defined on graphic objects with the behavior of the selection interactor.

The default behavior looks for a static method called ShouldDispatchEvents on the class associated with this graphic object. The method must return a value, and has two instances as parameters: The first parameter is the real target of the event, and the second one is this graphic container.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphicContainer.ShouldStartMultipleChildrenSelection(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphicObject)
member.summary: Is called by the SelectInteractor to know if the selection of multiple children (by dragging a rectangle) should be started.
member.param: The over which the mouse pointer is currently placed.
member.returns: if the the selection of multiple children should be started; Otherwise, .

remarks.p: This method is used to enhance the behavior or selected objects when a SelectInteractor has been set on a diagram view. By overriding this method, you will be able to control whether a multi-selection is started, or whether the whole container will be selected and possibly moved.
This method is called only if the property is .
The default behavior returns .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphicContainer.RefreshSubLayouts
member.summary: Clears the layouts allocated by the layout provider for the subgraphs of this container. This method must be called every time a sub-layout is subject to change, that is: - when the toplevel layout itself changes (i.e., the GraphLayout.LinkLayout properties), - when a property of a toplevle layout changes, - when the Graph/LinkLayoutActive properties change - when a subgraph is added (because the sublayout must be attached immediately if we are in auto-layout, so that the layout is done is something changes in the subgraph.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphicContainer.LayoutProvider
member.summary: The layout provider that determines the layout to perform for each container or sub-container.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.DefaultLayoutProvider
member.summary: A default implementation of the interface .

remarks.p:
This class is mainly useful when laying out nested graphs, that is, graphs containing nodes that are other graphs. It provides the following services:
Allows you to set a layout instance for a given graph model (see the method ).
When no layout instance is specified for a given graph model using the method , the protected method () is called. The default implementation of this method "clones" the layout instance of the closest parent graph for which a layout has been set. You can override this method to change this behavior.
Warning: to avoid repeatedly "cloning" the layout instance, the method
stores the "cloned" layout instance as the preferred layout of the given graph model. This means that any change to the parameters of the layout that has been "cloned," after the call of , does not affect the "cloned" layout instance. This allows you to set parameters independently on each layout instance. However, if you need to replicate the same parameter settings on the layout instance that has been previously "cloned," you can, for instance, delete the preferred layout (SetPreferredLayout(model, null)). This way the layout instance of the parent graph will be "cloned" again with its new parameter settings.

Note that you must call the method
when you no longer need the layout provider instance; otherwise, some objects may not be garbage collected.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ILayoutProvider
member.summary: An interface used to specify the layout instance to be used for laying out a given graph.

remarks.p: This interface is mainly useful when laying out nested graphs, that is, graphs containing nodes that are other graphs.
Note that in many cases, it is simpler either to use the subclass as is, or to subclass it, instead of directly implementing this interface.

example.para: The following code is an example of the implementation of the method . In this example, the criteria used for choosing the layout instance is the value of a property stored in advance in the graph model. Of course, many other criteria can be used.
example.code: Public Function GetGraphLayout(ByVal graphModel As IGraphModel) As GraphLayout Dim name As String = TryCast(graphModel.GetProperty("layout type"), String) If name Is Nothing Then Return Nothing End If Dim layout As GraphLayout = Nothing If name.Equals("tree") Then layout = New TreeLayout Else If name.Equals("flow") Then layout = New HierarchicalLayout Else Throw New Exception("unsupported layout choice: " + name) End If End If layout.Attach(graphModel) Return layout End Function

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ILayoutProvider.GetGraphLayout(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel)
member.summary: Returns the layout instance to be used for laying out a graph model.
member.remarks:
The layout instance that is returned must be attached to via the method .
Note that this method must return a different layout instance for each subgraph. The same layout instance should not be returned for two different subgraphs of the same graph. Also, the layout instance returned for a subgraph should not be the same as the one returned for the topmost graph.
This method is called during the recursive layout of a nested graph using the method
with traverse flag set to , and when the is performed. If the method returns , this means that no layout is needed for .
member.param: The graph model (eventually the graph model that encapsulates the topmost grapher).
member.returns: The layout instance to be used for , or if no layout is need for .

Use the method
to specify preferred layouts.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.DefaultLayoutProvider.SetPreferredLayout(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel,ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets the layout instances to be used for laying out .

remarks.p: If the argument is , is stored as the preferred layout of . If the argument is , is stored as the preferred layout of and, recursively, a clone of is stored as preferred layout of all the models encapsulating the subgraphs of . The clones are obtained by calling the method .

You can call this method with a value for the argument to reset previous settings. By default, there is no preferred layout and the method
returns .

If it is not already attached, the method attaches the layout instance to the graph model using the method . The layout instance is stored in the provider until it is detached using the method . If a different layout instance was previously specified and the argument is , the graph model is detached from it using the method .

The same layout instance should not be used for different subgraphs in the same nested graph, and should not be used inside a different default layout provider. Also, the method should not be called for graph models that are adapter created internally by the method
on a layout instance which is not .

member.param: The graph model (the graph model that encapsulates the topmost graphic container, or a subgraph).
The layout instance to be used for laying out , or .
If , the layout instance previously specified as the preferred layout of (if any) is detached.
If , is stored as the preferred layout of , and clones of are recursively stored on the submodels of . Otherwise, the method does not go recursively into the submodels.

member.summary:
Returns the layout instance that has been specified using the method
for laying out , or if none has been specified or a layout has been specified (that is, no layout should be applied to this graph model).
member.remarks: The layout instance is already attached. If you detach the layout instance, it is automatically removed from the provider.
member.param: The graph model (the graph model that encapsulates the topmost graphic container, or a subgraph).

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.DefaultLayoutProvider.DetachLayouts(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Detaches the layout instances from and cleans the preferred layout settings.

remarks.p: This method allows you to easily detach all the layout instances used for a nested graph. The layout instances are obtained using the method . If the argument is , the method is applied recursively on the subgraphs of .
Note that you must call this method when you no longer need the layout provider instance; otherwise, some objects may not be garbage collected.

member.param: The graph model (the graph model that encapsulates the topmost graphic container, or a subgraph).
If , the method applies to and recursively to all subgraph models. Otherwise, it applies only to itself.

member.summary: Returns the layout instance to be used to lay out .

remarks.p: The default implementation first searches for a preferred layout specified using . If none is found, the method returns the layout instance returned by the method .

member.param: The graph model (the graph model that encapsulates the topmost graphic container, or a subgraph).

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.DefaultLayoutProvider.CreateGraphLayout(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel)
member.summary: Returns a layout instance to be used to lay out a graph model for which no layout has been specified using the method .

remarks.p: The method clones (using the method ) the layout instance of the nearest parent graph model for which a non- preferred layout has been specified. If no non- preferred layout has been specified for any of its parents, including the topmost (root) graph model, the method returns .

The layout instance that is returned does not need to be attached to the specified graph model. The attachment (using the method
is done in the method .

member.param: The graph model (the graph model that encapsulates the topmost graphic container, or a subgraph).
member.returns: The layout instance to be used for , or if no layout is need for .

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IAutoLayoutHandler
member.summary: An interface used to automatically perform a layout again following a structural or geometric change of the graph.
member.remarks:
The interface can be installed at a layout instance. It is used inside
to start the automatic layout.

example.para: The following sample shows an example of a simple implementation of the PerformAutoLayout method.
example.code: Public Sub PerformAutoLayout(ByVal layout As Object, ByVal objects As ArrayList) If TypeOf layout Is GraphLayout Then CType(layout, GraphLayout).PerformLayout(True) End If End Sub

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IAutoLayoutHandler.PerformAutoLayout(System.Object,System.Collections.ArrayList)
member.summary: Performs an automatic layout that was caused by a structural or geometric change of some graphic objects.
member.param: The graph layout to be performed.

The vector of graphic objects that caused the need for layout. These objects were added, removed, or have moved. If is passed, the need for layout has no specific reason (for example, when all nodes and links have moved).

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.FilterEffect
member.summary: Defines the base class for all filter effects.
member.remarks: A filter effect represents a single image filter effect in a object. Each filter effect as one or more input filter effects defined by the property. The filter effect take the resulting images created by the input filter effects and create a single resulting image.

example.para: The following sample shows how to create a drop shadow filter.
example.code:
Function CreateDropShadowFilter() As Filter
Dim filter As Filter = New Filter
Dim gaussianBlur As FeGaussianBlur = New FeGaussianBlur(4F, 4F) gaussianBlur.In = New FeSourceAlpha
Dim offset As FeOffset = New FeOffset(5F, 5F) offset.In = gaussianBlur
Dim merge As FeMerge = New FeMerge
merge.Inputs.Add(offset); merge.Inputs.Add(New FeSourceGraphic())
filter.Effects.Add(gaussianBlur) filter.Effects.Add(offset) filter.Effects.Add(merge)
Return filter End Function

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.FilterEffect.FilterEffectRegion
member.summary: Gets or sets the region on which this filter effect applies.
member.value: A object that represents the region on which the filter effect applies. The region is only meaningful if the value is not an empty rectangle. The coordinate space for value is defined by the property of the class. If the value is ObjectBBox then the value of the filter effect region should be considered as percentage of the graphic object's bounding rectangle otherwise the value is defined in the current coordinate space. By default the value is an empty rectangle which means that the filter effect applies on all the filter region defined by the property of the class.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeColorMatrix
member.summary: This filter effect applies a matrix transformation on each pixel of the input image.
member.remarks:
This filter applies a matrix transformation:
| R' | | a00 a01 a02 a03 a04 | | R | | G' | | a10 a11 a12 a13 a14 | | G | | B' | = | a20 a21 a22 a23 a24 | * | B | | A' | | a30 a31 a32 a33 a34 | | A | | 1 | | 0 0 0 0 1 | | 1 |
on the RGBA color and alpha values of every pixel on the input graphics to produce a result with a new set of RGBA color and alpha values.
The property defines the type of the matrix transformation. When the type is then the values of the matrix transformation must be specified by the property that is an array of 20 floats that represents the 5x4 matrix values (a00, a01, a02, a03 , a04, a10 ...). The other types defined by the enumeration represent convenience shortcuts to allow commonly used color operations to be performed without specifying a complete matrix.
For type , the operation is equivalent to the following matrix operation:
| R' | |0.213+0.787s 0.715-0.715s 0.072-0.072s 0 0 | | R | | G' | |0.213-0.213s 0.715+0.285s 0.072-0.072s 0 0 | | G | | B' | = |0.213-0.213s 0.715-0.715s 0.072+0.928s 0 0 | * | B | | A' | | 0 0 0 1 0 | | A | | 1 | | 0 0 0 0 1 | | 1 |
where s is defined by the property.
For type , the operation is equivalent to the following matrix operation:
| R' | | a00 a01 a02 0 0 | | R | | G' | | a10 a11 a12 0 0 | | G | | B' | = | a20 a21 a22 0 0 | * | B | | A' | | 0 0 0 1 0 | | A | | 1 | | 0 0 0 0 1 | | 1 |
where the terms a00, a01, etc. are calculated as follows:
| a00 a01 a02 | [+0.213 +0.715 +0.072] | a10 a11 a12 | = [+0.213 +0.715 +0.072] + | a20 a21 a22 | [+0.213 +0.715 +0.072] [+0.787 -0.715 -0.072] cos(hueRotate value) * [-0.213 +0.285 -0.072] + [-0.213 -0.715 +0.928] [-0.213 -0.715+0.928] sin(hueRotate value) * [+0.143 +0.140-0.283] [-0.787 +0.715+0.072]
where hueRotate is defined by the property.
For type , the operation is equivalent to the following matrix operation:
| R' | | 0 0 0 0 0 | | R | | G' | | 0 0 0 0 0 | | G | | B' | = | 0 0 0 0 0 | * | B | | A' | | 0.2125 0.7154 0.0721 0 0 | | A | | 1 | | 0 0 0 0 1 | | 1 |

member.remarks: When a view receives an input event, it first forwards the event to the view interactor, if there is one. If there is no interactor, the event is forwarded to a possible graphic object targeted by the input event. Otherwise, the event propagation is stopped.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Windows.Forms.CreateLinkInteractor
member.summary: The class is a subclass of that is used to interactively create new instances of classes that implement the interface.

remarks.para: The is used to create new objects in a .

To create a new link, the user first clicks on the start point of the link, then on the end point. Alternatively, the user can press the left mouse button on the start point, drag the mouse, then release the mouse button on the end point.

New links can be created in an empty area of the diagram view, or they can be connected to existing graphic objects. To create a connected link, the user first moves the mouse cursor over the start object. The objects attached to the object are drawn as small squares. The user then moves the mouse cursor over the anchor to which the link must be connected, and clicks (or presses) the left mouse button. The same process is repeated for the end object.

By default, the creates new instances of the class. To create an instance of another class, the property can be set to an instance of a class that implements the interface (note that the created object must implement the interface). If you just need to create instances of the class with a different , you can set the property.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.Internal.InternalFlatBaseGraphModel
member.summary: A base class for all the internal graph models that we use.
member.remarks: This is suitable for internal graph models that need only one attached layout, and handle only flat graphs.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel
member.summary: IGraphModel defines a suitable generic API for graphs that have to be laid out with IBM ILOG Diagram for .NET graph layout algorithms.
member.remarks:
The class is implemented by and by .
The concept of the graph model allows the use of any application object as a graph, a node, or a link. This makes it much easier to add graph layout features to existing applications.
All the layout algorithms provided in IBM ILOG Diagram for .NET are designed to lay out a graph model. This allows any application to benefit from the graph layout algorithms, whether or not it uses the IBM ILOG Diagram for .NET graphic container (). However, to make things simple for the common case of applications that use a graphic container, it is not mandatory to work directly with the graph model, since an appropriate instance of is allocated on the fly when attaching the layout to a graphic container.
Learning to use the interface IGraphModel is a bit difficult because it is very general and uses the type Object for the arguments of many methods. For laying out graphs, most often it is sufficient to use the API of the layout algorithms.
Note that if an application uses the class , the graphic container can be attached directly to the layout instance without explicitly using a graph model (see the method ). In this case the appropriate adapter () is created internally. If necessary, this adapter can be retrieved using the method , which in this circumstance returns an instance of .
The methods defined in this interface can be divided into the following categories:
Methods and properties that provide information about the topology (structure) of the graph. For instance: , , , , and so on.
Methods that provide information about the geometry of the graph. For instance: and .
Methods that allow the layout algorithm to modify the geometry of the graph. For instance: and .
Methods that provide services such as the test whether layout is needed or the capability to store "property objects" for nodes and links, and so on.
Since graphs can be nested (nodes can be graphs themselves), some methods and properties are only relevant for nested graphs, such as , , , and so on.
Note that the efficiency of the layout algorithms directly depends on the efficiency of the implementation of the graph model as well as the efficiency of the implementation of the underlying graph data structure.
The implementations of IGraphModel usually assume that the method is called after detaching the layouts when you no longer need the graph model instance; otherwise, some objects may not be garbage collected. If you allocate an instance of IGraphModel, you should call when your instance is no longer needed. Calling in your code is not necessary if the graph model instance is created internally by the IBM ILOG Diagram for .NET Graph Layout library, because then it will be called by the the system automatically. Internally allocated graph models occur for instance when you directly attach a GraphicContainer to a layout instance using , or when you use an for recursive layout.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel.GetGraphModel(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns a graph model instance for a subgraph of a nested graph.
member.remarks:
The current graph model must belong to the nested graph; for instance, it can be the root graph model or the parent graph model of the subgraph.
The typical way to deal with nested graphs is the following:
You create only the graph model for the root graph explicitly.
You retrieve the graph models of subgraphs by calling GetGraphModel(subgraph) on the root graph model. If a graph model has already been created for a subgraph, the graph model is returned. Otherwise, a new instance of a graph model is created.
The method must always return the same graph model for the same subgraph. The implementation of the method must remember which graph model is used for which subgraph.
member.param: The subgraph object. This is an object for which the method , called on the parent graph model of the returned graph model, returns . This must not be the root graph.
member.returns: The graph model that encapsulates subgraph.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel.IsLayoutNeeded(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout)
member.summary: Returns if a given layout that has been already applied to this graph is still valid.

member.summary: Called before a layout is performed.
member.param: The layout algorithm that is about to be performed.

member.summary: Called after a layout is performed.
member.param: The layout algorithm that was performed.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel.GetLinkPoints(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the points that define a link.
member.remarks:
The point at index 0 must correspond to the connection point of the link on the origin node. The point at the last index must correspond to the connection point of the link on the destination node.
A link must always have at least 2 points, corresponding to the connection points. Therefore, the length of the array returned by this method must be at least 2. The method must work for normal links and intergraph links.

member.summary: Reshapes a link.
member.remarks:
The method must work for normal links and intergraph links.
The link style represents the style of the shape of the link. The details of the shape of the link are given by the further arguments of the method. If the new shape of the link must be a straight-line link without any intermediate points, call the method with an empty array for the points argument, or with the value 0 for the length argument. In this case, the values of the arguments startIndex and length are ignored.
The mode parameters determine how the and should be used:
The or parameter contains no meaningful value. The layout does not specify how the corresponding origin or destination point of the link should be determined.
The or parameter contains a meaningful value. The layout wants to move the corresponding origin or destination point of the link to the specified point.
The or parameter contains no meaningful value. The layout wants to keep the previous corresponding origin or destination point of the link fixed, relative to the node position.
The or parameter contains no meaningful value. The layout wants to clip the corresponding origin or destination point of the link against the border of the node.
The or parameter contains a meaningful value. The layout wants to clip the corresponding origin or destination point of the link against the border of the node, but the link should go though the specified point.
member.param: The style of the shape of the link.
The connection point of the link on the origin node.
The mode that indicates how the should be used.
The array of intermediate points. Ignored if length is 0."/>
The starting position in the array of points.
The connection point of the link on the destination node.
The mode that indicates how the should be used.

member.remarks: Returns if the connection point of link on the origin or destination node is "pinned," and otherwise. The connection point is said to be "pinned" if its location is fixed with respect to the bounding box of the corresponding origin or destination node of the link. members.member:
This class contains utilities for managing node/link parameters.
To use the standard parameter storage mechanism (including input check), use the high-level API: Set/GetNode/Link/NodeOrLinkParameter
You can also use the lower-level API: Set/GetNode/Link/NodeOrLinkProperty
@author Adrian Vasiliu

Returns the graph model attached to a layout instance. If input check is enabled, the method checks (on request) whether nodeOrLink is a node/link contained in the graph model attached to the layout instance.
Returns the name of the layout property used to save layout parameters for a node.
Returns the name of the layout property used to save layout parameters for a link.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LayoutParametersUtil.GetGraphModel(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout)
member.summary: Returns the graph model of the specified layout. if no graph model was attached, create a temporary graph model and attach it. This method is called instead of all (3) occurences of layout.GetGraphModel() this file.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TempGraphicContainerAdapter
member.summary: The temporary graph model used to store the parameters before the real model is attached. We use a GraphicContainerAdapter: it stores the parameters in the properties of the graphic object, so when the new graph model is attached the properties will still be there (no need to transfer them).

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphicContainerAdapter
member.summary:
An encapsulates an and provides a bridge between the API of the and the API of the
is a concrete subclass of that allows a to be laid out using the layout algorithms provided in IBM ILOG Diagram for .NET. It provides an implementation for all the abstract methods of . It also provides overridden implementation of some non-abstract methods of , in order to improve the efficiency by taking advantage of the particularities of the .

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.AbstractGraphModel
member.summary: AbtractGraphModel is an abstract default implementation of .

remarks.p: This class can be used as base class for a concrete implementation of . It encapsulates some services that are common to all graph models. A special adapter class, , is provided in order to use an as the underlying graph data structure.

Note that you must call the method after detaching the layouts when you no longer need the graph model instance; otherwise, some objects may not be garbage collected. If you allocate an instance of AbstractGraphModel, you should call when your instance is no longer needed. Calling in your code is not necessary if the graph model instance is created internally by the IBM ILOG Diagram for .NET Graph Layout library, because then it will be called by the the system automatically. Internally allocated graph models occur for instance when you directly attach a GraphicContainer to a layout instance using , or when you use an for recursive layout.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.AbstractGraphModel.GetGraphModel(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns a graph model instance for a subgraph of a nested graph.
member.remarks:
The current graph model must belong to the nested graph; for instance, it can be the root graph model or the parent graph model of the subgraph.
The typical way to deal with nested graphs is the following:
You create only the graph model for the root graph explicitly.
You retrieve the graph models of subgraphs by calling GetGraphModel(subgraph) on the root graph model. If a graph model has already been created for a subgraph, the graph model is returned. Otherwise, a new instance of a graph model is created.
member.param: The subgraph object. This is an object for which the method , called on the parent graph model of the returned graph model, returns . This must not be the root graph.
member.returns: The graph model that encapsulates .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.AbstractGraphModel.CreateGraphModel(System.Object)
member.summary: Creates a new graph model for a subgraph.
member.remarks:
The method is called on the root graph model that encapsulates the root graph of the nested graph containing the subgraph.
Subclasses must override this method in order to return a new instance of the appropriate subclass of AbstractGraphModel, encapsulating .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.AbstractGraphModel.FireEvent(System.Object,ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphModelContentsChangedEventAction,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Notifies that nodes or links have been added or removed, or that their geometry has changed (nodes or links were moved or reshaped).

remarks.p: This method fires a graph model ContentsChanged event.
It is the responsibility of the graph model subclasses to call this method any time the contents of the model have changed (for example, when changes are due to user interaction).

This notification is needed to allow the graph layout algorithms to detect changes and avoid performing the layout when it is not needed. If a graph model subclass does not call this method but a change has occurred in the graph, you need to force a re-layout by passing a force flag of and calling the method .

If a series of events is fired due to major modifications of the contents, it is useful to start the series of events with an optional call of and then mark these events with flag set to . In this case, the series of the events must be followed by a call of to indicate the end of the series. This allows event handlers to optimize their treatment of series of events, since not all event handlers need to react on each single event of the series.

Furthermore, the notification is used by the default graph model () to ensure that and are called automatically at the right time. The GraphicContainerAdapter calls this method with event type or
whenever a node or link is removed. If you do not use the GraphicContainerAdapter or if your model does not fire these events, the cleanup is not automatically performed, so you need to call these cleaning methods yourself.

member.param: The object that was added, removed or moved, or if the event concerns unknown nodes or links.
Indicates whether this event is in a series of events.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.AbstractGraphModel.BeginUpdate
member.summary: Notifies that it is the start of a series of events.

remarks.p: This method fires a graph model ContentsChanged event that indicates the start of a series of events. This method can be called at the start of a series of events that have the updating flag enabled (see ). This method indicates the start of a major modification of the contents of the graph model, for example when adding, removing, moving, or reshaping many nodes or links.

It is the responsibility of the graph model subclasses to call this method before a series of updating events. If a BeginUpdate event before a series of updating events is missing, this is usually not fatal, while a missing EndUpdate may result in the layout not being automatically performed in automatic layout mode.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.AbstractGraphModel.EndUpdate
member.summary: Notifies that it is the end of a series of events.

remarks.p: This method fires a graph model ContentsChanged event that indicates the end of a series of events. This method must be called at the end of a series of events that have the updating flag enabled (see ). This method indicates the end of a major modification of the contents of the graph model, for example when adding, removing, moving, or reshaping many nodes or links.
It is the responsibility of the graph model subclasses to call this method after a series of updating events.

This notification is needed to allow the graph layout algorithms to detect changes and avoid performing the layout when it is not needed. If a graph model subclass does not call this method but a change has occurred in the graph, you need to force a re-layout by passing a force flag of and calling the method .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.AbstractGraphModel.GetLinkPoints(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the points that define a link.
member.remarks:
The point at index 0 must correspond to the connection point of the link on the origin node. The point at the last index must correspond to the connection point of the link on the destination node.
A link must always have at least 2 points, corresponding to the connection points. Therefore, the length of the array returned by this method must be at least 2. The method must work for normal links and intergraph links.

member.summary: Reshapes a link.
member.remarks:
The method must work for normal links and intergraph links.
The link style represents the style of the shape of the link. The details of the shape of the link are given by the further arguments of the method. If the new shape of the link must be a straight-line link without any intermediate points, call the method with an empty array for the points argument, or with the value 0 for the length argument. In this case, the values of the arguments startIndex and length are ignored.
The mode parameters determine how the and should be used:
The or parameter contains no meaningful value. The layout does not specify how the corresponding origin or destination point of the link should be determined.
The or parameter contains a meaningful value. The layout wants to move the corresponding origin or destination point of the link to the specified point.
The or parameter contains no meaningful value. The layout wants to keep the previous corresponding origin or destination point of the link fixed, relative to the node position.
The or parameter contains no meaningful value. The layout wants to clip the corresponding origin or destination point of the link against the border of the node.
The or parameter contains a meaningful value. The layout wants to clip the corresponding origin or destination point of the link against the border of the node, but the link should go though the specified point.
member.param: The style of the shape of the link.
The connection point of the link on the origin node.
The mode that indicates how the should be used.
The array of intermediate points. Ignored if length is 0."/>
The starting position in the array of points.
The connection point of the link on the destination node.
The mode that indicates how the should be used.

The connection point is said to be "pinned" if its location is fixed with respect to the bounding box of the corresponding origin or destination node of the link. member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphicContainerAdapter.CoordinatesMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the coordinates mode to be used outside layout.
member.remarks:
Sets the coordinates mode to be used outside layout. Valid value are:
The geometry of the graph is computed using the coordinate space of the encapsulated without applying any transformation.
This mode should be used if you visualize the graph at zoom level 1, or you do not visualize it at all, or the grapher contains only fully zoomable objects. In all these cases there is no need to take the transformer into account during the layout.
Note that in this mode the dimensional parameters of the layout algorithms are considered as being specified in manager coordinates.
The geometry of the graph is computed in the coordinate space of the reference . More exactly, all the coordinates are transformed using the current reference transformer.
This mode should be used if you want the dimensional parameters of the layout algorithms to be considered as being specified in manager view coordinates.
The geometry of the graph is computed using the coordinate system of the graphic container and then transforming them back into the coordinate system of the manager (by applying the inverse transformation). This mode is equivalent to the "graphic container coordinates" mode if the geometry of the graphic objects strictly obeys the transformer. (A small difference may exist because of the limited precision of the computations.)
On the contrary, if some graphic objects are either nonzoomable or semizoomable (for example, links with a maximum line width), this mode gives different results than the manager coordinates mode. These results are optimal if the grapher is visualized using the same transformer as the one taken into account during the layout.
Note that in this mode the dimensional parameters of the layout algorithms are considered as being specified in manager coordinates.
The default value is .
Note: this coordinates mode is only used when layout is not running. While layout is running, the coordinates mode of the layout instance is used (see ).

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphicContainerAdapter.ReferenceView
member.summary: Gets or sets the view that is used to retrieve the reference transformer used when the property is or .
member.remarks: If this property is not , the property always returns the transformation of the reference view.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphicContainerAdapter.ReferenceTransform
member.summary: Gets or sets the transformation used when property is or .
member.remarks: If the property is not , the reference transformation is always the transformation of the view. So, setting the property is useful only when the property is .

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout
member.summary: The base class of the Graph Layout algorithms.

remarks.p: IBM ILOG Diagram for .NET provides special support for applications that need to display graphs (also called networks) of nodes and links. Using the class, any graphic object can be defined to behave like a node and can be connected to other nodes with links, which themselves can have many different forms. Used in conjunction with layout algorithms, this feature is often used to create network topologies for telecommunications networks and system management applications.

The usage of the Graph Layout algorithms is not restricted to applications using an to store and display the graph. You can use external graph data source structures. This is achieved through the generic graph model (see ). This interface defines the API that is necessary to allow the graph layout algorithms to work. To use an external graph, all you need to do is to implement an adapter that connects the graph with the generic graph model. For details, see the class .
The class GraphLayout is abstract and cannot be used directly. You must use one of its concrete subclasses.

You can also create your own subclasses to implement other layout algorithms. Note that, in order to be applied on any graph, the layout algorithms must be written using the API of instead of the API of .

The class contains layout parameters or options that can be useful for different layout algorithms. The implementation of the method is solely responsible for whether or not the current settings of the parameters are taken into account.

Note that all layout parameters that are specific to nodes or links, such as the "fixed" attribute (see , ), can be accessed only while the graph that contains the nodes or links is attached to the layout instance. Also, if the attached graph model is an , layout parameters that are specific to nodes or links must be set after specifying filtering rules (see ).

If the documentation does not indicate a different coordinate space, all dimensional parameters are expressed in the same coordinate space as the position and dimension of the nodes and the link points. In particular, when laying out an , the dimensional parameters are expressed by default in the coordinate space of the graphic container, not in the coordinate space of the view (). However, optionally, the coordinate space of the view can be used. For details, see .

If you want to perform the layout on a subset of the nodes and links of and , you can use a filter (see the class and the property ). The filter allows the layout algorithm to determine, for each node and link of a graph, if it must be taken into account or can be ignored.

If you want to perform the layout recursively over a nested graph (for instance, an contained in another ), you can use the method
and pass for the traverse argument.

To learn more about the layout algorithms and the corresponding GraphLayout subclasses, read the sections of the Reference Manual describing those classes and the IBM ILOG Diagram for .NET Graph Layout User's Manual.

Note that, when implementing a subclass of GraphLayout, the initialization of all instance variables of the subclass needs to be done in the overridden implementation of the method . This is to prevent execution of methods of the subclasses before the initialization of the instance variables of the subclasses.

Note also that you must call the method when you no longer need the layout instance; otherwise, some objects may not be garbage collected. This is necessary only if the layout instance is directly created by your code. Calling is not necessary if the layout instance is created internally by the ILOG Diagram for .NET Graph Layout library, when using an for recursive layout.

member.summary: Creates a new layout instance by copying an existing one.
member.remarks:
This constructor is used by the method. Any subclass should provide a copy constructor.
The parameters of the source layout are copied using the method . The attached graph is not copied.
member.param: The layout instance that is copied.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.CopyParameters(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout)
member.summary: Copies the parameters from a given layout instance.

remarks.p:
Note that the parameters which are specific to a node or a link are not copied. The other parameters, including the layout region specification and the link connection box interfaces, are also copied. If the method
returns , a copy of the layout instance used for laying out the connected components is set on this layout instance.
If a method of the type SupportsXXX is associated with a parameter, the parameter is copied only if the corresponding method returns .
Subclasses that need to copy additional parameters must override this method. The method can be implemented as follows:
remarks.code: Public Overloads Overrides Sub CopyParameters(ByVal source As GraphLayout) MyBase.CopyParameters(source) ' SubClassLayout is the name of the subclass If TypeOf source Is SubClassLayout Then Dim msource As SubClassLayout = CType(source, SubClassLayout) ' copy the parameters of the subclass SomeParameter = msource.SomeParameter End If End Sub

member.param: The layout instance from which the parameters are copied.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.Init
member.summary: Initializes instance variables.

remarks.p: You should not call this method directly. The method is called internally by the constructor without arguments and by the copy constructor.
The method must be overridden by subclasses that need to initialize additional instance variables. The initialization of all the instance variables of the subclasses must be done in this method.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.Copy
member.summary: Copies the layout instance.

remarks.p: This method must return a copy of this layout instance by calling a constructor defined as follows: public <CLASSNAME>(<CLASSNAME> source).
When performing a recursive layout on a nested graph, this method is used by to "clone" the layout instance of a parent graph.

Note that the parameters which are specific to a node or a link are not copied. The other parameters, including the layout region specification and the link clip and link connection box interfaces, are also copied. If the method
returns , a copy of the layout instance used for laying out the connected components is set on the new instance.
If a method of the type SupportsXXX is associated with a parameter, the parameter is copied only if the corresponding method returns .

member.returns: A copy of the layout instance.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.GetInstanceId
member.summary: A utility method that returns a unique integer value for each layout instance inside the same C# program.
member.remarks: This method can be used to obtain names for properties that are unique for each layout instance.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.Attach(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphicContainer)
member.summary: Sets the graphic container to be laid out.
member.remarks:
This method automatically creates an to encapsulate the graphic container. Then, the adapter is attached to the layout instance by calling the method .
You must attach the graphic container before performing the layout, that is, before calling the method , and before specifying layout parameters for specific nodes or links.
The method does nothing if the graphic container is already attached.
You can get the GrapherAdapter instance created by this method using . However, notice that you are not allowed to do the following:
Attach this adapter to any other layout instance.
Use this adapter in any way once the method has been called on the layout instance.
In case you need to be able to do any of the above operations, create directly the instance of GrapherAdapter and attach it using .
To determine whether a given GraphModel instance has been created using , you can use the method . This method returns a non- object if the model has not been created using .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.Attach(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel)
member.summary: Sets the graph model to be laid out.

remarks.p: You must attach the graph model before performing the layout, that is, before calling the method , and before specifying layout parameters for specific nodes or links.
This method first calls if a graph model is already attached. The method calls , passing this layout instance as argument.

member.param: The graph model to lay out.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.Detach
member.summary: Detaches the graph model from the layout instance.

remarks.p:
When a new graph model is attached to the layout instance, it is not necessary to detach the previously attached graph model because this is done automatically when the method
is called.

This method performs cleaning operations on the graph model (for example, properties added to the graph model objects and graph model event handlers are removed). The method
is called with the currently attached graph model as the argument. The methods and are called for each node and link returned by the methods , and .
If the model currently attached is an internally created using the method , the method is called on it. Notice that in this case you can no longer use the adapter instance.
Subclasses can override this method to remove additional information stored in the layout instance.
The method calls , passing this layout instance as an argument. If the model has been internally created using the method , the method is called just before disposing of the model.
Note that you must call this method when you no longer need the layout instance; otherwise, some objects may not be garbage collected.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.CleanGraphModel(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel)
member.summary: Cleans a graph model.
member.remarks:
This method removes any data that has been stored by the layout algorithm on a graph model.
Subclasses can override this method to remove additional information stored in the graph model.
member.param: The graph model to be cleaned.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.CleanNode(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel,System.Object)
member.summary: Cleans a node.
member.remarks:
This method removes any data that has been stored by the layout algorithm on a node.
The method is automatically called by
whenever a of type is received.
Subclasses can override this method to remove additional information stored in the nodes.
Notice that the method may be called multiple times for the same node. At the time this method is called, the node may already be removed; therefore, overridden versions of this method should be implemented so that they work even if the object is no longer a node of .
member.param: The graph model to which the belongs.

member.summary: Cleans a link.
member.remarks:
This method removes any data that has been stored by the layout algorithm on a regular link or on an intergraph link.
The method is automatically called by
whenever a of type is received.
Subclasses can override this method to remove additional information stored in the links.
Notice that the method may be called multiple times for the same link. At the time this method is called, the link may already be removed; therefore, overridden versions of this method should be implemented so that they work even if the object is no longer a link of .
member.param: The graph model to which the belongs.

member.summary: Returns the graph model to lay out if a graph model is attached.

Otherwise, the method returns .
If an is attached directly using , the method returns the instance of that has been created internally. Note that in this case the model cannot be used once the method has been called and cannot be attached to any other layout instance.
Note that, during the layout of a disconnected graph by a layout class that supports the connected components layout mechanism (see ) and for which this mechanism is enabled (see ), the method

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.SetParentLayout(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout)
member.summary: Sets the parent layout of this layout instance.
member.remarks: You should not call this method directly.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.GetParentLayout
member.summary: Returns the parent layout.
member.remarks:
If a layout instance A creates or uses another layout instance B to accomplish a part of or the total layout work, the layout instance A is called the "parent" of the layout instance B. The parent layout instance is responsible for declaring itself as a parent of B by calling the method
on it. The layout instance B is called a sublayout of A.
Sublayouts never have their own local event handlers for the LayoutStepPerformed event. Layout events have parent layouts as the source.
The method returns if the layout instance has no parent.

member.remarks:
The default implementation returns a new instance of .

This method is called by . The returned object is stored internally in the layout instance and will be returned by the method .
You can use this method to obtain information about the behavior of the layout algorithm if the information is added in the layout report inside the implementation of the method, where it can be obtained using .
While the method is running, you can also obtain the layout report outside this method via handlers of the event.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.SetLayoutReport(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutReport)

with the layout report created using the method . Subclasses can override this method to perform additional actions.

with the force argument set to .

The layout report returned by

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.PerformLayout(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Starts the layout algorithm using the currently attached graph model and the current settings for the layout parameters.

remarks.p:
The method first calls
to obtain a new instance of the layout report. This instance is stored internally and can be used to obtain information about the behavior of the layout algorithm when the method returns. The implementation of the method is solely responsible for adding this information to the layout report. Note that subclasses of GraphLayout can override the method
in order to return a subclass of of when additional information needs to be stored in the report.
If the graph is empty (that is, it does not contain any node) the appropriate code () is stored in the layout report and the method returns.

If the argument is , the method calls
to determine if it is necessary to perform the layout. If this method returns , the appropriate code () is stored in the layout report and the method returns.

Otherwise, if the argument is or
returns , the method is called on the attached graph model. Then the method , which executes the layout algorithm, is called.

Instead of directly calling the method on the attached graph model, layout classes which support the connected components layout (see ) and for which this mechanism is enabled (see
first cut the graph model into connected components. Then each connected component is laid out separately by a call of the method . To do this, the attached graph model is temporarily changed into an internally generated graph model corresponding to each of the connected components of the original graph. Finally, the layout instance returned by the property
is used to position the connected components.
Note that while the method is running, you can also obtain the layout report outside this method using the layout event handler mechanism (see ).

If the layout is successfully performed (that is, if the property called on the layout report instance returns or ), the layout instance is notified that the structure, the geometry, and the parameters are now up-to-date (see the properties , , and ).
In any case, if the method has been called, the method is finally called on the attached graph model.

member.param:
If , the method
is not called. No check is made to determine if it is necessary to perform the layout.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.PerformLayout(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Starts the layout algorithm using the currently attached graph model and the current settings for the layout parameters.

remarks.p:
If the argument is , the method simply calls
passing the argument. Note that if the attached graph is a nested graph, this applies the layout only on the topmost graph and does not apply recursively on the subgraphs. In this case, the return value is the result code stored in the layout report (see ).

If the argument is , the layout is applied to the attached graph model and recursively to all subgraph models of the attached graph model. In fact, clones of this layout are attached and used for the subgraph models. This is equivalent to GetRecursiveLayout().PerformLayout(force). In this case, the return value is the combined result code of all layout calls:
- The graph is empty.
- The layout was up-to-date in the graph and in all subgraphs.
- The layout was successfully done in the graph and in all subgraphs, as needed.
- The layout was successfully done in the graph and in all subgraphs, as needed, but some layouts of subgraphs run out of time before completion and stored the result code in their layout reports.
- The layout was not completed. The method
was called, or the layout of one of the subgraphs run out of time before completion and stored the result code in its layout report. In this case, the entire recursion stopped immediately, and the layouts of the remaining subgraphs was not done.
To get the report of the Recursive Layout after performing layout, you can call GetRecursiveLayout().GetLayoutReport(). To get the report of the layout of a specific subgraph, you can call GetRecursiveLayout().GetLayoutReport(subgraph). You can also install a handler for the LayoutStepPerformed event for all layouts of subgraphs via GetRecursiveLayout().SubLayoutStepPerformed.

This method is the simplest way to apply a single layout recursively on an entire nested graph. If different layout algorithms need to be used for different subgraphs, or some subgraphs should not be laid out at all, you should explicitly allocate a Recursive Layout and either use the internal provider mode or the specified provider mode (see ).

member.returns: The layout code.
member.param:
If , the method
is not called. No check is made to determine if it is necessary to perform the layout.
If , the layout is applied to the attached graph model and recursively to all subgraph models of the attached graph model. Otherwise, it is only applied on the attached graph model.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.PerformSublayout(System.Object,ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Starts the input layout algorithm.
member.remarks: This is used when this layout controls the input layout as sublayout. Layout classes can override this method if changes are needed with respect to the way how the input layout is started. You should not call this method directly.
member.param: The subgraph if used during nested layout, or .
If , no check is made to determine if it is necessary to perform the layout.
member.returns: The layout code. See .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.GetRecursiveLayout
member.summary:
Returns the instance of Recursive Layout that is used to perform this layout recursively when you call
with the traverse flag set to .
member.remarks:
The returned instance of Recursive Layout uses this layout as a reference layout, and it is attached to the same graph model as this graph model. You should call this method only when a graph model is attached. You should neither detach the returned layout nor attach it to any other graph model.
You can use this instance of Recursive Layout to set parameters per node or link for the layout of a subgraph, and to save or load the settings from the named properties.
The returned instance always uses the reference layout mode (see ).

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.GetLayouts(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns the instances of GraphLayout for the nested graph encapsulated by the graph model of this layout instance.

remarks.p: It returns this layout instance and recursively the layout instances for all subgraphs that are clones of this layout instance. The order of the enumeration can be preorder (that is, the layout of the parent graph comes before the layout of the subgraphs) or postorder (that is, the layout of the subgraphs comes before the layout of the parent graph).
This method is equivalent to GetRecursiveLayout().GetLayouts(preOrder).

member.param: If , the layout instances are returned in preorder, otherwise in postorder.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.GetLayout(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the layout instance for a subgraph of the nested graph encapsulated by the graph model of this layout instance.
member.remarks:
The returned layout instance is a clone of this layout instance.
This method is equivalent to GetRecursiveLayout().GetLayout(subgraph).
member.param: The subgraph object. This must not be the root graph.
member.returns: The layout instance.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.IsLayoutNeeded
member.summary: Verifies that it is necessary to perform the layout.
member.remarks:
The default implementation returns the value returned by a call of the method on the attached graph model, with this layout instance as argument.
If no graph model is attached, the method returns .
Basically, the method returns if no changes occurred on the graph model (no nodes or links were inserted, removed, reshaped, or moved) and no parameters changed since the last time the layout was successfully performed using this layout instance. Otherwise, the method returns .
member.returns: if it is necessary to perform the layout, otherwise.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.Layout
member.summary: Executes the layout.

remarks.p: This method must be implemented by each layout algorithm (subclasses of GraphLayout). This method computes the coordinates of the nodes in the attached graph model and moves the nodes to the new positions using the method .
The method can also perform reshape operations on the links using the method .

When writing the implementation of this method, you can obtain an instance of the layout report using
and store particular information about the behavior of the layout algorithm in the layout report. You can also notify the handlers for the LayoutStepPerformed event using the method .
When the layout algorithm is finished and if the layout is performed successfully, you must set the property to the value on the layout report instance.
Here is a sample implementation for a Random layout:
remarks.code:
Protected Sub Layout() ' obtain the graph model Dim graphModel As IGraphModel = GetGraphModel ' obtain the layout report Dim layoutReport As GraphLayoutReport = GetLayoutReport ' obtain how many steps to do Dim stepsToGo As Integer = graphModel.Nodes.Count Dim stepsGone As Integer = 1
' obtain the layout region Dim rect As Rectangle2D = GetCalcLayoutRegion Dim xMin As Single = rect.X Dim yMin As Single = rect.Y Dim xMax As Single = rect.X + rect.Width Dim yMax As Single = rect.Y + rect.Height
' initialize the random generator Dim random As System.Random = New System.Random If UseSeedValueForRandomGenerator Then random = New System.Random(SeedValueForRandomGenerator) End If
' browse the nodes For Each node As Object In graphModel.Nodes
' skip fixed nodes If Not (PreserveFixedNodes AndAlso GetFixed(node)) Then
' compute coordinates Dim x As Single = xMin + (xMax - xMin) * CType(random.NextDouble, Single) Dim y As Single = yMin + (yMax - yMin) * CType(random.NextDouble, Single) ' move the node to the computed position graphModel.MoveNode(node, x, y)
' notify handlers on layout step performed events IncreasePercentageComplete(System.Math.Min( _ System.Threading.Interlocked.Increment(stepsGone),stepsGone-1) _ * 100 / stepsToGo)
' Call ...IfNeeded to avoid that we sent events too often OnLayoutStepPerformedIfNeeded
End If Next
' final notification that we are at 100% complete IncreasePercentageComplete(100) OnLayoutStepPerformed(False, False)
' Set the final result code layoutReport.Code = GraphLayoutReportCode.LayoutDone End Sub

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.IsLayoutRunning
member.summary: Indicates whether the layout algorithm is running or not.
member.remarks:
It returns if the layout has been started and is not yet completed. It returns otherwise.
The layout is considered as started once the method
is called. It is considered as completed after this method returns or throws an exception.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.OnLayoutStepPerformed(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Fires a graph layout LayoutStepPerformed event/
member.param: Indicates whether it is the very first event during the execution of this layout.
Indicates whether it is the very last event during the execution of this layout.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.OnLayoutStepPerformedIfNeeded
member.summary: Calls layoutStepPerformed when necessary.

remarks.p:
This method is provided for convenience in the implementation of layout algorithms. It calls
when the last call finished earlier than the minimal busy time before this call. It avoids calling
when the layout time has elapsed or when the layout is notified to stop immediately, if the algorithm supports these features.

This mechanism is used by some algorithms to avoid the overhead of
becoming too high if it is called too often. Internal routines of layout algorithms can use callLayoutStepPerformedIfNeeded often without worrying that too many layout events are raised.

Layout algorithms call
directly instead of using callLayoutStepPerformedIfNeeded when it is necessary to report a specific state (for example, when the layout report sets the code or ).

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.OnParameterChanged(System.String)
member.summary: This method is called when a global layout parameter changed.
member.remarks:
Global layout parameters affect all or many nodes and links. It sets the property
to to notify the layout instance that the layout is not anymore up to date. It also fires a graph layout parameter event. If you add new global parameters in your own subclass of GraphLayout, you should call this method each time they are modified.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.OnParameterChanged(System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: This method is called when a layout parameter for a specific node or link changed.
member.remarks:
It sets the property
to to notify the layout instance that the layout is not anymore up to date. It also fires a graph layout parameter event. If you add new parameters for specific nodes and links in your own subclass of GraphLayout, you should call this method each time they are modified.

members.member:
Indicates whether the layout class allows the user to specify fixed nodes.
Fixed nodes are not moved during the layout.
The default implementation always returns . Subclasses can override this method in order to return , that is, to indicate that this option is supported.
Note that fixed nodes can be handled differently by different layout algorithms. Some layout algorithms can adapt the layout of the nonfixed nodes to take into account the current positions of the fixed nodes. For details, see the documentation of the layout algorithm.
'/>
Always .

Sets the specified node or link as fixed.
Fixed nodes are not moved during the layout only if the value of the property is .
By default, no node is fixed.
Fixed links are not reshaped during the layout only if the value of the property is .
By default, no link is fixed.
If the argument is a node, the setter of this property throws an exception if the layout class does not support fixed nodes. If the argument is a link, the setter of this property throws an exception is thrown an exception if the layout class does not support fixed links.
An exception is also thrown if the node or link does not belong to the attached graph model.
'/>
'/>

Returns whether the node or link is specified as fixed.
'/>
'/>

Removes the fixed attribute from all nodes in the graph model.
An exception is thrown if the layout class does not support this option or if there is no attached graph model.

Indicates whether the layout class allows the user to specify fixed links.
Fixed links are not reshaped during the layout.
The default implementation always returns . Subclasses can override this method in order to return ; that is, to indicate that this option is supported.
'/>
always .

Removes the fixed attribute from all links in the graph model.
An exception is thrown if the layout class does not support this option or if there is no attached graph model.
