member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.SupportsPercentageComplete
member.summary: Indicates whether the layout class can estimate the percentage of completion during the run of layout.
member.remarks:
If supported, the percentage is stored in the layout report and can be retrieved by any event handler for the LayoutStepPerformed event. For instance, this feature can be used by a progress bar that shows how much of the layout has already been performed.
The default implementation always returns . Subclasses can override this method in order to return ; that is, to indicate that this option is supported.
member.returns: Always .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.IncreasePercentageComplete(System.Int32)
member.summary: Increases the percentage of completion that is stored in the layout report to the input value.
member.remarks: Layout algorithms that support the percentage complete feature should call this method during the run of the layout. This method does not set the percentage to a lower value than the previous value. It also does not set the value to more than 100%. It silently ignores wrong input values.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.SupportsStopImmediately
member.summary: Indicates whether the layout class can interrupt the current run of layout immediately in a controlled way.

remarks.p: The default implementation always returns . Subclasses can override this method in order to return , that is, to indicate that this option is supported.

member.returns: Always .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.StopImmediately
member.summary: Stops the running layout algorithm as soon as possible.

remarks.p:
This method only sets the flag
to . It is the sole responsibility of the implementation of the method to react in an appropriate way. Layout algorithms that support the immediate stop feature should check this flag from time to time and react when the flag
changes to .

This method can be used when multiple threads are used for layout and GUI control. The GUI control thread calls this method to notify the layout thread that the layout run must be stopped. This method returns if the stop is possible and otherwise. The layout algorithm will perform final cleanup operations before terminating. Therefore, the layout thread will continue until the cleanup operations are finished. The GUI thread, however, returns immediately from this method.
Layout algorithms that are stopped in this way set the result code of the layout report either to or to .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.IsStoppedImmediately
member.summary:
Returns if the method
was called.
member.remarks: Layout algorithm classes can use this method to recognize that it was requested to stop the current layout run.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.IsLayoutOfConnectedComponentsEnabledByDefault
member.summary: Returns if the connected components layout mechanism is enabled by default.
member.remarks:
Otherwise, the method returns .
The default implementation always returns .
Subclasses can override this method in order to return , that is, to indicate that the connected components layout is enabled by default.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.GetLayoutOfConnectedComponentsReport
member.summary: Returns the layout report containing information about the behavior of the connected components layout.

remarks.p: This method returns the instance of the layout report created by the connected components layout instance.

If the last run of the layout did not use the connected components layout (because either the graph was connected, the layout does not support this feature, this feature was disabled, or an exception occurred during the layout process), the method returns .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.SupportsLayoutRegion
member.summary: Indicates whether the layout class can control the position and/or size of the graph drawing according to a user-defined region (a rectangle) or a user-defined area of a manager view.

remarks.p: The default implementation always returns .
Subclasses can override this method in order to return , that is, to indicate that this option is supported.

member.returns: Always .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.GetSpecLayoutRegion
member.summary: Returns the rectangle that defines the layout region, as specified using and .

remarks.p: Note that if the attached graph is an GraphicContainer or an GraphicContainerAdapter, the dimensions of the rectangle are in graphic container coordinates, and not in diagram view coordinates.

Several cases can occur:
1. If the layout region mode is , and a rectangle has been specified for the layout region property, it returns this rectangle with no transformation.
2. If the layout region mode is , and a rectangle has been specified for the layout region property, it returns this rectangle transformed to graphic container coordinates using the transformer of the reference view.
3. If the layout region mode is , and a rectangle has been specified for the layout region property, it returns a rectangle with the attributes X=0, Y=0 and the Width/Height equal to the current Width/Height of the view transformed to graphic container coordinates using the current transformer of the view. (However, the transformation to graphic container coordinates is not done if the coordinates mode is .)
4. If no layout region is specified, the default behavior is to return a rectangle with the dimensions W=0, Y=0 and the Width/Height equal to the current Width/Height of the first attached view, transformed to graphic container coordinates using the transformer of the view. (However, the transformation to graphic container coordinates is not done if the coordinates mode is .) If no view is attached, or the width or height of the view is zero, the method returns .

The implementation of the method in subclasses of GraphLayout is solely responsible for whether the rectangle returned by this method is taken into account when calculating the layout, and in which manner.

The method returns in the following cases:
The layout region mechanism is not supported (that is,
returns ).
The layout region mode requires to consider the size of the view but the view has a width or height equal to zero, or no view is attached to the , or no graph model is attached to the layout.
Note that, when the layout region depends on the size of a view, the layout region can change with time, for example because the size of the view changes, or its transformer is changed.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.GetCalcLayoutRegion
member.summary: Returns the rectangle that defines the layout region parameter.

remarks.p: This method first tries to use the layout region specification by calling . If this method does not return a , this rectangle is returned. Otherwise, the method tries to estimate an appropriate layout region according to the number and size of the nodes in the attached graph. If no graph is attached or the attached graph is empty, it returns a default rectangle (0, 0, 1000, 1000).

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.IsFitToView
member.summary: Returns if the graph drawing must fit (exactly or approximately) an area of a given diagram view.
member.remarks:
This is the case when the layout region mode is
or . Otherwise, the method returns .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.SupportsRandomGenerator
member.summary: Indicates whether the layout class uses randomly generated numbers (or randomly chosen parameters) for which it can accept a user-defined seed value.
member.remarks:
When you perform the same layout on the same graph several times and use the same user-defined seed value (or some other constant value), the same random numbers are generated and, if the algorithm is deterministic, you obtain the same drawing of the graph model. If you want different drawings each time you perform the layout, you can modify the seed value and set the property
to the value .
For example, you can use this parameter in the implementation of the method in the following way:
Random random; if (isUseSeedValueForRandomGenerator()) random = new Random(getSeedValueForRandomGenerator()); else random = new Random();
The default implementation always returns .
Subclasses can override this method in order to return , that is, to indicate that this option is supported.
member.returns: Always .

member.summary: Performs the layout again following a structural or geometric change of the graph.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.SupportsLinkConnectionBox
member.summary: Indicates whether the layout class can use a link connection box interface to calculate the end points of a link.
member.remarks:
The link connection box interface is an object that provides the rectangle to which the links are connected for each node and the tangential shift offset at each side for the connection points.
If the layout class supports this feature and a connection box interface object is set at the property , the layout algorithm uses this object to calculate the connection points for links. If additionally the clip mode is enabled (see ) the layout tells the graph model to obtain the final connection points by clipping against the shape of the nodes via the reshape mode of .
The default implementation always returns . Subclasses can override this method in order to return , that is, to indicate that this option is supported.
member.returns: Always .

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.LayoutRegion
member.summary: Gets or sets the layout region.

remarks.para: For subclasses that support this parameter, the layout region is usually the rectangle that the graph must fit (exactly or approximately) after the layout is performed, or the rectangle which influences the position and/or size of the resulting layout. The way the layout region parameter is taken into account is the sole responsibility of the subclasses.
The layout region is interpreted according to the property.
If is , the is interpreted as a rectangle in the coordinate system of the to which this layout is attached.
If is , the is interpreted as a rectangle in the coordinate system of the reference view.
If is , the is ignored, and the layout region is set to the visible area of the reference view.
The reference view is the first view (an object of type ) that displays the to which this layout is attached.
Note: if the width or height of the are less than zero, the behavior is always as if was .

member.remarks:
This is the time between two calls of
when the method
is used.
The objective is to avoid the overhead of
becoming too high if the method is called too often. Internal routines of layout algorithms usually call , which calls
if the time since the last call was at least the minimal busy time.
The default value is 50 (milliseconds).

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.StructureUpToDate
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the structure of the graph is up to date.

remarks.p: Returns if at least one modification occurred in the structure of the graph model (a node or link was added or removed) since the last time the layout was successfully performed on the same graph model using this layout instance or if the layout has never been performed successfully on the same graph model. The following are considered to be modifications of the structure: adding or removing a node or link, or modifying the filter (see ).
Returns if no changes occurred.
This method is automatically called by .

Note that when the layout is performed successfully (that is, called on the layout report returns ), the layout instance is automatically notified that the structure is now up-to-date. It is also automatically notified of the topological modifications of the graph model.

member.value: Whether the structure of the graph is up to date.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.GeometryUpToDate
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the geometry of the graph is up to date.

remarks.p: Returns if at least one node or link was moved or reshaped since the last time the layout was successfully performed on the same graph model or if the layout has never been performed successfully on the same graph model.
Returns if no changes occurred.
This method is automatically called by .

Note that when the layout is performed successfully (that is, called on the layout report returns ), the layout instance is automatically notified that the geometry of the graph is now up-to-date. It is also automatically notified of the modifications of the geometry of the graph model.

member.value: Whether the geometry of the graph is up to date.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.CoordinatesMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the coordinates mode to be used during layout.

remarks.p:
Valid values are:
- The geometry of the graph is computed using the coordinate space of the graphic container (that is, the attached ) without applying any transformation.
This mode should be used if you visualize the graph at zoom level 1, or you do not visualize it at all, or the graph contains only fully zoomable objects. In all these cases there is no need to take the transformer into account during the layout.
Note that in this mode the dimensional parameters of the layout algorithms are considered as being specified in graphic container coordinates.
- The geometry of the graph is computed in the coordinate space of the diagram view. More exactly, all the coordinates are transformed using the current reference transformer.
This mode should be used if you want the dimensional parameters of the layout algorithms to be considered as being specified in diagram view coordinates.
- The geometry of the graph is computed using the coordinate space of the diagram view and then applying the inverse transformation. This mode is equivalent to the "graphic container coordinates" mode if the geometry of the graphic objects strictly obeys the transformer. (A small difference may exist because of the limited precision of the computations.)
On the contrary, if some graphic objects are either nonzoomable or semizoomable (for example, links with a maximum line width), this mode gives different results than the graphic container coordinates mode. These results are optimal if the graph is visualized using the same transformer as the one taken into account during the layout.
Note that in this mode the dimensional parameters of the layout algorithms are considered as being specified in graphic container coordinates.
The default value is .

This option is useful only if the attached graph model is an (or a subclass). Otherwise, it has no effect. Note: the coordinates mode of the layout is used only while this layout is running. If layout is not running, operations on the graphic container adapter use the coordinates mode that was set on the graphic container adapter directly (see ).

member.value: The coordinates mode to be used during layout.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.ParametersUpToDate
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the layout parameters are up to date.

remarks.p: Returns if at least one parameter was modified since the last time the layout was successfully performed on the same graph or if the layout has never been performed successfully on the same graph.
Returns if no parameters changed since the last time the layout was successfully performed on the same graph model.

If a layout class supports the layout of the connected components (that is,
returns ) and if this mechanism is enabled (that is,
returns ), an additional test is performed to check that the layout of the connected components is up-to-date. Therefore, the property is if the graph is disconnected and the property
called on the layout instance returned by
returns .

If a layout class supports the layout region mechanism (that is,
returns ) and if a diagram view must be taken into account for the computation of the layout region in manager coordinates (see ), an additional test is performed to verify that the size of the diagram view has changed. The property is if a change occurred.
This method is automatically called by .
Note that when the layout is performed successfully (that is, called on the layout report returns ), the layout instance is automatically notified that the parameters are now up-to-date.

member.value: Whether the layout parameters are up to date.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.InputCheckEnabled
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the checks for the nodes and/or links provided as arguments for the different methods of the layout algorithms are enabled.

remarks.p: If enabled, methods that require a node or a link as an argument check whether the object they receive is really a node or a link in the attached graph (using the methods and ).
The default value is . The checks can be disabled to avoid their overhead cost.

member.value: Whether the checks for the nodes and/or links provided as arguments for the different methods of the layout algorithms are enabled.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.PreserveFixedNodes
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the layout avoids movement of fixed nodes.
member.remarks:
If the argument is , specifies that the layout is not allowed to move the nodes indicated as fixed by the user. If the argument is , the layout is free to move all the nodes of the graph. (This does not change the setting for the fixed nodes, which can still be used at any time in the future.)
The default value is .
An exception is thrown if the layout class does not support this option.
Note that fixed nodes can be handled differently by different layout algorithms. Some layout algorithms can adapt the layout of the nonfixed nodes to take into account the current positions of the fixed nodes. For details, see the documentation of the layout algorithm.
member.value: Whether the layout avoids movement of fixed nodes.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.PreserveFixedLinks
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the layout avoids movement of fixed links.
member.remarks:
If the argument is , specifies that the layout is not allowed to reshape the links indicated as fixed by the user. If the argument is , the layout is free to reshape all the links of the graph. (This does not change the setting for the fixed links, which can still be used at any time in the future.)
The default value is .
An exception is thrown if the layout class does not support this option.
member.value: Whether the layout avoids movement of fixed links.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.LayoutOfConnectedComponentsEnabled
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the generic connected component layout mechanism is enabled.
member.remarks:
If enabled on a layout class that supports this mechanism (see ), the method
cuts the attached graph model into connected components and lays out each connected component separately. Then the connected components are placed using the layout instance returned by the property .
Notice that the connected component layout is not used if the graph is connected.
An exception is thrown if the layout does not support this mechanism.
The default value is the value returned by the property .
member.value: Set to to enable the connected component layout mechanism, or to disable.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.LayoutOfConnectedComponents
member.summary: Gets or sets the layout instance that lays out the connected components of the graph.
member.remarks:
When this property is not set, a default layout instance (see
is used. You can set this property to to return to the default connected components layout instance.
An exception is thrown if the layout does not support this mechanism.
Note the following points:
The layout instance passed as the argument cannot be used independently as long as it is set as a connected component layout.
The connected component layout is not used if the graph is connected.
member.value: The layout instance to set, or to return to the default layout instance.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.AllowedTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the upper limit for the duration of the layout algorithm.

remarks.p: When an iterative layout algorithm is used, the iterations can be stopped when this time is exceeded. Noniterative algorithms can also use this parameter as an upper limit for the computation time. The default value is normally 32000 (32 seconds). Subclasses that support this feature can use a different default value depending on their particular behavior. Layout algorithms that are stopped in this way set the result code of the layout report either to or to .

When the connected components of disconnected graphs are laid out separately (see ), the specified allowed time is considered as the total time for the layout of all the connected components plus the time for the connected components layout.

Note that the method
does NOT automatically stop the layout when the allowed time is exceeded. It is the sole responsibility of the implementation of the method to do this.
An exception is thrown if the layout does not support this mechanism.

member.value: The allowed time in milliseconds.

member.summary: Gets or sets the auto layout handler.
member.value: The auto layout handler.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether the auto layout mode is enabled.
member.remarks:
If the argument is , the layout is automatically performed each time the layout instance is notified that the geometry or the structure of the graph has changed.
The default value is .
member.value: Whether the auto layout mode is enabled.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.LinkConnectionBoxProvider
member.summary: Gets or sets the link connection box interface for the connection points of links.
member.remarks:
The link connection box interface is an object that provides the rectangle to which the links are connected for each node and the tangential shift offset at each side for the connection points.
By default, the layout algorithm places the connection points of the links relative to the bounding box of the nodes (see and ).
By setting a link connection box interface, the links can be connected relative to a different box (see ). It is furthermore possible to "shift" the links tangentially by using the method from the interface LinkConnectionBoxInterface:
On the "top" and "bottom" sides of a node, the connection points are moved to the right if the offset is positive and to the left if the offset is negative.
On the "left" and "right" sides of a node, the connection points are moved to the bottom if the offset is positive and to the top if the offset is negative.
The details of how the link connection box is used depend on the specific layout algorithm. If the layout class supports the link connection box and link clipping, this method calculates the initial connection points with the link connection box interface and obtains the final connection points by clipping with the link clip interface.
You can call this method with a argument to restore the default behavior.
An exception is thrown if the layout does not support this mechanism.
member.value: The link connection box interface for the connection points of links.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout.LinkClipping
member.summary: Gets or sets whether links should be clipped at the shape of the end nodes.
member.value: Whether links should be clipped at the shape of the end nodes.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.DefaultLinkConnectionBoxProvider
member.summary:
A default implementation of that uses the extended properties defined by the
and methods.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ILinkConnectionBoxProvider
member.summary: An interface used to customize the computation of the connection points of the links.
member.remarks:
An interface used to customize the computation of the connection points of the links.
This interface is useful when a layout algorithm that supports this customization must place the connection points of the links at a certain distance inside or outside the bounding box of the nodes. This interface also allows a tangential "translation" of the connection points separately for each side of each node.

example.para: In the following code, the connection points are at a distance of 10 outside the bounding box of the nodes. Therefore, the method computes the bounding box of the node and expands it with a value of 10 in all four directions.
example.code: Public Function GetBox(ByVal graphModel As IGraphModel, ByVal node As Object) As Rectangle2D Dim bbox As Rectangle2D = graphModel.BoundingBox(node) bbox.X -= 10 bbox.Y -= 10 bbox.Width += 20 bbox.Height += 20 Return bbox End Function

example.para: In the following code, the connection points on the left and right side of the nodes are shifted to the top by a fixed amount of 10. (Of course, this amount could be variable dependent on specific conditions, for example, the height of a label below a node)
example.code: Public Function GetTangentialOffset(ByVal graphModel As IGraphModel, ByVal node As Object, ByVal nodeSide As NodeSide) As Single Select nodeSide Case NodeSide.Left Return -10 Case NodeSide.Right Return -10 Case Else Return 0 End Select End Function

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.INodeBoxProvider
member.summary: An interface used to define a rectangle associated with a node of a graph.
member.remarks:
An interface used to define a rectangle associated with a node of a graph.
This interface is useful when a layout algorithm must use a node size that is different from the bounding box (see ).

example.para: The following code is an example of the implementation of the method . In this example, the height of the node box is never smaller than a predefined value (80). The additional height is added to the bottom of the original bounding box.
example.code: Public Function GetBox(ByVal graphModel As IGraphModel, _ ByVal node As Object) As Rectangle2D Dim bbox As Rectangle2D = graphModel.BoundingBox(node) If bbox.Height < 80 Then bbox.Height = 80 End If Return bbox End Function

example.para: In the following code example, the additional height is added to the top of the original bounding box.
example.code: Public Function GetBox(ByVal graphModel As IGraphModel, ByVal node As Object) As Rectangle2D Dim bbox As Rectangle2D = graphModel.BoundingBox(node) If bbox.Height < 80 Then bbox.Y = bbox.Y + bbox.Height - 80 bbox.Height = 80 End If Return bbox End Function

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.INodeBoxProvider.GetBox(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel,System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the rectangle associated to .
member.remarks:
Returns the rectangle associated to . The rectangle must be in the actual coordinate system of the input node.
Note that when routing intergraph links, the coordinate system of the node is not necessarily the same as the coordinate system of the link. If the input graph model is a grapher adapter (instance of GraphicContainerAdapter), the returned rectangle value should depend on the actual coordinate mode that can be queried from the input model by .
member.param: The graph model to which the node belongs
member.returns: The rectangle which defines the size of the node

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ILinkConnectionBoxProvider.GetTangentialOffset(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel,System.Object,ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.NodeSide)
member.summary: Returns the tangential offset for the connection points of a link on a given side of a node.
member.remarks:
Returns the tangential offset for the connection points of a link on a given side of a node. The offset must be in the actual coordinate system of the input node.
By default, some layout algorithms place the links connected to a given side of a node symmetrically with respect to the middle of the side. Using this method, it is possible to "shift" the links tangentially as follows:
On the "top" side of a node, the connection points are translated to the right if the offset is positive and to the left if the offset is negative.
On the "bottom" side of a node, the connection points are translated to the right if the offset is positive and to the left if the offset is negative.
On the "left" side of a node, the connection points are translated to the bottom if the offset is positive and to the top if the offset is negative.
On the "right" side of a node, the connection points are translated to the bottom if the offset is positive and to the top if the offset is negative.
This method must return 0 if no offset is necessary on a certain node and/or side.
Note that when routing intergraph links, the coordinate system of the node is not necessarily the same as the coordinate system of the link. If the input graph model is a grapher adapter (instance of GraphicContainerAdapter), the returned offset value should depend on the actual coordinate mode that can be queried from the input model by .
member.param: The graph model to which the node belongs.
The side of the node. The values are defined in the enumeration .

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.SubDiagram
member.summary: A graphic container with a title that can be collapsed/expanded and scrolled.
member.remarks:
The class is a graphic container that provides the following features:
Expand/collapse:
The sub-diagram can appear as an embedded diagram, or as a single collapsed object.
Scrolling:
The content of the expanded sub-diagram can extend outside of the sub-diagram bounds, and can be scrolled using built-in scrollbars.
Title bar:
In expanded state, the sub-diagram has an optional title bar that displays a title text and can be placed on either side of the sub-diagram.
Customizable icons:
The icons displayed in expanded and collapsed state can be customized (bitmaps, SVG or IVN files can be used). The expand and collapsed buttons can be changed too.
Graph layout:
Graph layout algorithms can be applied to the contents of the sub-diagram.

example.para: The following example creates a simple sub-diagram containing two rectangles:
example.code: Function CreateSubDiagram() As SubDiagram Dim subDiagram As SubDiagram = New SubDiagram subDiagram.TitleText = "Sub-Diagram (Expanded)" subDiagram.CollapsedText = "Sub-Diagram (Collapsed)" subDiagram.SubDiagramObjects.Add(New Rect(10, 10, 20, 20)) subDiagram.SubDiagramObjects.Add(New Rect(200, 100, 20, 20)) Return subDiagram End Function

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.UserSymbol
member.summary: Provides the base class for designing user defined symbols.
member.remarks: The gives you the ability to create graphic objects that can be used in multiple places within an application or organization. You can define the graphical representation of the symbol by combining graphic objects or other in a subclass of . You can also include all the code needed for defining the logic and the user inputs necessary for the symbol. The easiest way to create a new is to use the Visual Studio Designer provided by Diagram for .NET.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.UserSymbol.ChildResizeMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the resize mode for the children of this object.
member.value: One of the values. The default value is .
member.remarks: When the geometry bounds of the user symbol are changed, the user symbol has two way of applying the new size to its children, depending on the value of the property. If this property is , the user symbol will apply an affine transformation to its children. If this property is , the user symbol will resize its children.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.SubDiagramIcon
member.summary: Defines a button or an icon of a object.

remarks.para: The class is used to customize the icons and buttons of a . The properties that contain objects are , , and .
The image of a is defined by the property and can be either a bitmap image or a vector image (SVG or IVN).

example.para: The following example sets the collapsed icon of a sub-diagram to an image defined in an SVG file:
example.code: Function SetCollapsedIcon(ByVal subDiagram As SubDiagram) Dim icon As SubDiagramIcon = New SubDiagramIcon() Icon.Image = "file://" + System.IO.Path.GetFullPath("icon.svg") Icon.Size = New Size2D(50, 50) subDiagram.CollapsedIcon = Icon subDiagram.CollapsedText = "" Return 0 End Function

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Anchor
member.summary: Represents a connection point between a graphic object and a link (instance of ).
member.remarks: An anchor defines a connection point and holds a collection of objects that are connected to it. This class is , you must override the and methods. The base class caches the connection point according to the owner-to-parent transform, and the reference point (if returns ), so subclasses do not need to implement their own caching mechanism.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.Anchor.FindAnchor(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphicObject,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Finds an anchor by its name in a specified object.
member.remarks: If the parameter is , the anchor is looked for recursively in sub-containers of this object. Otherwise, the anchor is looked for only in the anchors of this object.
member.param: The name of the anchor to search.
Specifies if the search must be done recursively in the sub-objects of this objects.
member.returns: The first anchor in the specified object (or in one of its descendants) whose name is equal to .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.Anchor.GetRelativePoint(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphicContainer,ILOG.Diagrammer.Point2D,ILOG.Diagrammer.Point2D@,ILOG.Diagrammer.Point2D@)
member.summary: Gets the connection and origin points in the coordinate system of the specified parent.

remarks.para: The parameter is ignored if returns . Otherwise, the parameter must be in the local coordinate system of the container.

This method first checks if the previously cached connection and origin points are valid. If so, they are returned immediately. Otherwise, the method calls and applies the appropriate transforms so that the returned points and are in the parent's coordinate system.

member.param: An ancestor of the object. The connection and origin points will returned in the coordinate system of this container.
The reference point used to compute the anchor points. Typically, the reference point is the "other end" of the link.
The method must set this parameter to the connection point. When an is connected to this anchor, the start or end point of the connected to this anchor will be set to the connection point.

The method must set this parameter to the origin point. The origin point is typically the center of the object. When an is connected to this anchor, the origin point may be used, for example, to determine whether the link starts with a horizontal or a vertical segment.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.Anchor.GetRelativePoint(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphicContainer,ILOG.Diagrammer.Point2D)
member.summary: Gets the connection point in the coordinate system of the specified parent.

remarks.para: If you need to get the origin point as well as the connection point, use the other overload.
The parameter is ignored if returns . Otherwise, the parameter must be in the local coordinate system of the container.

This method first checks if the previously cached connection and origin points are valid. If so, they are returned immediately. Otherwise, the method calls and applies the appropriate transforms so that the returned point is in the parent's coordinate system.

member.param: An ancestor of the object. The connection and origin points will returned in the coordinate system of this container.
The reference point used to compute the anchor points. Typically, the reference point is the "other end" of the link.
member.returns: The method must return the connection point. When an is connected to this anchor, the start or end point of the connected to this anchor will be set to the connection point.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.Anchor.GetPoint(ILOG.Diagrammer.Point2D,ILOG.Diagrammer.Point2D@,ILOG.Diagrammer.Point2D@)
member.summary: Returns the connection and points in the object's local coordinate system.

remarks.para: The parameter may be an empty point if returns . Otherwise, the parameter is in the local coordinate system of the of this .
This method must return the points and in the local coordinate system of the of this .

member.param: The reference point used to compute the anchor points. Typically, the reference point is the "other end" of the link.
The method must set this parameter to the connection point. When an is connected to this anchor, the start or end point of the connected to this anchor will be set to the connection point.

The method must set this parameter to the origin point. The origin point is typically the center of the object. When an is connected to this anchor, the origin point may be used, for example, to determine whether the link starts with a horizontal or a vertical segment.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.Anchor.GetRelativeConnectionBounds(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphicContainer)
member.summary: Returns the connection bounds of the owner of this anchor, in the local coordinate system of the owner object.
member.returns: A structure.
member.remarks: The connection bounds may be used to compute the shape of the links so that they avoid crossing the owner's bounding region. This method calls and transforms the resulting rectangle into the specified parent's coordinate system.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.ShapeAnchor
member.summary: Represents a floating connection point on the outline of a object.

remarks.para: The connection point defined by this anchor class is the intersection of the outline of the graphic object object with a line starting at the reference point and ending at the center of the graphic object bounds, translated using the property. The property can be used to set a distance between the connection point and the graphic object outline.
Although this class will work with any shape, it is best suited for closed shapes.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.ShapeAnchor.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

members.member: Overrides Anchor.GetPoint. is set to the intersection of the outline of the object with a line starting at the and ending at the center point. The center point is the center of the , modified by the property. is set to the center point. . The reference point used to compute the connection point. The resulting connection point. The resulting center point.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.ShapeAnchor.NeedsReferencePoint
member.summary: Returns because this anchor class uses the reference point to compute the connection point.

member.summary: Returns a short description of this anchor.

member.summary: This member overrides Anchor.IsSame.

member.summary: This member overrides Anchor.ValidFor.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.ShapeAnchor.Distance
member.summary: Gets or sets the distance between the shape of the graphic object and the connection point.
member.value: A value in pixels. The default value is 0.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.ShapeAnchor.CenterOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the offset of the center point.
member.value: A structure. The default value is the (0, 0) point.

remarks.para: The X and Y coordinates of the offset are floating-point values between -1 and 1, and define a relative position within the bounds of the owner object. For example, an offset equal to (0.25, 0) means that the center point is half-way between the center of the shape and its right side.

The connection is computed as the intersection of the outline of the object with a line starting at the and ending at the center point. The center point is the center of the , modified by the property.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayoutReport
member.summary: The class used to store information about the behavior of the Orthogonal Long Link Layout algorithm.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutReport
member.summary: The base class of the objects used to store information about the behavior of the layout algorithms.

remarks.p: The layout report is returned by the method . It can be also obtained during the layout using the handlers for the LayoutStepPerformed event.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutReport.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the report object.
member.remarks: This is done by .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutReport.CodeToString(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutReportCode)
member.summary: Returns a message string (in English) corresponding to the code value that can be obtained by .

remarks.p: For example, the method returns the string "layout done" for the input code and the string "layout not needed" for the input code .

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutReport.LayoutTime
member.summary: Gets the total duration of the layout algorithm (in milliseconds).
member.remarks:
The starting and ending times are automatically recorded. The total duration is the sum of the duration of the methods
and .
member.value: The total duration of the layout algorithm (in milliseconds).

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutReport.PercentageComplete
member.summary: Gets the current percentage of completion during layout, if the layout algorithm supports the percentage completion feature.
member.remarks: This value is set to 0 at the beginning of layout, increases during layout, and reaches 100 at the end of layout.
member.value: The current percentage of completion during layout, if the layout algorithm supports the percentage completion feature.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutReport.Code
member.summary: Gets or sets the code describing the current state of the layout algorithm.
member.remarks:
The possible values are (, , , and so on).
The property can be queried inside an event handler that handles the event to inform the event handler about the status of layout. This method returns if it is called at the beginning of the layout process (unless the layout is not needed).
It returns if it is called at the end of the layout process (unless the layout is not needed or the graph is empty).
Whenever the code is returned, the code will also be returned, even in the cases when an exception occurs during the layout process, the layout is stopped prematurely (by , or because the layout time elapsed).
member.value: The code describing the current state of the layout algorithm.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayoutReport.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the report object.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayoutReport.GetNumberOfFallbackLinks
member.summary: Returns the number of links that could not be routed on the grid without obstacle overlaps.
member.remarks:
A link may not be routed without overlaps, if the allowed time to find a route for this single link elapsed (see ), if the route would have to bypass too many obstacles (see ), or if there is no path on the grid from the start node to the end node that bypasses all obstacles at all.
If the fallback routing option was set to by using , these links are routed by a simple fallback routing algorithm.

member.summary: Gets or sets the radius of the circle.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Circle
member.summary: Defines a graphic object that represent a circle.
member.remarks: represents a graphic object that displays a circle. The circle is defined by a center point through the property and a radius through the property.

example.para: The following sample shows how to create a circle.
example.code: Function CreateCircle() As Circle Dim circle As Circle = New Circle circle.Center = New Point2D(100, 100) circle.Radius = 80 circle.Stroke = New Stroke(Color.Black, 2, DashStyle.Dash) circle.Fill = New SolidFill(Color.Blue) Return circle End Function

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Serialization.ObjectXmlSerializer
member.summary: A class to serialize object instances.
member.remarks:
The class is a generic class that is able to serialize any kind of objects to or from an XML representation. The only requirement is that the class to serialize must define a default constructor.
This class maintains the state of the reference graph during the serialization, and recycles instances when the graph is deserialized.
The format used by the serializer follows a Class-Property-Class pattern. The class declaration is serialized first as an Xml element (provided the serialization scope allows it), then the properties of the class. Each property is serialized as an Xml element recursively by means of their corresponding serializers.
The following example illustrates the Class-Property-Class pattern, where a class A with two properties PropB and PropC of type respectively B and C would be serialized as:
... Properties of class B
... Properties of class C
Exceptions to this rule are for properties whose data type support bi-directional string conversion (object-to-string and string-to-object). For such cases, properties are serialized as of the parent element.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Windows.Forms.FilterDialog
member.summary: Defines a dialog box that allows to select a .
member.remarks: The class defines a dialog box that allows to edit a object. You specify the filter to edit through the property. You can preview the result of the filter on a specific graphic object through the property.

example.para: The following example shows how to use the dialog box.
example.code:
Function EditFilter(ByVal filter As Filter, ByVal preview As GraphicObject) As Filter
' Create the dialog Dim dialog As FilterDialog = New FilterDialog
' Specify the filter to edit
dialog.Filter = filter
' Specify the graphic object used to preview the result dialog.PreviewObject = preview
' Show the dialog If dialog.ShowDialog = DialogResult.OK Then
' returns the resulting filter Return dialog.Filter
End If
' in other case return the old filter Return filter End Function

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.Windows.Forms.SelectInteractor.CreateGhostGraphic(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphicObject)
member.summary: Is called to create the ghost graphic that will be used to render selection interactions when the view is not in selection instant editing mode.

remarks.para: when the view is not in selection instant editing mode, the modifications made on the selected objects are not instantaneous. Instead, a ghost graphic is created on which modifications will be performed. At the end of the interaction, the modifications made on the ghost graphic will be applied to the real graphic objects.
The default implemetation of this method creates of clone of with a transparency of 50%.

member.returns: A reference.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalRelativeLevelConstraint
member.summary: The class HierarchicalRelativeLevelConstraint is a constraint to place a node relative to another node.
member.remarks:
It forces a node to be placed at a level with higher index than another node. The constraint can also be applied to groups of nodes.
Nodes are organized in horizontal or vertical levels numbered from 0 to "n". If the link flow direction is from top to bottom, the nodes with level index 0 are placed in the topmost level, and the nodes with higher level indices are placed in the levels below. If the link flow direction is from left to right, the nodes with level index 0 are placed in the leftmost level, and the nodes with higher level indices are placed in the levels farther to the right.
The constraint is evaluated, if the incremental mode is disabled. If the incremental mode is enabled, the constraint is only evaluated for those nodes that are marked for incremental recalculation, because otherwise, the incremental positions of the nodes are dominant.
Among the constraints, this kind is dominated by level range constraints, that is, if the level range for node A is below the level range of node B, then A cannot be forced to be placed in a higher level than B. This kind of constraint is also dominated by the same level constraints, that is, if both nodes A and B are forced to be at the same level, then A cannot be forced to be placed in a higher level than B.
The relative constraints have priorities. Conflicting relative level constraints are resolved by removing the constraint with the smallest priority. Relative level constraints also compete with the links of the graph. Each link acts like a constraint (with the same priority as the link) that forces that the target node is placed in a higher level than the source node.
The automatic conflict resolution can handle conflicting constraints. However, to speedup the layout, it is recommended to specify constraints in a way such that there are no conflicts.

example.para: The following example shows how to use the constraint to place one node in a higher level than another node.
example.code:
Imports System Imports ILOG.Diagrammer Imports ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic Imports ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout
' node1 and node2 are part of group Dim group As Group = ... Dim node1 As GraphicObject = ... Dim node2 As GraphicObject = ...
Dim layout As HierarchicalLayout = New HierarchicalLayout group.GraphLayout = layout
layout.Constraints.Add( New HierarchicalRelativeLevelConstraint(node1, node2, 1.0f)) group.PerformGraphLayout

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalConstraint
member.summary: The abstract class HierarchicalConstraint is the base class for constraints of the Hierarchical Layout.
member.remarks: Constraints can be used to influence the way how the layout algorithms partitions the nodes into levels and orders the nodes within the levels.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalRelativeLevelConstraint.#ctor(System.Object,System.Object,System.Single)
member.summary: Creates a new HierarchicalRelativeLevelConstraint.
member.param: A node, or a group of type that is placed in levels below the second node or group.
A node, or a group of type that is placed in levels above the first node or group.

example.para: The following examples shows how to use the constraint. The first statement applies it to individual nodes and forces node2 to be placed at a level with higher index than node1. The second statement applies it to groups or nodes and forces the nodes of listOfNodes2 to be placed at a level with higher index than the nodes of listOfNodes1.
example.code: layout.Constraints.Add( new HierarchicalRelativeLevelConstraint(node1, node2, priority)); layout.Constraints.Add( new HierarchicalRelativeLevelConstraint( new HierarchicalNodeGroup(listOfNodes1), new HierarchicalNodeGroup(listOfNodes2), priority));

layout.Constraints.Add( New HierarchicalRelativeLevelConstraint(node1, node2, priority)) layout.Constraints.Add( New HierarchicalRelativeLevelConstraint( New HierarchicalNodeGroup(listOfNodes1), New HierarchicalNodeGroup(listOfNodes2), priority))

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.TextAppearance
member.summary: Regroups the properties that controls text appearance in a .
member.remarks: The object regroups the information such as font and colors for displaying text in a graphic object. Each graphic object holds a instance in its property, this instance is used to display the text specified by the property inside the graphic object. Through the text appearance object, you may for example specify the font of the text through the property or the way the text is painted through the property.

example.para: The following sample creates an ellipse with some blue text displayed inside.
example.code:
Public Function CreateEllipseWithText() As Ellipse
Dim ellipse As Ellipse = New Ellipse(520F, 160F, 140F, 120F) ellipse.Fill = New SolidFill(Color.WhiteSmoke) ellipse.Text = "Welcome to IBM ILOG Diagram for .NET"
Dim appearance As TextAppearance = New TextAppearance appearance.Font = New Font("Arial", 12F) appearance.Foreground = New SolidFill(Color.Blue) appearance.Margins = New Margins(5F) appearance.VerticalAlignment = VerticalTextAlignment.Center appearance.HorizontalAlignment = HorizontalTextAlignment.Center
ellipse.TextAppearance = appearance Return ellipse End Function

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutFlowDirection
member.summary: The flow directions for the Tree layout algorithm.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutFlowDirection.Left
member.summary: Left direction.
member.remarks: When used as an argument of , the root of the tree is on the left and the links flow to the right.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutFlowDirection.Right
member.summary: Right direction.
member.remarks: When used as an argument of , the root of the tree is on the right and the links flow to the left.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutFlowDirection.Top
member.summary: Top direction.
member.remarks: When used as an argument of , the root of the tree is at the bottom and the links flow to the top.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutFlowDirection.Bottom
member.summary: Bottom direction.
member.remarks: When used as an argument of , the root of the tree is at the top and the links flow to the bottom.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutAlignment
member.summary: The alignment options for the Tree layout algorithm.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutAlignment.Center
member.summary: Center alignment.
member.remarks: With this alignment, a parent is centered above its children, taking the center of the children into account.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutAlignment.BorderCenter
member.summary: Border center alignment.
member.remarks: With this alignment, a parent is centered above its children, taking the border of the children into account. This differs from the alignment if the respect node sizes option is enabled.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutAlignment.East
member.summary: East alignment.
member.remarks: With this alignment, a parent is aligned to the border of its easternmost child.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutAlignment.West
member.summary: West alignment.
member.remarks: With this alignment, a parent is aligned to the border of its westernmost child.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutAlignment.TipOver
member.summary: Tip over alignment.
member.remarks: With this alignment, a parent is outside the border of the children, while the children are placed sequentially instead of in parallel. This alignment option is not possible in the radial or level layout modes.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutAlignment.TipOverBothSides
member.summary: Tip over both sides alignment.
member.remarks: With this alignment, the alignment is similar to , but the children are arranged in pairs at both sides of the link segment that starts at the parent node. This alignment option is not possible in the radial or level layout modes.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutAlignment.Mixed
member.summary: Mixed alignment.
member.remarks: With this alignment, each node can have a different alignment option. The alignment of each individual node can be set by the method so that different alignments can occur in the same graph.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutLevelAlignment
member.summary: The level alignment options for the Tree layout algorithm.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutLevelAlignment.Center
member.summary: Center alignment.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutLevelAlignment.North
member.summary: North alignment.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutLevelAlignment.South
member.summary: South alignment.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutConnectorStyle
member.summary: The connector style options for the Tree layout algorithm.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutConnectorStyle.Automatic
member.summary: Automatic pins connector style.
member.remarks: When set as value of , the connector style is selected depending on the link style.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutConnectorStyle.Centered
member.summary: Centered connector style.
member.remarks: When set as value of , the link connector pins are placed in the center of the border of the node bounding box to which the link is attached.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutConnectorStyle.Clipped
member.summary: Clipped connector style.
member.remarks: When set as value of , each link pointing to the center of the node is clipped at the bounding box of the node. This style affects straight links; it behaves like centered connector pins for orthogonal links.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutConnectorStyle.EvenlySpaced
member.summary: Evenly spaced connector style.
member.remarks: When set as value of , the link connector pins are evenly spaced along the border of the node bounding box.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutLinkStyle
member.summary: The link style options for the Tree layout algorithm.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutLinkStyle.Orthogonal
member.summary: Orthogonal link style.
member.remarks: With this link style, the link has an orthogonal shape, that is, a shape consisting of a sequence of orthogonal line segments. This option is not available for the radial layout modes.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutLinkStyle.Straight
member.summary: Straight line link style.
member.remarks: With this link style, the link has a straight-line shape.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutLinkStyle.Mixed
member.summary: Mixed link style.
member.remarks:
With this link style, each link can have a different link style. The style of each individual link can be set by the method
so that different link shapes can occur in the same graph.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutLinkStyle.NoReshape
member.summary: No reshape link style.
member.remarks: With this link style, no reshape is performed on the links.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutMode
member.summary: The layout modes for the Tree layout algorithm.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutMode.TipOver
member.summary: Tip over layout mode.
member.remarks: When used as an argument of , all links flow roughly in the flow direction. In this layout mode, the algorithm tries to optimize the layout to automatically fit best to the specified aspect ratio by calculating which individual nodes need tip-over alignment and which nodes can use the specified alignment. The layout algorithm uses a fast heuristic.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutMode.TipLeavesOver
member.summary: Tip leaves over layout mode.
member.remarks: When used as an argument of , all links flow roughly in the flow direction. The algorithm tries to optimize the layout to automatically fit best to the specified aspect ratio. This slow heuristic tries to tip over beginning with the leaves and then chooses the best layout. It checks the alignment mode , but not . It keeps the alignment of all nodes close to the root as specified.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutMode.TipRootsOver
member.summary: Tip over layout mode.
member.remarks: When used as an argument of , all links flow roughly in the flow direction. The algorithm tries to optimize the layout to automatically fit best to the specified aspect ratio. This slow heuristic tries to tip over beginning with the roots and then chooses the best layout. It checks the alignment mode , but not . It keeps the alignment of all nodes close to the leaves as specified.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutMode.TipRootsAndLeavesOver
member.summary: Tip roots and leaves over layout mode.
member.remarks: When used as an argument of , all links flow roughly in the flow direction. The algorithm tries to optimize the layout to automatically fit best to the specified aspect ratio. This slow heuristic tries to tip over beginning with the roots and with the leaves, and then chooses the best layout. It checks the alignment mode , but not . It keeps the alignment of all nodes in the middle between roots and leaves as specified.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutMode.Free
member.summary: Free layout mode.
member.remarks: When used as an argument of , all links flow roughly in the flow direction. Nodes of different tree branches (that is, nodes with a different parent node) are not justified to each other; therefore, the level alignment parameter is ignored. Tip-over alignment is possible if specified as alignment. All link styles are possible. The aspect ratio is ignored.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutMode.Level
member.summary: Level layout mode.
member.remarks: When used as an argument of , all links flow roughly in the flow direction. Nodes are organized in levels and are justified to their borders or centered according to the level alignment parameter. Tip-over alignment is not possible, but all link styles are possible. The aspect ratio is ignored.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutMode.Radial
member.summary: Radial layout mode.
member.remarks: When used as an argument of , the root node is in the center, the links flow radially away from the center, and the nodes are placed in circular layers around the root node according to the level alignment. Tip-over alignment and orthogonal link styles are not possible. Clipped connector pins are used as the connector style. If an aspect ratio is specified, the layers are ellipses around the center.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutMode.AlternatingRadial
member.summary: Alternating radial layout mode.
member.remarks: When used as an argument of , this is the same as mode , with the exception that children of the same node are placed alternating in different circular layers when this results in a smaller radius and better usage of the space. Tip-over alignment and orthogonal link styles are not possible. Clipped connector pins are used as the connector style. If an aspect ratio is specified, the layers are ellipses around the center.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalRelativePositionConstraint
member.summary: The class HierarchicalRelativePositionConstraint is a constraint to place a node relative to another node that belongs to the same level.
member.remarks:
It does not affect the order of nodes that belong to different levels. It forces a node to be placed after another node within the same level. The constraint can also be applied to groups of nodes.
Nodes are organized in horizontal or vertical levels. Within each level, the nodes are placed sequentially at relative positions numbered from 0 to "n". If the link flow direction is from top to bottom, the node with position index 0 is placed leftmost within its level, and the nodes with higher position indices are placed farther to the right. If the link flow direction is from right to left, the node with position index 0 is placed topmost within its level, and the nodes with higher position indices are placed below. The constraint specifies that a node is placed at a higher position index than another node. The constraint is ignored, if both nodes do not belong to the same level.
The constraint is evaluated, if the incremental mode is disabled. If the incremental mode is enabled, the constraint is only evaluated for those nodes that are marked for incremental recalculation, because otherwise, the incremental positions of the nodes are dominant.
Among the constraints, this kind is dominated by side by side constraints, that is, if a node A and B must be placed side by side, then a node C cannot be forced to be at a higher position than A but at a lower position than B at the same time. The node C cannot be forced to be placed in between A and B. The constraint is also dominated by specified position indices, i.e. it does not change the order of nodes that have specified position indices, and by swim lane constraints, that is, it is not able to break swim lanes apart.
The relative constraints have priorities. Conflicting relative position constraints are resolved by removing the constraint with the smallest priority.
The automatic conflict resolution can handle conflicting constraints. However, to speed up the layout, it is recommended to specify constraints in a way such that there are no conflicts.

example.para: The following example shows how to use the constraint to specify the order of two nodes that belong to the same level.
example.code:
Imports System Imports ILOG.Diagrammer Imports ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic Imports ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout
' node1 and node2 are part of group Dim group As Group = ... Dim node1 As GraphicObject = ... Dim node2 As GraphicObject = ...
Dim layout As HierarchicalLayout = New HierarchicalLayout group.GraphLayout = layout
' node1 and node2 must be on the same level layout.SetSpecNodeLevelIndex(node1, 2) layout.SetSpecNodeLevelIndex(node2, 2)
layout.Constraints.Add( New HierarchicalRelativePositionConstraint(node1, node2, 1.0f)) group.PerformGraphLayout

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalRelativePositionConstraint.#ctor(System.Object,System.Object,System.Single)
member.summary: Creates a new HierarchicalRelativePositionConstraint.
member.param: A node, or a group of type that is placed at lower positions than the second node or group.
A node, or a group of type that is placed at higher positions than the first node or group.

example.para: The following examples shows how to use the constraint. The first statement applies it to individual nodes. If node1 and node2 are placed at the same level, then this forces node2 to be placed at a higher position index than node1. If the flow direction is top down, this means that node2 is placed to the right of node1. The second statement applies it to groups or nodes. This forces the nodes of listOfNodes2 to be placed at a higher position index than the nodes of listOfNodes1 that belong to the same level.
example.code: layout.Constraints.Add( new HierarchicalRelativePositionConstraint(node1, node2, priority)); layout.Constraints.Add( new HierarchicalRelativePositionConstraint( new HierarchicalNodeGroup(listOfNodes1), new HierarchicalNodeGroup(listOfNodes2), priority));

layout.Constraints.Add( New HierarchicalRelativePositionConstraint(node1, node2, priority)) layout.Constraints.Add( New HierarchicalRelativePositionConstraint( New HierarchicalNodeGroup(listOfNodes1), New HierarchicalNodeGroup(listOfNodes2), priority))

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ForceDirectedLayout
member.summary: The main class for the Force-Directed Layout algorithm.

remarks.p: The Force-Directed Layout algorithm can be used to lay out any type of graph. It often provides a drawing with no, or only a few, edge crossings and with approximately equal-length edges for small- and medium-size graphs having a small number of cycles.
This layout algorithm iteratively searches for a configuration of the graph such that the lengths of the edges are close to a desired value.
Here are sample drawings produced with the Force-Directed Layout algorithm:

Several parameters have an impact on speed. In some extent, the performance can be improved by modifying these parameters.
Parameters that allow to reduce the number of iterations that are executed:
. The algorithm stops iterating when the length of all links is close to the specified "preferredLinksLength" parameter. If the preferred length is very high while the initial length of the links is small, reducing the preferred length is an indirect way to reduce the necessary number of iterations, hence to speed up.
. Reducing the allowed time is a way to force the completion of the layout quicker. However, the quality gets of course worst.
. Similar as for .
Parameters that allow to reduce the time spent at each iteration:
. If disabled, the algorithm is a bit quicker because it does not try to avoid overlaps between nodes. This is in particular possible, without quality degradation, when all the nodes have approximately the same size and have more or less a square shape. In such cases, specifying a "preferredLinksLength" high enough usually avoids overlaps even if "respectNodeSizes" is not enabled.
. This indicates the maximum distance the algorithm is allowed to move a node at each iteration. The higher the value, quicker the optimum may be reached, but also the algorithm may fail to converge (no "crash", just that the quality may be worst).

See the corresponding chapter of the IBM ILOG Diagram for .NET Graph Layout User's Manual for details on the algorithm, the types of graphs for which this algorithm can be used, the features and limitations, code samples, parameters, and so on.
You can specify a preferred length for the links globally ( or for specific links ().

You can request that the real size of the nodes is taken into account (). This is especially recommended when the nodes are not square (have a larger or smaller width than height), or have different sizes. In such a case, the layout quality can be often further improved by increasing the weight of the node repulsion force (see ; the default is zero).
While the layout algorithm optionally restricts the region where the nodes are placed (see ), the layout quality is usually much better if this option is not used (this is the default behavior).

If this option is not set, the nodes are considered to be points located in the center of the bounding box of the nodes. Using the layout algorithm without setting this option is recommended when the width of the nodes is close to their height and there are no significant size differences among the nodes.
Note that the initial position of the nodes (at the moment you start the layout) is taken into account by the layout algorithm, so you may get different results depending on the initial position.

example.para: The following example shows how to apply the Force-Directed Layout.
example.code:
Imports System Imports ILOG.Diagrammer Imports ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic Imports ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout
Dim group As Group = New Group
' Fill the group with nodes and links here
Dim layout As ForceDirectedLayout = New ForceDirectedLayout group.GraphLayout = layout group.PerformGraphLayout

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ForceDirectedLayout.Copy
member.summary: Copies the layout instance.

remarks.p: This method copies the layout instance by calling the copy constructor.
When performing a recursive layout of a nested graph, this method is used by to "clone" the layout instance of a parent graph.

Note that the parameters which are specific to a node or a link are not copied. The other parameters, including the layout region specification and the customization interfaces, are also copied. A copy of the layout instance used for laying out the connected components is set on the new instance.
If a method of the type SupportsXXX is associated with a parameter, the parameter is copied only if the corresponding method returns .

member.returns: A copy of the layout instance.
