member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ForceDirectedLayout.SupportsLinkConnectionBox
member.summary: Indicates that this layout class can use a link connection box interface to calculate the end points of a link.
member.remarks:
The link connection box interface is an object that provides the rectangle to which the links are connected for each node and the tangential shift offset at each side for the connection points.
The connection box interface is used only if link clipping is enabled by setting a link clip interface, and if the link style is straight line. In this case, the layout algorithm calculates the virtual center of the end nodes of each link by the link connection box interface and obtains the final connection points by clipping with the link clip interface. The virtual center is defined as the center of the connection box shifted by the average of the tangential "top" and "bottom" offsets in the horizontal direction, and by the average of the tangential "left" and "right" offsets in the vertical direction. For instance, if the tangential offset is 20 at the top side and 10 at all other sides, the average shift offset is (20 + 10)/2 = 15 in the horizontal direction and (10 + 10)/2 = 10 in the vertical direction; hence, the virtual center is at connectionBox.center() + (15, 10).
If no link clipping is performed, the layout algorithms does not actively place the end points of links. It relies on the link connectors that are attached to the nodes to find appropriate connection points for the links.
member.returns: Always .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ForceDirectedLayout.Layout
member.summary: Computes the layout using the Force-Directed Layout algorithm.
member.remarks: To start the layout, call the method . Note that this class overrides the and creates an instance of .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ForceDirectedLayout.SetPreferredLength(System.Object,System.Single)
member.summary: Sets the preferred length of a link.
member.remarks:
The layout algorithm tries to compute a layout where the link has the specified length. If a preferred length is set for a link, this overrides the global preferred length for this link.
After having specified a length for a link, you can call the method with a strictly negative value to indicate that the global preferred length must be used again for this link.
By default, no length is specified for the individual links.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ForceDirectedLayout.GetPreferredLength(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the preferred length of a link.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ForceDirectedLayout.ConvergenceThreshold
member.summary: Gets or sets the threshold value for the convergence detection mechanism.
member.remarks:
The iterative algorithm is stopped if the greatest movement of a node at an iteration is smaller than during several successive iterations.
The default value is 1. The units are in the same coordinate space as the coordinates and size of the nodes. Increasing this value may speed up the layout because the iterations may be stopped earlier. However, this may produce a nonoptimal layout. Decreasing this value in some cases improves the quality of the layout but needs more time because more iterations are performed. Note that if the specified value is too small, the iterations cannot be stopped until the allowed time or the allowed number of iterations is reached.
member.value: The threshold value for the convergence detection mechanism.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ForceDirectedLayout.MaxAllowedMovePerIteration
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum authorized node move at each iteration of the layout algorithm.
member.remarks:
The default value is 5.
Increasing this parameter may speed up the layout, but the algorithm may fail to converge. Decreasing this parameter slows down the layout but in some cases improves the convergence. You should not specify a zero value, because in this case the layout cannot move the nodes at all.
member.value: The maximum authorized node move at each iteration of the layout algorithm.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ForceDirectedLayout.ForceFitToLayoutRegion
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the layout algorithm must force the graph drawing to fit the layout region.
member.remarks: If the argument is (which is the default), the layout algorithm is free to move nodes outside the layout region. Note that the layout may not be optimal if the size of the layout region is too small. It is recommended to avoid forcing the use of a layout region anytime this is possible.
member.value: Whether the layout algorithm must force the graph drawing to fit the layout region.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ForceDirectedLayout.PreferredLinksLength
member.summary: Gets or sets the global preferred length of the links.
member.remarks:
The layout algorithm tries to compute a layout where the links have the specified length. The preferred length can also be specified individually for each link (or for some links). If an individual length is not specified for a particular link, the global length specified by this property is used for this link.
The default value is 60.
member.value: The global preferred length of the links.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ForceDirectedLayout.NodeDistanceThreshold
member.summary: Gets or sets the node distance threshold.
member.remarks:
The additional repulsion force (see ) is applied only for nodes that are not connected by a link and are at a distance smaller than this threshold.
The default value is 30.
Note that the additional repulsion force is applied only if the corresponding weight (see ) is larger than 0. The default weight is 0; therefore, the node distance threshold has no effect if the weight is not modified.
member.value: The node distance threshold.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ForceDirectedLayout.RespectNodeSizes
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the algorithm must try to respect the size of the nodes.
member.remarks: If the argument is , the preferred length parameter is interpreted as a minimum distance between the bounding boxes of the end nodes. Otherwise, the preferred length parameter is considered as the center-to-center distance between the end nodes.
member.value: Whether the algorithm must try to respect the size of the nodes.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ForceDirectedLayout.LinkLengthWeight
member.summary: Gets or sets the link length weight.
member.remarks: This weight is a multiplier that is applied when two nodes connected by a link are moved in order to obtain a link length close to the preferred value (see and ). The default value is 1. Increasing (or decreasing) this value increases (or decreases) the priority that is given to the link length criteria with respect to the minimum distance between nodes not connected by a link.
member.value: The link length weight.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ForceDirectedLayout.AdditionalNodeRepulsionWeight
member.summary: Gets or sets the weight of the additional node repulsion force.
member.remarks:
This weight is a multiplier which is applied to the repulsion force between two nodes that are not connected by a link. The additional repulsion force is applied only if the distance between the nodes is smaller than the node distance threshold (see ).
The default value is 0.2. Increasing the weight increases the priority that is given to maintaining the nodes at a distance larger than the node distance threshold. On the other side, increasing the weight decreases the ability of the algorithm to reach convergence quickly.
member.value: The weight of the additional node repulsion force.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ForceDirectedLayout.AllowedNumberOfIterations
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of iterations of the layout algorithm.
member.remarks: The default value is 1000.
member.value: The maximum number of iterations of the layout algorithm.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ForceDirectedLayout.LinkStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the style of the shape of the links.
member.remarks:
Valid values are (the links are given a straight-line shape) and (no reshape is performed on the links).
This feature can be useful if the graph contains links that have intermediate points and are not straight-line links, for instance, links with shape type with intermediate points.
The default value is .
member.value: The style of the shape of the links.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether the layout avoids movement of fixed nodes.
member.remarks: See for details.
member.value: Whether the layout avoids movement of fixed nodes.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ForceDirectedLayout.AllowedTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the upper limit for the duration of the layout algorithm.
member.remarks: See for details.
member.value: The upper limit for the duration of the layout algorithm.

member.summary: Draws the specified graphic object.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Group
member.summary: Groups elements in a group.
member.remarks: A allows to group graphic objects together. A does not have any graphical representation and the size of the group is automatically computed from the size of its children. Use the property to add objects in a group.

example.para: The following example adds a triangle and a rectangle in a group.
example.code:
Function CreateGroup() As Group Dim group As Group = New Group Dim triangle As Basic2DShape = New Basic2DShape(0F, 0F, 80F, 70F) triangle.ShapeType = Basic2DShapeType.Triangle triangle.ControlValue = 0.5F triangle.Fill = New SolidFill(Color.Blue)
Dim rectangle As Rect = New Rect(0F, 50F, 130F, 40F) rectangle.Fill = New SolidFill(Color.Gray) rectangle.Stroke = New Stroke(Color.Red)
group.Objects.AddRange(New GraphicObject() {rectangle, triangle}) Return group End Function

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeTurbulence
member.summary: This filter effect creates an image using the Perlin turbulence function.
member.remarks: This filter effect creates an image using the Perlin turbulence function. It allows the synthesis of artificial textures like clouds or marble. For a detailed description of the Perlin turbulence function, see "Texturing and Modeling", Ebert et al, AP Professional, 1994.

member.summary: Initializes a new object.

member.summary: Initializes a new from serialization information.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeTurbulence.Setup_seed(System.Int32)
member.summary: Produces results in the range [1, 2**31 - 2]. Algorithm is: r = (a * r) mod m where a = 16807 and m = 2**31 - 1 = 2147483647 See [Park Miller], CACM vol. 31 no. 10 p. 1195, Oct. 1988 To test: the algorithm should produce the result 1043618065 as the 10,000th generated number if the original seed is 1.

member.value: One of the values. The default value is .

member.summary: Represents a common dialog box that displays a preview of a .
member.remarks: Use the property to get or set the document to preview.

example.para: The following sample shows how to preview a .
example.code: Dim container As Group = New Group Dim ellipse As Ellipse = New Ellipse(0, 0, 100, 100) container.Objects.Add(ellipse) Dim document As DiagramPrintDocument = New DiagramPrintDocument(container) Dim dialog As DiagramPrintPreviewDialog = New DiagramPrintPreviewDialog dialog.Document = document dialog.ShowDialog()

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayoutLevelJustification
member.summary: The justification options of nodes within the levels of a hierarchical layout.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayoutLevelJustification.Top
member.summary: Nodes are justified at their top border.
member.remarks: This option can be specified when the flow direction is to the top or to the bottom.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayoutLevelJustification.Bottom
member.summary: Nodes are justified at their bottom border.
member.remarks: This option can be specified when the flow direction is to the top or to the bottom.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayoutLevelJustification.Left
member.summary: Nodes are justified at their left border.
member.remarks: This option can be specified when the flow direction is to the left or to the right.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayoutLevelJustification.Right
member.summary: Nodes are justified at their right border.
member.remarks: This option can be specified when the flow direction is to the left or to the right.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayoutLevelJustification.Center
member.summary: Nodes are justified at their center.
member.remarks: This option can be specified with all flow directions.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayoutMovementMode
member.summary: The modes how nodes can be moved by the Hierarchical layout algorithm.
member.remarks:
Node movement modes only have an effect if the incremental mode is switched on. In incremental mode, the layout is able to restrict the movement of nodes in x direction or in y direction.
Node movement modes can be specified globally for all nodes by , or locally for individual nodes by . If you want to specify the mode for individual nodes, you need to set the global mode to .

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayoutMovementMode.Free
member.summary: Free movement mode.
member.remarks:
When used as an argument of , the incremental layout is free to move the nodes. Depending on the various parameters of the incremental mode, the layout shifts the nodes to optimize the space usage, but the shifting does not change the relative order of the nodes and links, so that the diagram after an incremental layout looks very similar to the previous diagram.
To specify the mode of an individual node, use this mode as the argument of the method .

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayoutMovementMode.Fixed
member.summary: Fixed movement mode.
member.remarks:
When used as an argument of , the incremental layout keeps all nodes fixed. Only nodes that are marked for incremental repositioning will be moved, and links are rerouted.
To specify the mode of an individual node, use this mode as the argument of the method .

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayoutMovementMode.FixedInX
member.summary: Fixed movement mode for the x direction.
member.remarks:
When used as an argument of , the incremental layout is free to move the nodes in the y direction but keeps the nodes fixed in the x direction.
To specify the mode of an individual node, use this mode as the argument of the method .

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayoutMovementMode.FixedInY
member.summary: Fixed movement mode for the y direction.
member.remarks:
When used as an argument of , the incremental layout is free to move the nodes in the x direction but keeps the nodes fixed in the y direction.
To specify the mode of an individual node, use this mode as the argument of the method .

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayoutMovementMode.Mixed
member.summary: Mixed movement mode.
member.remarks: When is used as the argument of , each node can have a different movement mode during incremental layout. The mode for an individual node can be set by the method .

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Animations.TimerAnimation
member.summary: An animation that behaves like a timer.
member.remarks: The is an infinite animation that triggers an event at regular intervals. Use property to specify the period at which the animation will trigger the event.

example.para: The following sample creates a TimerAnimation.
example.code:
Dim timer As TimerAnimation = New TimerAnimation(TimeSpan.FromSeconds(0.1!)) AddHandler timer.Tick, AddressOf Me.TimerTick timer.Start()
Private Sub TimerTick(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal args As EventArgs) ... End Sub

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Animation
member.summary: The base class for animations.

remarks.p: An animation is the representation of a change that occurs over time.
To control the animation execution, use the , , or methods.
After the animation has been started, the animation engine will call the method to perform the animation.

member.summary: An animation that has a known duration.

remarks.p: A BoundedAnimation has its duration defined by the property. The property indicates whether the animation plays in reverse after it completes a forward iteration. The property allows to repeat the animation.
The is called to play the animation.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.Animations.BoundedAnimation.Rewind
member.summary: Is called to rewind the animation.
member.remarks: This method is called at the end of an animation if the property is set to . It is also called if the animation is stopped by calling .

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Animations.BoundedAnimation.InterpolationPoint
member.summary: Gets or sets the interpolation point for this animation.
member.value: A structure.
member.remarks: The interpolation point determines how the completion of the animation will evolve during time. The X value of the point represents the time axis, and the Y value the animation completion. Both values must be in the range ]0..1[. The interpolation of the animation completion is done so that at X percent of the duration, the animation completion should be Y. The default value for this property is the point 0.5, 0.5, which corresponds to a linear interpolation over time.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Animations.BoundedAnimation.Duration
member.summary: Gets or sets the duration for this animation.
member.value: A structure.
member.exception: if the duration is negative or null.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Animations.BoundedAnimation.RepeatCount
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of repetition of this animation.
member.value: An that represents the number of times the animation will be run before ending. A negative value can be used to specify that the animation will never end. The default value is 0.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Animations.BoundedAnimation.AutoReverse
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the animation plays in reverse after it completes a forward iteration.
member.value: if the animation plays in reverse at the end of each iteration; otherwise, . The default value is .

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Animations.BoundedAnimation.HoldEnd
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the animation should go back to the state before playing the animation.
member.value: if the animation should go back to the state before playing the animation; otherwise, . The default value is .

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Animations.IntAnimation
member.summary: An animation that animates a property of type .

member.summary: An animation that animates a property of type .

example.para: The following sample creates a ColorAnimation that animates the Color property of a object from Yellow to Red, then from Red to Yellow. The animation plays indefinitely.
example.code: Dim obj As Rect = New Rect(0, 0, 100, 100) obj.Fill = new SolidFill() Dim animation As ColorAnimation = New ColorAnimation(obj.Fill, "Color", Color.Yellow, Color.Red, TimeSpan.FromSeconds(1!)) animation.AutoReverse = true animation.RepeatCount = -1 animation.Start()

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Animations.SetAnimation
member.summary: An animation that animates a property using an array of .
member.remarks: Unlike other animations that use interpolation to animate a property between two values, the uses an array of . Each frame defines a duration and a value that should be set after the animation frame duration has been elapsed.

example.para: The following sample creates a SetAnimation that animates the Color property of a object.
example.code: Dim obj As Rect = New Rect(0, 0, 100, 100) obj.Fill = New SolidFill Dim frames() As AnimationFrame = New AnimationFrame() { New AnimationFrame(TimeSpan.FromSeconds(0!, Color.Red)), New AnimationFrame(TimeSpan.FromSeconds(1!, Color.Blue)), New AnimationFrame(TimeSpan.FromSeconds(2!, Color.Yellow)) } Dim animation As SetAnimation = New SetAnimation(obj.Fill, "Color", frames) animation.Start()

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ILongLinkTerminationPointFilter
member.summary: An interface used to define complex requirements concerning the connection of the links to specific point at the nodes.

remarks.p: The filter can be used instead of to allow more precisely which termination points can be used when routing a link. For each link, the layout algorithm proposes certain termination points that are on the grid at any of the four sides of the corresponding end node. The termination point filter allows you to assign a penalty to the termination points. The termination point with the lowest penalty is most likely to be used. Termination points with penalty Int32.MaxValue are never chosen for the link routing.

The penalty affects which termination point is used, but this also depends whether a route from the "start" termination point to the "end" termination point of the link is possible at all without overlapping obstacles.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ILongLinkTerminationPointFilter.GetPenalty(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel,System.Object,System.Boolean,System.Object,ILOG.Diagrammer.Point2D,ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.NodeSide,System.Int32)
member.summary: Allows you to assign a penalty to the termination point of at a given start point which is on the given side of the node .

remarks.p: Returns a number between 0 and Int32.MaxValue. As smaller the number, as more likely the termination point will be chosen for the link routing. Termination points with penalty Int32.MaxValue are never chosen for the link routing.
The values for are defined in the class ilog.views.Direction. Valid values are Top, Bottom, Left, and Right.

This method is called by if a termination point filter is installed. You can implement this method in order to define complex requirements concerning the connection of the links to the different sides of nodes. For example, if you want all links to be connected to any side except the top side of the nodes, you could use:
return (side != NodeSide.Top ? proposedPenalty : Int32.MaxValue);

member.param: The graph model to which the node belongs.
The link to be connected to the node.
If is , the method determines whether the link origin can be connected. Otherwise, the method determines whether the link destination can be connected.
The proposed termination point for the link.
The side of the node where the proposed termination point is placed. The values are defined in the class ilog.views.Direction. Valid values are Top, Bottom, Left, and Right.
The proposed penalty for the termination point.
member.returns: The new penalty.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Stroke
member.summary: Represents an object used to paint the outline of graphic objects.
member.remarks: A is used to paint the outline of a graphic object with a specified width an style. Use the property to draw several varieties of dashed lines. The line drawn by a can be filled in a variety of fill styles, including solid colors, gradients and textures. The fill style depends on color, gradient or texture that is used as the fill object.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Stroke.MiterLimit
member.summary: Gets or sets the limit of the thickness of the join on a mitered corner.
member.value: The limit of the thickness of the join on a mitered corner. The default value is 10.
member.remarks: The miter length is the distance from the intersection of the line walls on the inside of the join to the intersection of the line walls outside of the join. The miter length can be large when the angle between two lines is small. The miter limit is the maximum allowed ratio of miter length to stroke width. The default value is 10. If the miter length of the join of the intersection exceeds the limit of the join, then the join will be beveled to keep it within the limit of the join of the intersection.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.ScrollViewer
member.summary: Define an object that can scroll any .
member.remarks: The displays a rectangular area with two scroll bars and allows to scroll a graphic object specified through the property. The visibility of the scroll bars are controlled through the and properties.

example.para: The following example creates a ScrollViewer that allows to scroll over a group containing 2 ellipses and a rectangle.
example.code:
Function CreateScrollViewer() As ScrollViewer Dim scrollview As ScrollViewer = New ScrollViewer scrollview.Rectangle = New Rectangle2D(0, 0, 200, 200)
scrollview.HScrollBar = ScrollBarVisibility.AsNeeded scrollview.VScrollBar = ScrollBarVisibility.AsNeeded scrollview.Background = New SolidFill(Color.White)
Dim group As Group = New Group group.Objects.Add(New Ellipse(0, 0, 100, 100)) group.Objects.Add(New Ellipse(120, 0, 100, 100)) group.Objects.Add(New Rect(0, 120, 100, 100))
scrollview.Content = group
Return scrollview End Function

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Polyline
member.summary: Defines a graphic object that draws a polyline.
member.remarks: is a graphic object that displays a polyline. The points of the polyline are defined by the property.

example.para: The following sample shows how to create a dashed polyline.
example.code: Function CreatePolyline() As Polyline Dim polyline As Polyline = New Polyline polyline.Points.AddRange(New Point2D() { _ New Point2D(0, 0), _ New Point2D(100, 10), _ New Point2D(200, 0), _ New Point2D(300, 10)}) polyline.Stroke = New Stroke(Color.Black, 2, DashStyle.Dash) Return polyline End Function

A value of 0 means the first point of the polyline, a value of 1 means the last point of the polyline, and an intermediate value means a point whose linear distance along the polyline path is equal to the total length of the path multiplied by the position.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeMorphology
member.summary: This filter effect performs "fattening" or "thinning" of artwork.
member.remarks: It is particularly useful for fattening or thinning an alpha channel. The dilation (or erosion) kernel is a rectangle with a width of 2*x-radius and a height of 2*y-radius. In dilation, the output pixel is the individual component-wise maximum of the corresponding R,G,B,A values in the input image kernel rectangle. In erosion, the output pixel is the individual component-wise minimum of the corresponding R,G,B,A values in the input image kernel rectangle.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.Internal.ConnectedComponentCollectionAdapter.GetLinkPoints(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the points that define a link.
Reshapes a link.
member.remarks:
The method must work for normal links and intergraph links.
The link style represents the style of the shape of the link. The details of the shape of the link are given by the further arguments of the method. If the new shape of the link must be a straight-line link without any intermediate points, call the method with an empty array for the points argument, or with the value 0 for the length argument. In this case, the values of the arguments startIndex and length are ignored.
The mode parameters determine how the and should be used:
The or parameter contains no meaningful value. The layout does not specify how the corresponding origin or destination point of the link should be determined.
The or parameter contains a meaningful value. The layout wants to move the corresponding origin or destination point of the link to the specified point.
The or parameter contains no meaningful value. The layout wants to keep the previous corresponding origin or destination point of the link fixed, relative to the node position.
The or parameter contains no meaningful value. The layout wants to clip the corresponding origin or destination point of the link against the border of the node.
The or parameter contains a meaningful value. The layout wants to clip the corresponding origin or destination point of the link against the border of the node, but the link should go though the specified point.
member.param: The style of the shape of the link.
The connection point of the link on the origin node.
The mode that indicates how the should be used.
The array of intermediate points. Ignored if length is 0."/>
The starting position in the array of points.
The connection point of the link on the destination node.
The mode that indicates how the should be used.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayoutLinkReshapeMode
member.summary:
The incremental link reshape modes for the Short Link layout algorithm. Incremental link reshape modes can be specified globally for all links, using and , or locally for individual links, using
and . If you want to specify the mode for individual links, you need to set the global mode to .

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayoutLinkReshapeMode.Free
member.summary: Free mode.
member.remarks:
When using this link reshape mode in incremental layout mode, the layout is allowed to freely reshape the unmodified links. Of course, settings that may have been done using , , or
are still obeyed.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayoutLinkReshapeMode.Fixed
member.summary: Fixed mode.
member.remarks: When using this link reshape mode in incremental layout mode, the layout is not allowed to reshape the unmodified links in any way.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayoutLinkReshapeMode.FixedShapeType
member.summary: Fixed shape type mode.
member.remarks: When using this link reshape mode in incremental layout mode, the layout preserves the shape type of the unmodified links. This means that both the number of bends and the node sides to which the links are connected are preserved.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayoutLinkReshapeMode.FixedNodeSides
member.summary: Fixed node sides mode.
member.remarks: When using this link reshape mode in incremental layout mode, the layout preserves the node sides to which the links are connected.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayoutLinkReshapeMode.FixedConnectionPoints
member.summary: Fixed connection points mode.
member.remarks: When using this link reshape mode in incremental layout mode, the layout preserves the connection points of the links.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayoutLinkReshapeMode.Mixed
member.summary: Mixed mode.
member.remarks:
When using this link reshape mode in incremental layout mode, each link can have a different incremental reshape mode. The mode of each individual link can be set by the method
and . .

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayoutLinkBundlesMode
member.summary: The link bundle modes for the Short Link layout algorithm.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayoutLinkBundlesMode.NoBundle
member.summary: No bundle mode.
member.remarks: When used as value of , no link bundles are computed.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayoutLinkBundlesMode.FirstLastSegment
member.summary: First and last segment mode.
member.remarks: When used as value of , only the first and the last segments of the links are bundled.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayoutLinkBundlesMode.ImprovedFirstLastSegment
member.summary: Improved first and last segment mode.
member.remarks: When used as value of , the first and the last segments of the links are bundled in an improved manner.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayoutSelfLinkStyle
member.summary: The self-link styles for the Short Link layout algorithm.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayoutSelfLinkStyle.TwoBendsOrthogonal
member.summary: Two bends orthogonal style.
member.remarks: When used as value of , a two-bend shape is given to the self-links, that is, links with the same origin and destination node.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayoutSelfLinkStyle.ThreeBendsOrthogonal
member.summary: Three bends orthogonal style.
member.remarks: When used as value of , a three-bend shape is given to the self-links, that is, links with the same origin and destination node.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayoutConnectorStyle
member.summary: The connector styles for the Short Link layout algorithm. The connector style can be specified globally for all nodes, using , or locally for individual nodes, using . If you want to specify the style for individual nodes, you need to set the global style to .

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayoutConnectorStyle.Automatic
member.summary: Automatic connectors.
member.remarks:
In this mode, the connector style of all nodes is automatically selected as follows: The connection points are dispatched in the mode
if doing so no connection point goes outside the border the link is attached to. Otherwise, the connection points are dispatched using the style .

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayoutConnectorStyle.FixedOffset
member.summary: Fixed offset connection points.
member.remarks: In this mode, the connection points of all the links are placed at a fixed distance, given by the value of the property .

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayoutConnectorStyle.EvenlySpaced
member.summary: Evenly spaced connection points.
member.remarks: In this mode, the connection points of all the links are evenly spaced along the node border the link is attached to.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayoutConnectorStyle.Mixed
member.summary: Mixed connection points.
member.remarks: In this mode, each node can have a different connector style. The style of each individual node can be set by the method so that different link shapes can occur in the same graph.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayoutMode
member.summary: The modes of the Grid Layout.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayoutMode.TileToGridFixedWidth
member.summary: In this mode, the nodes are placed in the cells of a grid (matrix) that has a fixed maximum number of columns.
member.remarks: The number of columns is equal to the width of the layout region parameter divided by the horizontal grid offset (see .

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayoutMode.TileToGridFixedHeight
member.summary: In this mode, the nodes are placed in the cells of a grid (matrix) that has a fixed maximum number of rows.
member.remarks: The number of rows is equal to the width of the layout region parameter divided by the vertical grid offset (see .

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayoutMode.TileToRows
member.summary: In this mode, the nodes are placed in rows.
member.remarks: The maximum width of the rows is equal to the width of the layout region parameter. The height of each row is the maximum height of the nodes contained in the row (plus margins).

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayoutMode.TileToColumns
member.summary: In this mode, the nodes are placed in columns.
member.remarks: The maximum height of the columns is equal to the height of the layout region parameter. The width of each column is the maximum width of the nodes contained in the column (plus margins).

member.summary: The mode that determines how sub-containers are handled by algorithms.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.NestedGraphMode.Node
member.summary: The sub-container is just considered as a node of the graph, and its contents are ignored by the algorithm performed on its parent container.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.NestedGraphMode.Transparent
member.summary: The children of the sub-container are considered as belonging to the same graph as the children of the parent container, as if the graph was flat.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.NestedGraphMode.Subgraph
member.summary: The sub-container is considered as a nested graph by the graph layout algorithms. The layout algorithms will be performed recursively on the sub-container first, then on the parent container.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.ObjectEventArgs
member.summary: Provides data for the input events of a .
member.remarks:
When a raises an input event, the event is dispatched to the target graphic object itself and to its parents in the hierarchy.
The event dispatching is performed in two phases that determine the notification order in the hierarchy and occurs in the following order:
The first phase notifies the targeted object and its parents, starting from the root of the hierarchy (the top-level parent) down to the targeted graphic object. This is the tunneling routing phase. The events corresponding to this phase are prefixed with the word Preview.
"The second phase is the opposite process: the targeted object and its parents are notified starting from the targeted graphic object up to the root of the hierarchy (the top-level parent). This is the bubbling phase.
The event propagation occurs as long as the event is not marked as .

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLevelRangeConstraint
member.summary: The class HierarchicalLevelRangeConstraint is a constraint that forces the node to be placed at a level with index within the specified range.
member.remarks:
Nodes are organized in horizontal or vertical levels numbered from 0 to "n". If the link flow direction is from top to bottom, the nodes with level index 0 are placed in the topmost level, and the nodes with higher level indices are placed in the levels below. If the link flow direction is from left to right, the nodes with level index 0 are placed in the leftmost level, and the nodes with higher level indices are placed in the levels farther to the right.
For instance, a level range constraint with minimal index 5 and maximal index 7 causes the node to be placed at level with index 5, 6, or 7. A level range with minimal index 6 and maximal index 6 causes the node to be placed exactly at level 6. This has the same effect as specifying the node level index 6 by .
The constraint is evaluated, if the incremental mode is disabled. If the incremental mode is enabled, the constraint is only evaluated if the constraint node is marked for incremental recalculation, because otherwise, the incremental positions of the nodes are dominant.
This kind of constraint is dominated by same level constraints and group spread constraints, that is, two nodes cannot have different level ranges while being forced to the same level. The constraint has higher priority than any relative level constraints.
The automatic conflict resolution can handle conflicting constraints. However, to speedup the layout, it is recommended to specify constraints in a way such that there are no conflicts.
Note that empty levels are invisible after layout. For instance a node with level range constraint to be placed at level 2 may appear to be placed in the topmost level, if level 0 and 1 don't contain any other nodes.

example.para: The following example shows how to use the constraint to place the node in a level 5, 6, or 7.
example.code:
Imports System Imports ILOG.Diagrammer Imports ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic Imports ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout
' node is part of group Dim group As Group = ... Dim node As GraphicObject = ...
Dim layout As HierarchicalLayout = New HierarchicalLayout group.GraphLayout = layout
layout.Constraints.Add( New HierarchicalLevelRangeConstraint(node, 5, 7)) group.PerformGraphLayout

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLevelRangeConstraint.#ctor(System.Object,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new HierarchicalLevelRangeConstraint.
member.param: A node, or a group of type HierarchicalNodeGroup, that should be placed in the specified level range.
The lower bound of the level range, or HierarchicalConstraint.Unspecified if no lower bound is needed.
The upper bound of the level range, or HierarchicalConstraint.Unspecified if no upper bound is needed.

example.para: The following examples shows how to use the constraint. It forces node1 to be in level 5, 6, or 7, and node2 to be in a level with index greater or equal to 5, and node3 to be in a level with index smaller or equal to 7.
example.code: layout.Constraints.Add(New HierarchicalLevelRangeConstraint(node1, 5, 7)) layout.Constraints.Add(New HierarchicalLevelRangeConstraint(node2, 5, HierarchicalConstraint.Unspecified)) layout.Constraints.Add(New HierarchicalLevelRangeConstraint(node3, HierarchicalConstraint.Unspecified, 7))

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Windows.Forms.Overview
member.summary: Represents an overview of a .
member.remarks: The class is a Windows Forms control that displays the overview of a . Use the property to connect this overview to a IDiagramView.

example.para: The following sample shows how to display a in a controlled by an .
example.code: Dim container As Group = New Group Dim ellipse As Ellipse = New Ellipse(0, 0, 100, 100) container.Objects.Add(ellipse) Dim view As DiagramView = New DiagramView view.AutoSizeContent = true view.Content = container Dim oview As Overview = New Overview oview.ControlView = view

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Windows.Forms.DiagramView
member.summary: Represents a Windows Form control that displays the content of a diagram.

remarks.p: The is the Windows Form control that displays the content of a . Use the property to specify the container to display.
The diagram view uses an affine transformation to allow zooming, panning and rotating the view. Use the property to change this affine transformation.

The diagram view has scrolling capabilites. Use the and properties to specify the scrollbars visibility. You can also use the and property to configure the scrollable area. By default, scrolling is enabled into the whole diagram view content.

The DiagramView has a specific mode to display the whole diagram view content whatever its size is. Use the property to switch to this mode. The is used to specify which policy to apply to make the view content always fully visible.

The diagram view dispatches input events to the graphic objects its displays, or to a view interactor. A view interactor is a subclass of the class. When a view interactor has been set using the property, the input events are no more sent to graphic objects.

example.para: The following sample shows how to display a in a .
example.code: Dim container As Group = New Group Dim ellipse As Ellipse = New Ellipse(0, 0, 100, 100) container.Objects.Add(ellipse) Dim view As DiagramView = New DiagramView view.AutoSizeContent = true view.Content = container

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Windows.Forms.DiagramView.ToolLayer
member.summary: Gets or sets the displayed by the view on top of the view content.
member.value: A object that represents the object displayed by the view on top of the view content.
member.remarks:
This graphic container is not affected by the view transformation. It can be used to display static objects on top of the view. The graphic container is automatically resized to the size of the view. Note that if the graphic container has a background (such as objects), you should set it to transparent, or you'll not be able to see the view content.
When this property is not , optimized scrolling in the view is not possible, and thus the value of the property will be ignored.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.SVG.SVGReader
member.summary: Allows importing SVG (Scalable Vector Graphics) files in a diagram.
member.remarks: The class allows to reads a SVG (Scalable Vector Graphics) file and creates a diagram that reflects the content of the SVG document. SVG is a two-dimensional structure graphics format defined by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C). The format is based on the eXtensible Markup Language (XML) which gives it a great interoperability.

example.para: The following code sample shows how to import a SVG file.
example.code:
Sub ReadSVGDocument(ByVal fileName As String, ByVal view As DiagramView) ' Create the Reader Dim svgReader As SVGReader = New SVGReader
' Specifies the initial viewport to the current size of the ' diagram view Dim viewport As Rectangle2D = view.ViewRectangle svgReader.InitialViewPort = New Rectangle2D(0, 0, viewport.Width, viewport.Height)
Try ' read the file Dim svgResult As GraphicObject = svgReader.Load(fileName) Dim top As Group = New Group top.Objects.Add(svgResult) ' set the result in the view view.Content = top view.Transform = Transform.Identity
Catch e As Exception
' error cannot open file
End Try End Sub

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.GraphicSymbol
member.summary: Represents a graphic symbol.
member.remarks: A is a graphic object made of several other objects. A GraphicSymbol can be selected by clicking it, but it's not possible to select its sub-objects.

example.para: The following sample create a GraphicSymbol made of a blue triangle and a gray rectangle.
example.code:
Function CreateGraphicSymbol() As GraphicSymbol Dim symbol As GraphicSymbol = New GraphicSymbol Dim triangle As Basic2DShape = New Basic2DShape(15F, 0F, 80F, 70F) triangle.ShapeType = Basic2DShapeType.Triangle triangle.ControlValue = 0.5F triangle.Fill = New SolidFill(Color.Blue)
Dim rectangle As Rect = New Rect(0F, 20F, 130F, 40F) rectangle.Fill = New SolidFill(Color.Gray) rectangle.Stroke = New Stroke(Color.Red)
symbol.Objects.AddRange(New GraphicObject() {rectangle, triangle}) Return symbol End Function

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.SVG.Css.StreamTokenizer.#ctor(System.IO.TextReader)
member.summary:
Construct a new StreamTokenizer on the StreamReader r. Initialize the default state per specification.
All byte values 'A' through 'Z', 'a' through 'z', and '\u00A0' through '\u00FF' are considered to be alphabetic.
All byte values '\u0000' through '\u0020' are considered to be white space. '/' is a comment character.
Single quote '\'' and double quote '"' are string quote characters.
Numbers are parsed.
Ends of lines are considered to be white space rather than separate tokens.
C-style and C++-style comments are not recognized.
These are the defaults and are not needed in constructor.
member.param: The StreamReader to parse tokens on.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayout
member.summary: The main class for the Hierarchical Layout algorithm.

remarks.p: The Hierarchical Layout arranges the nodes in horizontal or vertical levels such that the majority of the links point in the same direction and the number of link crossings is small.

Here is a sample drawing produced by the Hierarchical Layout algorithm with two levels of nodes that are top-justified within each level:
Click on the image to see it in normal size.

Another sample drawing with eight levels follows. This graph contains a cycle and a self-loop. The direction of the flow is from top to bottom. The nodes are organized in horizontal levels.
Click on the image to see it in normal size.

The Hierarchical Layout algorithm supports different styles of links in the same drawing. The following sample drawing shows orthogonal, straight, and polyline links. The direction of the flow is to the right and the node levels are vertical.
Click on the image to see it in normal size.

The Hierarchical Layout algorithm supports port specifications. The side and index of the port where a link connects to a node can be specified. The following sample drawing shows a drawing with port specifications and orthogonal link style. The direction of the flow is from top to bottom.
Click on the image to see it in normal size.

To simplify the explanations of the layout parameters, we use the compass directions north, south, east, and west. The first level of the layout is the north pole. If the flow direction is top to bottom, north is always upwards, south towards the bottom, west towards the left, and east towards the right side of the layout. If the flow direction is left to right, north is left and south is right.
See the corresponding chapter of the User's Manual for details on the algorithm, the types of graphs for which this algorithm can be used, the features and limitations, code samples, and so on.

Note the following points:
- The layout algorithm always takes into account the direction of links.
- The initial position of the nodes (at the moment you start the layout) does not affect the resulting layout.
- The algorithm supports self-links, cycles, and multiple links between the same pair of nodes.

example.para: The following example shows how to apply the Hierarchical Layout.
example.code:
Imports System Imports ILOG.Diagrammer Imports ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic Imports ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout
Dim group As Group = New Group
' Fill the group with nodes and links here
Dim layout As HierarchicalLayout = New HierarchicalLayout group.GraphLayout = layout group.PerformGraphLayout

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayout.Copy
member.summary: Copies the layout instance.

remarks.p: This method copies the layout instance by calling the copy constructor.

When performing a recursive layout of a nested graph, this method is used by to "clone" the layout instance of a parent graph. Note that the parameters which are specific to a node or a link are not copied. Hierarchical constraints are not copied. The layout position is not copied. Only the global parameters are copied.

member.returns: A copy of the layout instance.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayout.Layout
member.summary: Computes the layout using the Hierarchical Layout algorithm.
member.remarks: To start the layout, call the method .

members.member:
Indicates that this layout class allows the user to specify fixed nodes.
Fixed nodes are not moved during the layout if the property
is set to . Links that are incident to fixed nodes are not reshaped during the layout. Fixed nodes are ignored by the Hierarchical Layout algorithm, which may lead to node overlaps.
'/> Always .

Indicates that this layout class allows the user to specify fixed links.
Fixed links are not reshaped during the layout if the property
is set to .
'/>
Always .

Indicates that this layout class can stop the layout computation in a proper manner when the user-defined allowed time is exceeded.
If the allowed time elapses before termination of the Hierarchical Layout algorithm, the nodes and links are not moved and remain at the same position as before the start of the algorithm. The result code in the layout report is in this case.
'/>
Always .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayout.SupportsStopImmediately
member.summary: Indicates that this layout class can interrupt the current run of layout immediately in a controlled way.
member.remarks: If the algorithm is stopped before termination of the Hierarchical Layout algorithm, the nodes and links are not moved and remain at the same position as before the start of the algorithm. The result code in the layout report is in this case.
member.returns: Always .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayout.StopImmediately
member.summary: Stops the running layout algorithm as soon as possible.
member.remarks: The Hierarchical Layout algorithm has several steps. In the first steps, stopping the algorithm is possible and the method returns . In the very last step, stopping the algorithm is no longer possible and the method returns .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayout.SupportsPercentageComplete
member.summary: Indicates that this layout class can estimate the percentage of completion during the run of layout.
member.returns: Always .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayout.SupportsLayoutOfConnectedComponents
member.summary: Indicates that this layout class can use the generic connected component layout mechanism of the GraphLayout base class.
member.remarks:
This mechanism cuts the attached graph into connected components, applies itself on each connected component separately, and uses the layout instance returned by the property
to place the connected components. By default, this layout is an instance of that can be customized as needed.
The generic connected component layout mechanism has the disadvantage that it moves connected components completely. Fixed nodes within a component do not preserve their previous positions. Nodes of different components with the same specified level index are no longer aligned in levels because each component has an individual level structure.
If the generic connected component layout mechanism is disabled, the algorithm uses its own specialized internal mechanism instead of the generic mechanism. All components are merged into the same global level structure.
member.returns: Always .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayout.SupportsLinkConnectionBox
member.summary: Indicates that this layout class can use a link connection box provider to calculate the end points of links.
member.remarks:
The link connection box provider is an object that provides the rectangle to which the links are connected for each node and the tangential shift offset at each side for the connection points. This is useful if the connection points of the links at a node should be relative to a rectangle that is smaller or larger than the real bounding box of the node.
Link connection points are calculated for all links except those with the no-reshape link style and fixed links. The tangential offsets provided by the link connection box provider are currently ignored.
If a connection box provider object is set at the property , the layout algorithm uses this object together with the connector style to calculate the connection points for links.
If the link clip mode is set additionally, the layout algorithm calculates the initial connection points at the node boxes with the link connection box provider and the connector style and tells the graph model to obtain the final connection points by clipping against the shape of the nodes via the reshape mode of . This works well in particular if the node box obtained by the link connection box provider is smaller than the real bounding box of the node.
member.returns: Always .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayout.SetLinkStyle(System.Object,ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayoutLinkStyle)
member.summary: Sets the style of the shape of an individual link.
member.remarks:
This link style is used only if the global link style is set to . Otherwise, all links have the style that is specified as the global link style.
Valid values are:
- The link gets a polyline shape, that is, a shape consisting of a sequence of line segments.
- The link gets an orthogonal shape, that is, a shape consisting of a sequence of orthogonal line segments.
- The link gets a straight-line shape.
- No reshape is performed on the link.
The default value is .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayout.GetLinkStyle(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the style of the shape of an individual link.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayout.UnspecifiedPosition
member.summary: Represents the unspecified position.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayout.SetLinkPriority(System.Object,System.Single)
member.summary: Sets the priority of a link.
member.remarks: The layout algorithm tries to place the links in such a way that the majority of the links are short and point in the same direction. However, this is not always possible for all links. Low priority links are more likely to be longer or point in the opposite direction than the high priority links. The link priority should be smaller than 10000.
member.param: The link priority value, a number up to 10000.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayout.GetLinkPriority(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the priority of a link.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayout.SetFromPortIndex(System.Object,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the port index of a link at the "from" side.
member.remarks:
This allows you to specify the relative ports of the links on the node border. Using relative ports is a way to specify the relative order of how the links connect to the "from" node. The specification is only used if the free origin point mode is used for the link.
Port numbers are between 0 and n - 1, where n is the number of ports at the node side where the link is connected. Links with an unspecified or negative port index are connected on the node border according to the global connector style. A link with a specified port index i is connected at the ith relative port, and the connection points of ports are evenly spaced on the corresponding node border.
member.param: The relative port index starting from 0.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalLayout.GetFromPortIndex(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the port index of a link at the "from" side.
member.remarks: Returns -1 if the port index is unspecified.

This allows you to specify the relative ports of the links on the node border. Using the relative ports is a way to specify the relative order of how the links connect to the "to" node. The specification is only used if the free destination point mode is used for the link.
Port numbers are between 0 and n - 1, where n is the number of ports at the node side where the link is connected. member.summary: Sets the number of relative ports of a node on a given side.
member.remarks:
Possible values for the parameter are , , , and .
Using the relative ports is a way to specify the relative order of how the links connect to the node. The ports of a node side can be considered as connection points that are evenly spaced on the node border. Links can connect to specific pins by setting the "from" port index or the "to" port index of the link.
If the "from" port index or the "to" port index of any link connecting to the node is greater than the specified number of ports of this node, the number of ports is automatically adjusted.
