member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.MinNodeCornerOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum offset between a node corner and a link starting at this node.
member.remarks:
Setting this to 0 enables the layout to start a link exactly at a node corner.
The default value is 3.
member.value: The minimum offset between a node corner and a link starting at this node.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.MinStartSegmentLength
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum length of the first segment of each link, that is, the segment incident to the "from" node.

remarks.p: The default value is 10.

member.value: The minimum length of the first segment of each link, that is, the segment incident to the "from" node.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.MinEndSegmentLength
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum length of the last segment of each link, that is, the segment incident to the "to" node.

remarks.p: The default value is 10.

member.value: The minimum length of the last segment of each link, that is, the segment incident to the "to" node.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.AllowedTimePerLink
member.summary: Gets or sets the upper limit for the time allowed to find a route for a long link.
member.remarks:
The algorithm tries to find a short route for the link. It uses a backtrack mechanism to find a route that bypasses obstacles. The runtime of the backtrack can be large if the size of the drawing area is large and the grid offset is small. The algorithm stops the backtrack when the specified time is elapsed and gives up without result.
The default value is 2000 (2 seconds).
Note that the specified time is valid for each single link, that is, the maximal time to find routes for all links is approximately the specified time per link multiplied by the number of links. However, this happens only extremely seldom. The algorithm will most likely find a route for the majority of the links before the time elapses; therefore, the average time to find routes for all links is much smaller.
If the specified time elapsed for a link and the fallback routing is enabled, the link is quickly routed by the fallback mechanism instead.
member.value: The upper limit for the time allowed to find a route for a long link.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.MaxBacktrack
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximal number of backtrack steps to find a route for a long link.
member.remarks:
The algorithm tries to find a short route for the link. The backtrack number indicates that the algorithm tries to find a route that is so many grid points longer than the shortest possible route before it gives up the search.
Decreasing the value causes the algorithm to give up earlier without result. If the "from" point and "to" point are fixed, this speeds up the search. Otherwise, the time behavior is more complex, so it may speed up or slow down the search.
The default value is 30000.
If the maximal number of backtrack steps is exceeded and the fallback routing is enabled, the link is quickly routed by the fallback mechanism instead.
member.value: The maximal number of backtrack steps to find a route for a long link.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.LinkStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the global style of the shapes of links.
member.remarks:
Valid values are:
- all links get an orthogonal shape, that is, a shape consisting of a sequence of alternating horizontal and vertical line segments.
- all links get a nearly straight-line shape. The shape of the links is a polyline composed of a straight-line segment between the end nodes with two short horizontal or vertical segments at its ends (their length is controlled by and and may be 0). In this link style, links may overlap nodes.
- each link can have a different link style. The style of each individual link can be set by the method
so that different link shapes can occur in the same graph.
Unless the global link style is , all links have the same style of shape.
The default value is .
member.value: The global style of the shapes of links.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.ExhaustiveSearching
member.summary: Gets or sets the exhaustive searching of routes for links.
member.remarks:
If this option is enabled, the algorithm examines the complete grid exhaustively to find a route for an orthogonal link. This may result in fewer bends, but it takes a huge amount of runtime for large graphs.
Exhaustive searching is disabled by default.
member.value: The exhaustive searching of routes for links.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.StraightRouteEnabled
member.summary: Gets or sets the straight routing.
member.remarks:
If this option is enabled, the algorithm makes an additional attempt to find a route with zero or one bend before starting the normal backtrack mechanism. As result, the layout has fewer bends, but the distribution of links at the border may become uneven.
Straight routing is enabled by default.
member.value: The straight routing.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.CrossingReductionEnabled
member.summary: Gets or sets the crossing reduction.
member.remarks:
If this option is enabled, the algorithm tries to reduce the crossings between orthogonal links that are routed.
Crossing reduction is enabled by default.
member.value: The crossing reduction.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.NumberCrossingReductionIterations
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximal number of iterations performed during crossing reduction.
member.remarks:
This option has an effect only if crossing reduction is enabled. Reducing the value speeds up the algorithm, but the layout may contain more link crossings.
The default value is 2.
member.value: The maximal number of iterations performed during crossing reduction.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.OriginPointMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the global mode for the connection point of the links on the origin nodes.
member.remarks:
Valid values are:
- For all links, the layout is free to choose the appropriate position of the connection point on the origin node, except for "pinned" connection points (see ).
- For all links, the layout must keep the current position of the connection point on the origin node. This can be useful, in particular, if the node has fixed pins where the link is attached (anchors for which returns ) and the pins should not be moved by the layout algorithm.
Note that, in this mode, the first segment of a link is not placed on the grid. Therefore, the first segment may be closer than the specified minimal offset to neighbor links, or may even overlap them if they start at the same fixed point.
- Each link can have a different mode for the connection point on the origin node. The mode of each individual link can be set by the method .
Unless the global mode is , the connection points on the origin node have the same mode for all the links.
The default value is .
member.value: The global mode to set.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.DestinationPointMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the global mode for the connection point of the links on the destination nodes.
member.remarks:
Valid values are:
- For all links, the layout is free to choose the appropriate position of the connection point on the destination node, except for "pinned" connection points (see ).
- For all links, the layout must keep the current position of the connection point on the destination node. This can be useful, in particular, if the node has fixed pins where the link is attached (anchors for which returns ) and the pins should not be moved by the layout algorithm.
Note that, in this mode, the first segment of a link is not placed on the grid. Therefore, the first segment may be closer than the specified minimal offset to neighbor links, or may even overlap them if they start at the same fixed point.
- Each link can have a different mode for the connection point on the destination node. The mode of each individual link can be set by the method .
Unless the global mode is , the connection points on the destination node have the same mode for all the links.
The default value is .
member.value: The global mode to set.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.IncrementalMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the incremental layout mode.
member.value: The incremental layout mode.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.IncrementalConnectionPreserving
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the incremental layout mode preserves the side and relative order of the link connection points.
member.remarks: The default is .
member.value: Whether the incremental layout mode preserves the side and relative order of the link connection points.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.InterGraphLinksMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the routing of intergraph links.
member.remarks:
If the argument is , the intergraph links are routed; otherwise, only the normal links are routed. An intergraph link is a link stored in a given graph that has an origin or destination not stored in this graph. If the combined intergraph link routing is enabled in additional, this means that normal links and intergraph links are routed together;, otherwise, only the intergraph links are routed.
The default value is .
If the intergraph link mode is enabled and the graph actually contains some intergraph links, there are some restrictions:
The incremental mode has no effect.
If layout is performed on a nested (or ), the top-level graph must have a view attached because of the coordinate transformations of the subgraphs. If you create your own subclass of instead of to route intergraph links, you must ensure that all graph models of all subgraphs use the same coordinate system through appropriate coordinate transformations.
member.value: The routing of intergraph links.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.CombinedInterGraphLinksMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the routing of normal links in addition to intergraph links.
member.remarks:
If intergraph link routing is disabled, the option has no effect. If intergraph link routing is enabled and the argument is , both normal links and intergraph links are routed in the same pass. Otherwise, only the intergraph links are routed.
The default value is .
member.value: The routing of normal links in addition to intergraph links.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.NodeObstacleEnabled
member.summary: Gets or sets whether nodes should be obstacles for the link routes.
member.remarks: The default is . There are, however, situations where it may be suitable to consider a set of obstacles different from the nodes. In this case you can switch nodes as obstacles off and use the method to specify the obstacles that are needed.
member.value: Whether nodes should be obstacles for the link routes.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.LinkObstacleEnabled
member.summary: Gets or sets whether links should be line obstacles for the link routes.
member.remarks:
The default is . There are, however, situations where it may be suitable to consider a set of obstacles different from the links. In this case you can switch links as obstacles off and use the methods
and
to specify the obstacles that are needed.
member.value: Whether links should be line obstacles for the link routes.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.FallbackRouteEnabled
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the fallback routing algorithm is enabled.
member.remarks:
This routing algorithm is used for those links that cannot be routed on the grid without overlapping other obstacles (nodes or links). If it is disabled, then these fallback links remain unrouted.
The default is .
member.value: Whether the fallback routing algorithm is enabled.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.NodeBoxProvider
member.summary: Gets or sets the node box interface for the obstacle area.
member.remarks:
The node box interface is an object that provides the rectangle that determines the node box for each node. If none is given, the layout algorithm uses the bounding box of each node (see and ) by default. This node box specifies the obstacle area of the node, that is, the area that links should avoid so they do not overlap the node. This can be different from the node box used to find the connection points of the links.
You can set this property to to go back to the default behavior.
member.value: The node box interface for the obstacle area.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.NodeSideFilter
member.summary: Gets or sets the node-side filter, that is, an object that allows or prohibits the connection of the links on a given side of the nodes.

remarks.p: Note that the node-side filter serves the same purpose as the termination point filter; it is, however, easier to use. If a termination point filter is installed, the node-side filter is ignored. If neither a termination point filter nor a node-side filter is installed, the layout algorithm is free to choose any side of the nodes.

When a filter is specified, the layout algorithm asks the filter at which side of its end node each link is allowed to attach to. Note that a filter should always allow a link to connect to at least one side of a node; otherwise the link cannot be routed.
You can set this property to to go back to the default behavior.

member.value: The node-side filter, that is, an object that allows or prohibits the connection of the links on a given side of the nodes.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.TerminationPointFilter
member.summary: Gets or sets the termination point filter, that is, an object that allows filtering the termination points that are proposed by the layout algorithm.

remarks.p: For each side, the layout algorithm proposes some termination points. It also proposes a penalty that indicates how "good" this termination point is. The default penalty indicates how far the termination point is away from the border. By installing a termination point filter, you can change this penalty.

Note that the termination point filter serves the same purpose as the node-side filter but allows a greater flexibility. If a termination point filter and a node-side filter are installed, the node-side filter is ignored. If neither a termination point filter nor a node-side filter is installed, the layout algorithm is free to choose any termination point.

When a filter is specified, the layout algorithm proposes a sequence of termination points on the grid for each link. It proposes termination points at all four sides of the corresponding end node. It asks the filter for the penalty of each termination point and then chooses the termination points with the lowest penalty that are feasible to route the link.
You can set this property to to go back to the default behavior.

member.value: The termination point filter, that is, an object that allows filtering the termination points that are proposed by the layout algorithm.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.PreserveFixedLinks
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the layout avoids movement of fixed links.
member.remarks: See for details.
member.value: Whether the layout avoids movement of fixed links.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.AllowedTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the upper limit for the duration of the layout algorithm.
member.remarks: See for details.
member.value: The upper limit for the duration of the layout algorithm.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LongLinkLayout.LinkConnectionBoxProvider
member.summary: Gets or sets the link connection box interface for the connection points of links.
member.remarks: See for details.
member.value: The link connection box interface for the connection points of links.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.LinkTextPositionType.AbsoluteFromStart
member.summary: The value specifies that the property is interpreted as a fixed length (in pixels) along the path of the link, measured from the starting point of the link.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.LinkTextPositionType.AbsoluteFromEnd

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.LinkTextPositionType.AbsoluteFromMiddle
member.summary: The value specifies that the property is interpreted as a fixed length (in pixels) along the path of the link, measured from the middle point of the link.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.LinkTextPositionType.Relative
member.summary: The value specifies that the property is interpreted as a ratio (between 0 and 1) of the total length of the link's path. For example, the position 0 means the starting point of the link, the position 1 means the end point of the link, the position 0.5 means the middle of the link.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Link
member.summary: Defines a polyline graphic object that can be connected to two other graphic objects so that when one of the objects moves, the link's shape is modified to stay connected to the object. Links can display arrows at both ends, and provide many style options for filling the link's path, drawing a border, and displaying text.

remarks.para: A Link can be connected to the objects of a through the and properties, or it can be disconnected, in which case the start and end points are set through the and properties.

The property can be set to compute the link's shape automatically depending on the end points. The link shape can be a simple straight line, a sequence of orthogonal segments, a sequence of orthogonal or oblique segments, or a free sequence of lines. The property can be used to display rounded link bends.
The link class can display arrows at both ends through the and properties. You can use a standard GDI+ arrow, or one of the predefined arrow shapes, or provide your own to draw a custom shape.
The link's path can be drawn using any stroke. The property can also be used to draw special "pipe" or "neon" effects.
An additional border can be drawn around the link's path using the and properties.
One or several text items can be displayed on the link through the property.

Crossings between links can be displayed using a "tunnel" or "bridge" shape, or simply by "cutting" the link's shape. This is controlled by the property. Note that, to enable the computation of link crossings, the property must enable link crossings on the toplevel that contains the links.

example.para: The following example creates a simple graph with 3 nodes and 3 links between the nodes:
example.code:
Function CreateNodesAndLinks() As GraphicObject ' Create a Group to store the graph Dim graph As Group = New Group
' Create ellipses for the nodes. Dim node1 As Ellipse = New Ellipse(0, 0, 50, 50) Dim node2 As Ellipse = New Ellipse(300, 0, 50, 50) Dim node3 As Ellipse = New Ellipse(150, 300, 50, 50)
' Add one anchor for each node node1.Anchors.Add(New ShapeAnchor) node2.Anchors.Add(New ShapeAnchor) node3.Anchors.Add(New ShapeAnchor)
node1.Fill = New SolidFill(Color.Blue) node2.Fill = node1.Fill node3.Fill = node1.Fill
' Create the links Dim link1 As Link = New Link link1.StartAnchor = node1.Anchors(0) link1.EndAnchor = node2.Anchors(0)
Dim link2 As Link = New Link link2.StartAnchor = node2.Anchors(0) link2.EndAnchor = node3.Anchors(0)
Dim link3 As Link = New Link link3.StartAnchor = node3.Anchors(0) link3.EndAnchor = node1.Anchors(0)
' Store node and links in the Group graph.Objects.AddRange( _ New GraphicObject() { _ link1, link2, link3, _ node1, node2, node3}) Return graph End Function

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Link.AddCrossings(System.Drawing.Drawing2D.GraphicsPath,ILOG.Diagrammer.CrossingPoint[],System.Single,System.Single,ILOG.Diagrammer.Point2D,ILOG.Diagrammer.Point2D,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Adds a shape representing one or several crossings to the path of this link. This method is called by CreateGraphicsPath while building the link's path if the link crosses other links. When a sequence of crossings are close to each other, the method is called with all the crossings of the "bundle", thus allowing to create a single shape that represents the bundle. Otherwise, the method is called once for each "isolated" crossing.
member.param: The link's path that is being built. The method must add to this path the appropriate elements to display the crossings.
The starting point of the "Space" that the crossings must fill.
The ending point of the "Space" that the crossings must fill.
The angle of the link segment on which the crossings appears.
if the starting point of the crossings is close to the start of the segment and cannot be displayed normally.
if the ending point of the crossings is close to the end of the segment and cannot be displayed normally.

member.summary: Shortens a segment to a specified length.
member.param: The start point of the segment
The end point of the segment
The desired length of the new segment
If true, the length of the new segment is limited to half the length of the initial segment.
A new point such that the segment [p1,result] is aligned with the segment [p1,p2], and has a length of 'e'.
member.returns: If half = false: true if the segment [p1,p2] has a length greater than e, otherwise false and 'e' is modified to be the length of [p1,p2]. If half = true: true if the segment [p1,p2] has a length greater than 2*e, otherwise false and 'e' is modified to be half the length of [p1,p2].

member.remarks:
The link shape can be one of the following:
The points of the link are not set automatically (except the first and last point if the link is connected to graphic objects).
The link is a single straight line.
The points of the link are set so that the link is a sequence of orthogonal segments. The shape is computed to avoid the bounding regions of the start and end objects (if possible).
The points of the link are set so that the link is a sequence of oblique (45 degrees) or orthogonal segments. The shape is computed to avoid the bounding regions of the start and end objects (if possible).

member.name: E:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Link.ShapeTypeChanged
member.summary: Occurs when the property is changed.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Link.BorderStroke
member.summary: Gets or sets the stroke used to draw the border of the link. The border is drawn "around" the normal path of the link.
member.value: A instance, or . The default value is .
member.remarks:
The border is drawn before (or "under") the link's path, so:
You must always leave the stroke alignment to , otherwise the border will be hidden by the path.
Since only half of the border's stroke will appear, you must use a stroke twice as wide as the desired border width.

member.name: E:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Link.BorderStrokeChanged
member.summary: Occurs when the property is changed.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Link.BevelBorder
member.summary: Gets or sets the flag that specifies if a "bevel" border is drawn around the link's path. The bevel is made of a sequence of segments with "light" and "dark" colors (derived from the color specified in the property ) to simulate a 3-D effect.
member.value: if a "bevel" border id drawing around the link's path; Otherwise, .

remarks.para: If the property is not , the property is ignored.
The visible width of the bevel is equal to the width of the divided by 4, with a minimum of 2.

member.name: E:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Link.BevelBorderChanged
member.summary: Occurs when the property is changed.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Link.FillEffect
member.summary: Gets or sets the type of effect used to draw the path of the link.
member.value: One of the values.
member.remarks:
The fill effect can be one of:
The path is drawn using the property.
Parallel stripes with darkening colors (derived from the 's color) are drawn to simulate a 3-D cylinder.
Parallel stripes with fading colors (derived from the 's color) are drawn to simulate a glowing neon lamp.

member.name: E:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Link.FillEffectChanged
member.summary: Occurs when the property is changed.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Link.Radius
member.summary: Gets or sets the radius used to draw the rounded bends of the link.
member.value: A value that represents the radius of the link bends. The default value is 0.
member.remarks: A radius of 0 means that the bends are not rounded (that is, the link is drawn normally as a polyline).

member.name: E:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Link.RadiusChanged
member.summary: Occurs when the property is changed.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Link.Curved
member.summary: Determines whether the link is drawn as a curve or as straight line segments.
member.value: if the link is drawn as a curve; Otherwise, .

remarks.para: If is , the link is drawn as a curve.
If the property is , the curve is a cardinal spline, that is, it goes through all the points of the link.
If is , the curve is a bezier spline that goes through the middle points of the intermediate segments of the link.
Note that this property has no effect on straight links, so the should be set to , or .

member.name: E:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Link.CurvedChanged
member.summary: Occurs when the property is changed.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Link.CardinalSpline
member.summary: When the property is , determines whether the curve goes through all the points of the link or if it goes through the middle points of the intermediate segments.
member.value: if the link is drawn as a cardinal spline; Otherwise, .

remarks.para: If is and is (the default), the link is drawn as a cardinal spline, that is, a curve that goes through all the definition points of the link. The sharpness of the bends can then be adjusted using the property.

If is and is , the link is drawn as a bezier spline. The spline starts at the start point of the link, then goes through the middle points of all the segments (except the first and last segments), and ends at the end point of the link. With this option, the curve does not go through all the points of the link, but the result is usually nicer than with a cardinal spline. The property controls how closely the curve follows the straight segments of the link.

member.name: E:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Link.CardinalSplineChanged
member.summary: Occurs when the property is changed.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Link.CurveTension
member.summary: Gets or sets the tension parameter used to compute the shape of the curve when is .
member.value: A value representing the curve tension. The default value is 0.5.

member.summary: Occurs when the property is changed.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.LinkArrow.Size
member.summary: Gets or sets the size of the arrow.

remarks.para: The actual size of the arrow will be the value of the multiplied by the width of the , plus the width of the or the bevel width if any.

The width and height must be thought of as applying to a vertical arrow. When the arrow is not vertical, it is just rotated and not resized. So, for example, the width of a horizontal arrow is determined by the property of the and a its height is determined by property of the .
The default size of the arrow is 4.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.LinkTextOrthogonalAlignment.Left
member.summary: Causes the text item to be drawn on the left of the link's path (looking towards the end of the link).
member.remarks: For example, if the text is on a horizontal segment of the link pointing right, the text will be drawn above the link.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.LinkTextOrthogonalAlignment.Right
member.summary: Causes the text item to be drawn on the right of the link's path (looking towards the end of the link).
member.remarks: For example, if the text is on a horizontal segment of the link pointing right, the text will be drawn below the link.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.LinkTextParallelAlignment
member.summary: Defines the alignment of a parallel to the direction of the .
member.remarks: Use the values of this enumeration to set the property of a .

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.LinkTextParallelAlignment.Middle
member.summary: Causes the text to be centered on the text item's position.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.LinkTextParallelAlignment.Start
member.summary: Causes the text to be aligned with the position of the text item, on the side nearest to the start of the link.
member.remarks: For example, if the text is on a horizontal segment of the link pointing right, the text will be left-aligned with respect to the position of the text item.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.LinkTextParallelAlignment.End
member.summary: Causes the text to be aligned with the position of the text item, on the side nearest to the end of the link.
member.remarks: For example, if the text is on a horizontal segment of the link pointing right, the text will be right-aligned with respect to the position of the text item.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Image
member.summary: Defines a graphic object that draws an image.
member.remarks: The class displays a raster image, or a vector image. To display a raster image, use the property. To display a vector image, use the property.

example.para: Following example creates an image object:
example.code: Function CreateImage() As ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Image Dim img As ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Image = New ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Image img.Rectangle = New Rectangle2D(0, 0, 100, 100) img.KeepAspectRatio = AspectRatioAlignment.XMidYMid img.ImageUri = New Uri("http://www.ilog.com/logo.gif") Return img End Function

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Image.Slice
member.summary: Gets or sets the mode used to stretch the image in the object bounding box.
member.value: When the value is , the image is stretched to respect the value of the property and the image will cover the bounding box of the object defined by the property, thus some part of the image might not be visible. When the value is (the default), the image will be stretched to respect the value of the property and the image will be fully visible inside the bounding box of the object, thus some part of the bounding box of the object might not be filled with the image.

If the container does not provide any anchor, a with a position equal to will be used as the default.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Printing.ExtendedPrintDocument
member.summary: Defines a document that can be sent to a printer.
member.remarks: Derives from the class and adds the notion of header and footer. Typically you create an instance of the class, set the properties that describe how to print, such as the header and footer, and use the Print method to start the printing process. Handle the event where you specify the content to print in a page by using the object in the .

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class using the default .
member.remarks: By default, there is no header, no footer, and the order of the page is over, then down.

member.summary: This member overrides PrintDocument.OnPrintPage.
member.remarks: This method is sealed. In order to print the content of a page you must override .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.Printing.ExtendedPrintDocument.OnPrintPageContent(System.Drawing.Printing.PrintPageEventArgs)
member.summary: Raises the event. It is called before the actual content of the current page is printed.
member.param: A PrintPageEventArgs that contains the event data that was received by .
member.remarks:
This method allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
When a derived class calls the OnPrintPageContent method, it raises the PrintPageContent event by invoking the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see Raising an Event.
When overriding OnPrintPageContent in a derived class, be sure to call the OnPrintPageContent method of the base class so that registered delegates receive the event.

member.remarks: The pages are numbered horizontally then vertically when this property is , otherwise they are numbered vertically then horizontally.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Printing.HeaderFooter
member.summary: Represents the header or footer of an .

remarks.p: You can set the header and the footer of a using the and properties.

A header or footer is defined by three text sections. The texts will be drawn on the left, center and right area of the header. Each text can have several lines and may contain some predefined patterns that will be translated to values of the document that is printed. Such patterns exist for the page number, the number of pages in the document, the file name, the document name, the author, the date and time.

example.para: The following example creates a print document that prints a footer showing the page number on each page.
example.code: Function CreatePrintDocument() As ExtendedPrintDocument Dim document As New ExtendedPrintDocument document.Header = new Header(null, HeaderFooter.PagePattern, null) Return document End Function

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.CrossingManager
member.summary: The class computes the crossings of a set of polyline objects in a canvas. The polyline objects must implement the ICrossable interface (for now, the interface is implemented only by objects). The crossing manager uses an implementation of the Bentley-Ottmann "sweep-line" algorithm, which has an execution time of O((n+k)log(n)) (n = # of segments, k = # of intersections). The algorithm is run every time the contents of the canvas change. When crossing points are detected, the crossing manager notifies crossable objects by setting their CrossingPoints property.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.CrossingManager.ComputeCrossings
member.summary: Performs the sweep-line algorithm on the segments of all the "crossable" objects (that is, objects that implement the ICrossable interface) contained in the specified Canvas, and recursively in the sub-Canvas. The crossings of each object are stored in the object's CrossingPoints property (if they have changed).

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.CrossingManager.AddSegments(ILOG.Diagrammer.ICrossable,ILOG.Diagrammer.Point2D[])
member.summary: Adds a set of segments on which to perform the algorithm.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.CrossingManager.Sweep
member.summary: Performs the sweep-line algorithm on the current segments.

member.summary: Returns if the connected component of the graph attached to the layout instance that contains is a pure tree (with no cycles).
member.remarks:
Returns if this component contains at least one cycle.
Self-links (that is, links with the same origin and destination node) are ignored during this test.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutUtil.IsConnected(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel)
member.summary: Checks whether a graph model is connected or not.
member.remarks: The method returns if is connected (that is, a graph where there is a path connecting each pair of nodes) and returns otherwise.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutUtil.GetConnectedComponents(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel)
member.summary: Returns a graph model.

remarks.p: If the argument represents a connected graph (see ), the graph model is returned unchanged. Otherwise, it returns a new graph model in which only nodes are stored (no links). Each node of the new graph model is itself a graph model (instance of ) and contains the nodes and the links of a connected component of the graph model passed as an argument.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutUtil.ComputeNumberOfNodeOverlaps(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel)
member.summary: Returns the number of overlaps between nodes in the graph model.
member.remarks: It takes the bounding box of the nodes into account, but not the precise shape.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutUtil.ComputeNumberOfNodeLinkOverlaps(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel)
member.summary: Returns the number of overlaps between a node and a link in the graph model.
member.remarks: It takes the bounding box of the nodes into account, but not the precise shape.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutUtil.ComputeNumberOfLinkBends(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel)
member.summary: Returns the number of bends of all links in the graph model.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutUtil.ComputeNumberOfLinkCrossings(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel)
member.summary: Returns the number of crossings between two links in the graph model.
member.remarks: This does not include the number of link overlaps: Two link segments cross if they are not parallel but have a common point. Two link segments overlap if they are parallel and have a common point.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutUtil.ComputeNumberOfLinkOverlaps(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel)
member.summary: Returns the number of overlaps between two links in the graph model.
member.remarks: This does not include the number of link crossings: Two link segments cross if they are not parallel but have a common point. Two link segments overlap if they are parallel and have a common point. It assumes the links have a width of at least 0.5.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutUtil.GetLayouts(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel,ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ILayoutProvider,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns the instances of GraphLayout for the nested graph encapsulated by the input graph model.
member.remarks: It returns the layout instance for this graph, and recursively for all subgraphs. The order of the enumerator can be pre-order (that is, the layout of parent graph comes before the layout of the subgraphs) or post-order (that is, the layout of the subgraphs comes before the layout of the parent graph).
member.param: The object that provides a layout instance to be used for laying out each subgraph.
If ), the layout instances are returned in pre-order, otherwise in post-order.

member.summary: Enumerator over the layouts of a nested model in preorder.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutUtil.LayoutsPostorderEnumerator
member.summary: Enumerator over the layouts of a nested model in postorder.
member.remarks: Careful: This is not Java enumerator style semantics.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.LinearGradientFill
member.summary: Defines a linear gradient fill.
member.remarks:
allows to fill an area with a linear gradient. The linear gradient follows a gradient axis defined by two points the and properties.
defines a starting color ( property) and a ending color ( property). The start color corresponds to the point defined by and the end color to the point . Additional colors can be added on the gradient axis through the property.

example.para: The following example creates a Rect object with a linear gradient from the top-left corner of the rectangle to the bottom-right corner.
example.code: Function CreateRectWithLinearGradient() As Rect Dim rectangle As Rect = New Rect(0, 0, 100, 100) Dim myFill As LinearGradientFill = New LinearGradientFill myFill.P1 = New Point2D(0, 0) myFill.P2 = New Point2D(1, 1) myFill.StartColor = Color.Red myFill.EndColor = Color.Blue myFill.GradientStops.AddRange(New GradientStop() {_ New GradientStop(Color.White, 0.25F), _ New GradientStop(Color.Orange, 0.75F)}) rectangle.Fill = myFill Return rectangle End Function
example.para: This example will produce the following image:

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.PathGradientFill
member.summary: Defines a path gradient fill.
member.remarks: allows painting an area with a gradient from the outline of a path to the center of the path. can have various shape. The shape can be an ellipse, a circle, a rectangle or when the gradient is used to fill a graphic object, the shape can be the shape of the graphic object itself. The shape of the gradient is defined by the property. defines a starting color ( property) and a ending color ( property). The start color corresponds to the outline of the path and the end color to the center of the path. Additional colors can be added between the center and the outline through the property.

example.para: The following example creates an ellipse filled with a path gradient.
example.code:
Function CreateEllipseWithPathGradientFill() As Ellipse Dim ellipse As Ellipse = New Ellipse(0, 0, 100, 100)
Dim myFill As PathGradientFill = New PathGradientFill myFill.GradientShape = PathGradientShape.CurrentShape myFill.StartColor = Color.Red myFill.EndColor = Color.Blue myFill.GradientStops.AddRange( _ New GradientStop() { _ New GradientStop(Color.White, 0.25F), _ New GradientStop(Color.Orange, 0.75F)}) myFill.CenterPoint = New Point2D(0.25F, 0.25F)
ellipse.Fill = myFill Return ellipse End Function
example.para: This example will produce the following image:

member.value: A that represents the affine transformation of the path gradient.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.PathGradientFill.Bounds
member.summary: Gets or sets the bounds of the path gradient.
member.value: A that represents the bounds of the path gradient. When the value of property is (the default), the value of the property must be interpreted in the coordinate system of the graphic object being painted. In this coordinate system (0,0) is mapped to the top-left corner of the graphic object and (1,1) to the bottom-right corner of the graphic object. Thus when the property is (0,0,1,1) the path gradient covers the whole graphic object.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.PathGradientFill.CenterPoint
member.summary: Gets or sets the center point of the gradient.
member.value: A structure that represents the center of the path gradient. The interpretation of the value depends on the value of the property. The default value is the point (0.5 0.5) and the default coordinate type is so the center is the center of the graphic object.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.PathGradientFill.GradientShape
member.summary: Gets or sets the shape of the gradient.
member.value: One of the values. The default value is .

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.DockPanel
member.summary: Defines an area within which you can arrange child elements by docking them on the left, top, bottom or center of the panel.
member.remarks: is a panel in which you can arrange child elements docking them on the left, top, bottom or center of the panel. Use the method to set the dock style of a child object. Use the and methods to specify how the child will be aligned in its docking position.

example.para: The following sample creates a DockPanel with two child, an ellipse docked in the center and a rectangle docked at the bottom.
example.code:
Function CreateDockPanel() As DockPanel Dim dockPanel As DockPanel = New DockPanel
dockPanel.BorderMargins = New Margins(2F) dockPanel.ItemsMargins = New Margins(2F) dockPanel.Rectangle = New Rectangle2D(0F, 0F, 200F, 200F)
Dim ellipse As Ellipse = New Ellipse dockPanel.SetDock(ellipse, DockStyle.Fill) dockPanel.SetVerticalAlignment(ellipse, VerticalAlignment.Stretch) dockPanel.SetHorizontalAlignment(ellipse, HorizontalAlignment.Stretch) ellipse.Fill = New SolidFill(Color.Red)
Dim rect As Rect = New Rect dockPanel.SetDock(rect, DockStyle.Bottom) rect.AutoSize = True rect.Text = "A DockPanel" dockPanel.SetVerticalAlignment(rect, VerticalAlignment.Center) dockPanel.SetHorizontalAlignment(rect, HorizontalAlignment.Stretch)
dockPanel.Objects.Add(ellipse) dockPanel.Objects.Add(rect) Return dockPanel End Function

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.ClosedCurve
member.summary: Defines a graphic object that draws a closed cardinal spline curve.
member.remarks: defines a graphic object that draws a closed cardinal spline curve. The points defining the curve are defined by the property.

example.para: The following sample creates a closed curve.
example.code: Function CreateClosedCurve() As ClosedCurve Dim curve As ClosedCurve = New ClosedCurve curve.Points.AddRange(New Point2D() {_ New Point2D(0, 0), _ New Point2D(100, 50), _ New Point2D(200, 0), _ New Point2D(300, 50)}) curve.Stroke = New Stroke(Color.Black, 2, DashStyle.Dash) curve.Fill = New SolidFill(Color.Blue) Return curve End Function

member.value: When the value is , the view contents is stretched to respect the value of the property and the image will cover the bounding box of the object defined by the property, thus some part of the image might not be visible. When the value is (the default), the image will be stretched to respect the value of the property and the image will be fully visible inside the bounding box of the object, thus some part of the bounding box of the object might not be filled with the image.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Basic2DShape
member.summary: Defines a class that represents basic 2D shapes.
member.remarks: The class draws basic 2D shapes defined by the enumeration. To modify the shape of a Basic2DShape object, use the and properties.

example.para: The following example creates a object that represents a star.
example.code: Function CreateBasicShape() As Basic2DShape Dim gradient As LinearGradientFill _ = New LinearGradientFill(New Point2D(0, 0), _ New Point2D(0, 1), _ Color.Yellow, Color.Red) Dim star As Basic2DShape = New Basic2DShape star.ShapeType = Basic2DShapeType.Star4 star.ControlValue = 0.8F star.Fill = gradient star.Stroke = New Stroke(Color.Olive) Return star End Function

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.GridElement
member.summary: Defines row or column specific properties within a .

remarks.para: A GridElement objects represent rows or a columns of a .

A GridElement can have a fixed size, a size that depends on the available space in the it belongs to, or a size that depends on the objects located in it. The and properties are used to control the GridElement size. When is set to , the property represents the amount of available space that will be allocated to the grid element relative to the other elastic grid elements. When is set to , the property is the size in pixels of the grid element.

member.example: For a complete example on see the class.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.remarks: This constructor creates an elastic grid element with a default size of 100.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the specified parameters.
member.remarks: This constructor creates an elastic grid element with a default size of 100.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.GridElement.Size
member.summary: Gets or sets the size of this grid element.
member.value: A value.
member.remarks: When the property is set to , the property represents the amount of available space that will be allocated to the grid element relative to the other elastic grid elements. When the property is set to , the property is the size in pixels of the grid element.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.GridElement.UnitType
member.summary: Gets or sets the unit type for this grid element.
member.value: One of the values. The default value is .
member.remarks: When the property is set to , the property represents the amount of available space that will be allocated to the grid element relative to the other elastic grid elements. When the property is set to , the property is the size in pixels of the grid element. When the property is set to , the property is not used, and the grid element size is computed with the size of the graphic objects located in this grid element.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.GridPanel
member.summary: Defines a grid area consisting of columns and rows.

remarks.para: A is made of columns and rows. Columns and rows can be accessed through the and properties, which are collections of objects.

To place a child object inside the grid, use the , methods. The and can also be used when an object needs to to span accross several columns or rows. Note that the method can also be used to place a graphic object in the grid.

example.code:
Function CreateGridPanel() As GridPanel
' Creates a grid panel Dim grid As GridPanel = New GridPanel grid.Rectangle = New Rectangle2D(0F, 0F, 300F, 300F)
' Create 2 rows and 2 columns ' The first column uses 30% of the width ' The second column uses 70% of the with ' Each row occupies 50 % of the total height Dim column1 As GridElement = New GridElement(GridUnitType.Elastic, 30F) Dim column2 As GridElement = New GridElement(GridUnitType.Elastic, 70F) Dim row1 As GridElement = New GridElement(GridUnitType.Elastic, 100F) Dim row2 As GridElement = New GridElement(GridUnitType.Elastic, 100F)
' Add columns and rows grid.Columns.Add(column1) grid.Columns.Add(column2) grid.Rows.Add(row1) grid.Rows.Add(row2)
' Creates a white rectangle on the first ' row and spanning on two columns Dim rect1 As Rect = New Rect rect1.Fill = New SolidFill(Color.White) grid.SetRow(rect1, 0) grid.SetColumn(rect1, 0) grid.SetColumnSpan(rect1, 2)
' Creates a blue rectangle on the second ' row and first column Dim rect2 As Rect = New Rect rect2.Fill = New SolidFill(Color.Blue) grid.SetRow(rect2, 1) grid.SetColumn(rect2, 0)
' Creates a yellow rectangle on the second ' row and second column Dim rect3 As Rect = New Rect rect3.Fill = New SolidFill(Color.Yellow) grid.SetRow(rect3, 1) grid.SetColumn(rect3, 2)
grid.Objects.AddRange(New GraphicObject() {rect1, rect2, rect3}) Return grid End Function

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Canvas
member.summary: Defines an area within which you can explicitly position child objects by coordinates relative to the area.
member.remarks: A is a graphic objects within which you can explicitly position child objects by coordinates relative to the area. Use the method to position a child object in the area.

example.para: The following example creates a canvas with two rectangle inside it, the first one is attached on the top right of the canvas and the second one on the bottom left.
example.code:
Function CreateCanvas() As Canvas Dim canvas As Canvas = New Canvas
canvas.Rectangle = New Rectangle2D(0F, 0F, 220F, 160F) canvas.Background = New SolidFill(Color.LightGray) canvas.Border = New Stroke(Color.Blue, 2F) canvas.CornerRadius = New CornerRadius(5F)
Dim rect1 As Rect = New Rect(10F, 10F, 70F, 40F) rect1.Fill = New SolidFill(Color.White)
canvas.SetAnchor(rect1, AnchorStyle.Top Or AnchorStyle.Left)
Dim rect2 As Rect = New Rect(140F, 110F, 70F, 40F) rect2.Fill = New SolidFill(Color.White)
canvas.SetAnchor(rect2, AnchorStyle.Bottom Or AnchorStyle.Right)
canvas.Objects.AddRange(New GraphicObject() {rect1, rect2}) Return canvas End Function

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Printing.DiagramPrintDocument
member.summary: Defines a reusable object to send the contents of a to the printer.

remarks.p: This class derives from the class and allows you to send the contents of a to the printer.
Typically you create an instance of the class, set the properties that describe how to print, such as the header and footer, and use the Print method to start the printing process.

The property is used to specify the that will be printed. The and properties are used to determine the area of the container that will be printed. The , , and properties can be used to specify the zoom factor at which the printing will occur.

example.para: The following sample shows how to print a diagram.
example.code: Dim container As Group = New Group Dim ellipse As Ellipse = New Ellipse(0, 0, 100, 100) container.Objects.Add(ellipse) Dim document As DiagramPrintDocument = New DiagramPrintDocument(container) document.AutoZoom = true document.Rows = 2 document.Columns = 2 document.PrinterSettings.PrinterName = "MyPrinter" document.Print()

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.Internal.GraphModelData.InternalGraphModelChecking
member.summary: Gets whether the extended checking of internally created graph models is enabled.
member.remarks: If a grapher is attached directly, a graph model is created internally. Internally created graph models are automatically disposed of when no longer needed. If the checking is enabled, exceptions are thrown in certain situations that are a potential misuse of the internally created graph model, since it may be disposed of too early. The option is enabled by default. Normally, you should not disable this option.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.Internal.Direction
member.summary:
The C# replacement of IlvDirection. For internal use only. This shared enum ensures that, for instance, TreeLayoutFlowDirection.Left has the same int value as TreeLayoutLevelJustification.Left, such that we can translate the Java usages of IlvDirection.Left into Direction.Left without needing to choose among TreeLayoutFlowDirection.Left or TreeLayoutLevelJustification.Left depending on the context.
Not all values of Direction are supported by all layout properties taking such an argument!!! In particular, the value "Center" is supported by some, but not by others.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.SubgraphCorrectionBoundsFixed
member.summary: This subgraph correction strategy keeps the bounds of a subgraph fixed during recursive layout.
member.remarks:
This works only if the graph model is an instance of and the subgraph is an instance of . Otherwise it behaves like . While the strategy only affects the position of the subgraph, this strategy potentially affects the zoom level of the subgraph as well.
If you use a Recursive Layout (see ) on a nested graph and all subgraphs are laid out completely, and the layout mode of all layouts is not incremental, then you do not need to install any subgraph correction at the Recursive Layout. However, in the following situations, it is useful to install this subgraph correction strategy:
The subgraph is laid out, but its parent graph is not laid out (because no layout is specified for the parent graph).
The subgraph is laid out, but the subgraph is specified as fixed inside the parent graph (for instance by ).
The subgraph and its parent graph are laid out, but the layout of the parent graph uses an incremental mode that analyzes the old position of the subgraph (see for instance
or ).
If subgraphs of type are used, the layout of the subgraph affects the bounding box of the subgraph. The subgraph may appear at a completely different position after layout, even though no layout of the parent graph was performed that contains the subgraph as a node, and even though was never called for the subgraph. By installing this subgraph correction strategy, this effect is eliminated because the subgraphs are moved back to their bounds after layout.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.SubgraphCorrectionBarycenterFixed
member.summary: This subgraph correction strategy keeps the barycenter of a subgraph fixed during recursive layout.

remarks.p:
If you use a Recursive Layout (see ) on a nested graph and all subgraphs are laid out completely, and the layout mode of all layouts is not incremental, then you do not need to install any subgraph correction at the Recursive Layout. However, in the following situations, it is useful to install this subgraph correction strategy:
The subgraph is laid out, but its parent graph is not laid out (because no layout is specified for the parent graph).
The subgraph is laid out, but the subgraph is specified as fixed inside the parent graph (for instance by ).
The subgraph and its parent graph are laid out, but the layout of the parent graph uses an incremental mode that analyzes the old position of the subgraph (see for instance
or ).
If subgraphs of type are used, the layout of the subgraph affects the bounding box of the subgraph. The subgraph may appear at a completely different position after layout, even though no layout of the parent graph was performed that contains the subgraph as a node, and even though was never called for the subgraph. By installing this subgraph correction strategy, this effect is eliminated because the subgraphs are moved back to their old barycenter after layout.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.SubgraphCorrectionBarycenterFixed.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new SubgraphCorrectionBarycenterFixed.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.SubgraphCorrectionBarycenterFixed.Correct(System.Object,ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout,ILOG.Diagrammer.Rectangle2D)
member.summary: Corrects the subgraph position by moving its center to the center of the input bounding box.
member.param: The subgraph that has been laid out.
The layout that has been performed on the subgraph.
The former bounding box of the subgraph at the point in time before the layout.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.SubgraphCorrectionBoundsFixed.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new SubgraphCorrectionBoundsFixed.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.SubgraphCorrectionBoundsFixed.Correct(System.Object,ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout,ILOG.Diagrammer.Rectangle2D)
member.summary: Corrects the subgraph bounds by trying to reshape the subgraph to the input bounding box.
member.remarks: The success depends on various modes of that permit or forbid movements or zoom level changes. This is called by the Recursive Layout (see ) immediately after the layout of the subgraph has finished.
member.param: The subgraph that has been laid out.
The layout that has been performed on the subgraph.
The former bounding box of the subgraph at the point in time before the layout.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.SolidFill
member.summary: Defines a solid color fill.
member.remarks: allows filling an area with a . You specify the color through the property.

example.para: The following example creates an ellipse filled with a blue solid fill.
example.code: Function CreateEllipseWithSolidFill() As Ellipse Dim ellipse As Ellipse = New Ellipse(0, 0, 100, 100) Dim myFill As SolidFill = New SolidFill(Color.Blue) ellipse.Fill = myFill Return ellipse End Function
example.para: This example will produce the following image:

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.Serialization.XmlSerializationManager.AddExtenderProvidedProperty(System.Object,System.Xml.XmlNode)
member.summary: Registers the specified property for late invokation on the given target.
member.remarks:
The xml node can either be an or an . The node name must respect the following format: providerRef.propertyName, where:
providerRef is the name of the provider instance in the xml document (the name of an instance is defined by a def:Name attribute on its corresponding XmlElement).
propertyName is the name of the extended property.
This method cannot be called outside of a serialization session.
member.param: The target instance of this extended property.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.Serialization.XmlSerializationManager.GetAssemblyMapping(System.Type,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns the xml mapping information for the specified .
member.remarks:
A is defined in the xml document by an xml namespace and a corresponding prefix. This xml namespace is computed from the and the CLR namespace where this type is defined, and allows Type resolution during the deserialization process.
The xmlns declaration corresponding to a Type definition is defined as: xmlns:prefix="namespace,assemblyFullName.
member.param: if a xml mapping information should be created if none already exists; otherwise.
member.returns: The xml mapping information for the specified .

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Path
member.summary: Represents a graphic object that can display any type of shape.
member.remarks: The shape of the object is specified by a object. You specify the shape of the path through the property.

example.para: The following example creates a path object that displays a triangle.
example.code: Function CreatePath() As Path Dim path As Path = New Path path.Fill = New SolidFill(Color.Blue) path.Stroke = New Stroke(Color.Red, 2) path.FillMode = FillMode.Alternate path.Data.Segments.AddRange(New PathSegment() {_ New StartSegment(50, 0), _ New LineSegment(100, 100), _ New LineSegment(0, 100), _ New CloseSegment}) Return path End Function

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeImage.Slice
member.summary: Gets or sets the mode used to stretch the image in the filter effect region.
member.value: When the value is , the image is stretched to respect the value of the property and the image will cover the filter effect region, thus some part of the image might not be inside the filter effect region. When the value is (the default), the image will be stretched to respect the value of the property and the image will be fully drawn inside the filter effect region, thus some part of the filter effect region might not be filled with the image.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeComponentTransfer
member.summary: Defines the component transfer filter effect.
member.remarks:
The component transfer filter effect. This filter effect performs component-wise remapping of data as follows:
R' = feFuncR( R ) G' = feFuncG( G ) B' = feFuncB( B ) A' = feFuncA( A )
for every pixel. It enables operations like brightness adjustment, contrast adjustment, color balance or thresholding.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeComponentTransferFuncType
member.summary: Defines the type of component transfer functions for a object.
member.remarks: Use the value of this enumeration to define the type of component transfer function in the property of the class.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeComponentTransferFuncType.Identity
member.summary: Defines the identity transfer function. The transfer function is : C' = C

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeComponentTransferFuncType.Table
member.summary:
Defines the table transfer function. For table, the function is defined by linear interpolation into a lookup table by attribute TableValues, which provides a list of n+1 values (that is, v 0 to v n ) in order to identify n interpolation ranges. Interpolations use the following formula.
For a value C pick a k such that:
k/N <= C < (k+1)/N The result C' is given by: C' = v k + (C - k/N)*N * (v k+1 - v k )

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeComponentTransferFuncType.Discrete
member.summary:
Defines the discrete transfer function. The function is defined by the step function defined by attribute TableValues, which provides a list of n values (that is, v 0 to v n-1 ) in order to identify a step function consisting of n steps. The step function is defined by the following formula.
For a value C pick a k such that:
k/N <= C < (k+1)/N The result C' is given by: C' = v k

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeComponentTransferFuncType.Linear
member.summary:
Defines the linear transfer function. The function is defined by the following linear equation:
C' = slope * C + intercept

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeComponentTransferFuncType.Gamma
member.summary:
Defines the gamma transfer function. The function is defined by the following exponential function:
C' = amplitude * pow(C, exponent) + offset

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.Internal.SubgraphData
member.summary: An container class that collects and delivers the node and link data of subgraphs. It kind of flattens all subgraph models into one.
member.remarks:
The main problem of the IGraphModel is, that the end nodes of intergraph links are not in the same graph model, hence we cannot ask their coordinates, and the nodes of a subgraph are not known to the intergraph link that does not belong to the subgraph, but must route through it because it ends inside.
All coordinates of the subgraph data are stored and delivered in view coordinates, hence we don't have to bother with the fact that each subgraph has its own local coordinate system.
It kind of looks like duplicating data that is anyway already in the nested graphers. But unfortunately, graph layout has to work with any graph model, not just with grapher adapters, hence the additional effort.
The class implements a graph model such that we easily can use a graph layout algorithm. The nodes and links in this graph model are dummy objects of type NodeData and LinkData, that correspond to a flattened view of the nested nodes and links.
If the information is derived from a grapher adapter, the class works only if this grapher adapter has a view, because it takes this view as reference for the coordinate transformations. The layout is either done in ViewCoordinates or in InverseViewCoordinates. The coordinates mode LocalCoordinates is handled as InverseViewCoordinates, because due to the nesting, there is not just one manager to deal with. If the customer specified an explicit reference transformer, this one is ignored (for technical reasons).

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.Internal.SubgraphData.GetLinkPoints(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the points that define a link.
Reshapes a link.
member.remarks:
The method must work for normal links and intergraph links.
The link style represents the style of the shape of the link. The details of the shape of the link are given by the further arguments of the method. If the new shape of the link must be a straight-line link without any intermediate points, call the method with an empty array for the points argument, or with the value 0 for the length argument. In this case, the values of the arguments startIndex and length are ignored.
The mode parameters determine how the and should be used:
The or parameter contains no meaningful value. The layout does not specify how the corresponding origin or destination point of the link should be determined.
The or parameter contains a meaningful value. The layout wants to move the corresponding origin or destination point of the link to the specified point.
The or parameter contains no meaningful value. The layout wants to keep the previous corresponding origin or destination point of the link fixed, relative to the node position.
The or parameter contains no meaningful value. The layout wants to clip the corresponding origin or destination point of the link against the border of the node.
The or parameter contains a meaningful value. The layout wants to clip the corresponding origin or destination point of the link against the border of the node, but the link should go though the specified point.
member.param: The style of the shape of the link.
The connection point of the link on the origin node.
The mode that indicates how the should be used.
The array of intermediate points. Ignored if length is 0."/>
The starting position in the array of points.
The connection point of the link on the destination node.
The mode that indicates how the should be used.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.ClipPath
member.summary: Defines a clip path to clip a graphic object.
member.remarks: This class is used to clip a graphic object by setting the property.

example.para: The following sample shows how to create a group clipped by an ellipse.
example.code: Dim group As Group = New Group Dim rect As Rect = New Rect(0, 0, 200, 200) rect.Fill = New SolidFill(Color.Blue) Dim circle As Circle = New Circle(100, 100, 50) circle.Fill = New SolidFill(Color.Black) group.Objects.Add(rect) group.Objects.Add(circle) ' clip with an ellipse Dim clip As ClipPath = New ClipPath clip.Path.AddEllipse(New Rectangle2D(0, 50, 200, 100)) group.Clip = clip

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.TextOnPath
member.summary: Represents a text drawn along a path.
member.remarks: Represents a text drawn along a path specified through the property. The text is specified through the property. The text is drawn along the path after the offset specified by the property. An additional spacing between letters can be specified using the property.

example.code:
Function CreateTextOnPath() As TextOnPath Dim textOnPath As TextOnPath = New TextOnPath textOnPath.Text = "Diagram for .NET" textOnPath.Font = New Font("Garamond", 35.0F, FontStyle.Bold)
Dim gradient As LinearGradientFill = _ New LinearGradientFill(New Point2D(0, 0), _ New Point2D(0, 1), _ Color.Yellow, _ Color.Red) textOnPath.Fill = gradient textOnPath.Stroke = New Stroke(Color.Olive) textOnPath.Path.SetGeometry( _ "M100 200 C 100 100 250 100 250 200 S400 300 400 200")
Return textOnPath End Function

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Arc
member.summary: Defines a graphic object that represent an arc.
member.remarks: is a graphic object that represents an arc. The arc is defined by a bounding rectangle (property , a start angle and a sweep angle (properties and .

example.para: The following sample creates an arc with a black border.
example.code: Function CreateArc() As Arc Dim arc As Arc = New Arc arc.Rectangle = New Rectangle2D(0, 0, 100, 100) arc.StartAngle = 10 arc.SweepAngle = 45 arc.Stroke = New Stroke(Color.Black, 2) Return arc End Function

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Pie
member.summary: Defines a graphic object that represent a pie.
member.remarks: is a graphic object that represents a pie. The pie is defined by a bounding rectangle (property ), a start angle and a sweep angle in degrees (properties and ).

example.para: The following sample creates a light blue pie with a black border.
example.code: Function CreatePie() As Pie Dim pie As Pie = New Pie pie.Rectangle = New Rectangle2D(0, 0, 100, 100) pie.StartAngle = 10 pie.SweepAngle = 45 pie.Fill = New SolidFill(Color.LightBlue) pie.Stroke = New Stroke(Color.Black, 2) Return pie End Function

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeSourceAlpha
member.summary: Represents the alpha channel of the graphic object to which the filter was set.
member.remarks: FeSourceAlpha has all of the same rules as except that only the alpha channel is used. The resulting image is an RGBA image consisting of implicitly black color values for the RGB channels, but whose alpha channel is the same as .

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeSourceGraphic
member.summary: Represents the graphic object to which the filter was set.
member.remarks: The graphic object will be rasterized into an initially clear RGBA raster in image space. Pixels left untouched by the original graphic will be left clear. The image is specified to be rendered in linear RGBA pixels. The alpha channel of this image captures any anti-aliasing.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeMerge
member.summary: This filter effect composites input image layers on top of each other using the over operator with Input1 at the bottom and the last specified input, InputN at the top.
member.remarks: Many effects produce a number of intermediate layers to create the final output image. This filter allows us to collapse those into a single image.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutStepPerformedEventArgs
member.summary: Provides data for the layout step event on layout instances.
member.remarks:
If you install a on a layout instance, a LayoutStepPerformed event is delivered to the handlers each time the method
is called by the layout algorithms. This allows you to obtain the layout report (using ) more than once during the layout and to be informed of the behavior of the layout algorithm before its completion. You can, for example, implement a progress bar and update it each time you receive the layout event.
Note that the layout event is delivered only if the method
is called. This depends on the implementation of the method .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutStepPerformedEventArgs.#ctor(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout)
member.summary: Creates the event.
member.param: The layout instance source of the event

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutStepPerformedEventArgs.LayoutStarted
member.summary: Gets whether the layout just has started.
member.remarks:
Returns if this event is the first event at the beginning of the layout process of a graph, and otherwise.
If this property returns , the property
called on the same event instance returns .
You can use this property to detect the first event sent by the layout process of a graph, for instance, in order to print a message or to give feedback to the end user. Note that the property returns for the events that follow the first event.
member.value: Whether the layout just has started.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutStepPerformedEventArgs.LayoutFinished
member.summary: Gets whether the layout just has finished.
member.remarks: Returns if this event is sent at the end of the layout process of a graph, and otherwise. You can use this property to detect the last event sent by the layout process of a graph, and to get the corresponding layout report code from it using .
member.value: Whether the layout just has finished.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutStepPerformedEventArgs.LayoutReport
member.summary: Gets the graph layout report contained in the event.
member.remarks:
It simply returns the layout report by calling the method
on the layout instance that is the source of the event.
Note that if a subclass of overrides the method , this method can return an instance of a subclass of , depending on the class of layout report created.
member.value: The graph layout report contained in the event.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutStepPerformedEventArgs.GraphLayout
member.summary: Gets the graph layout that is the source of the event.
member.value: The graph layout that is the source of the event.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutPropertyChangedEventArgs
member.summary: Provides data for the property event on layout instances.
member.remarks:
If you install a on a layout instance, a PropertyChanged event is delivered to the handler each time the property
is changed; that is, each time a layout parameter changes and each time the layout is successfully performed. This allows you to react when a layout parameter changes; for instance, to update a display that shows the current values of the layout parameters or to update a flag indicating whether the set of layout parameters must be saved to file.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutPropertyChangedEventArgs.#ctor(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout,System.Object,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates the event.
member.param: The layout instance source of the event.
The node or link that is affected, or if all nodes and links are affected.
The name of the layout parameter that has changed, or , when the layout was successfully performed.
if the layout parameters are set up-to-date; if a layout parameter changed.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutPropertyChangedEventArgs.GraphLayout
member.summary: Gets the graph layout instance of the event.
member.value: The graph layout instance of the event.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutPropertyChangedEventArgs.ParametersUpToDate
member.summary: Gets whether the parameters are up to date.
member.remarks:
Returns if
was called with a argument. This usually happens only after the layout was successfully performed.
Returns if
was called with a argument. This usually happens when a layout parameter changed.
member.value: Whether the parameters are up to date.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutPropertyChangedEventArgs.ParameterName
member.summary: Gets the name of the parameter that has been changed.
member.remarks: Returns if the layout became up to date but no specific parameter has changed.
member.value: The name of the parameter that has been changed.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutPropertyChangedEventArgs.NodeOrLink
member.summary: Gets the node or link that is affected by the layout parameter.
member.remarks: For layout parameters that affect a single node or link, this node or link is returned. Returns if the layout parameter is global or affects many or all nodes and links.
member.value: The node or link that is affected by the layout parameter.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ConnectionPointMode
member.summary: The modes how the layout algorithms handle the connection points of links at nodes.
member.remarks:
These modes are supported by , , and . The modes specify whether the layout needs to keep the connection points of links fixed or whether it is allowed to move them. If it is allowed to move them, the link must have an anchor that can be moved. The specification makes sense for connection points that are not pinned (), to fine tune whether connection points that are in principle movable should actually be moved by the layout algorithm. Pinned connection points however are never moved by the layout algorithms.
Connection point modes can be specified globally for all links, for instance by , or locally for individual links, for instance by . If you want to specify the mode for individual links, you need to set the global mode to .

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ConnectionPointMode.Free
member.summary: Free movement mode.
member.remarks: When this mode is used, the layout is free to choose the appropriate position of the connection points, except for "pinned" connection points (see ). This mode can be used as global mode affecting all links, or as local mode affecting only individual links.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ConnectionPointMode.Fixed
member.summary: Fixed movement mode.
member.remarks: When this mode is used, the layout must keep the current position of the connection point. This mode can be used as global mode affecting all links, or as local mode affecting only individual links.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ConnectionPointMode.Mixed
member.summary: Mixed movement mode.
member.remarks: This mode can only be used as global mode affecting all links. When this mode is used as global mode, it is possible to specify individual movement modes per link.

member.remarks: The flow direction is supported by and .

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.CoordinatesMode
member.summary: The modes for the coordinates for the layout algorithm.
member.remarks: These modes are used to specify which coordinates are used when computing the geometry of the graph. Layout spacing parameters are interpreted with respect to the coordinates mode. In view coordinates mode, a spacing of 40 means 40 pixel on the screen. In graphic container coordinates mode, a spacing of 40 mean 40 units relative to the units system used for graphic objects inside the graphic container; on the screen, this appears zoomed by the zoom factor of the view. In inverse view coordinates mode, a spacing of 40 means 40 units like in graphic container coordinates mode, however size and position of objects are calculated by inversing the coordinates system of the view. The difference between graphic container coordinates and inverse view coordinates is visible if the graphic container contains objects that don't follow the zoom level of the view proportionally.
