member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout
member.summary: The main class for the Tree Layout algorithm.

remarks.p: The Tree Layout algorithm places the nodes of a tree starting from the root of the tree to the leaves. If the graph has parts that are disconnected, it arranges each connected component as an individual tree. The Tree Layout algorithm is primarily designed for a forest of pure trees. In a tree, each node except the root has a parent node. All the nodes that have the same parent are called children with respect to the parent and siblings with respect to each other. The Tree Layout algorithm can also be used for non-trees (for example, cyclic graphs). In this case, the layout algorithm ignores those links that violate the tree structure and takes only the spanning tree of the graph into account.

The algorithm has several layout modes:
The nodes can be arranged freely in a horizontal or vertical way. This is suitable for a graph with a large variation of node sizes.
The nodes can be arranged in horizontal or vertical levels. This is suitable for a graph that contains nodes of approximately the same size.
The nodes can be arranged radially on concentric circles or on ellipses around the root of the tree.
To simplify the explanations of the layout parameters, we use the compass directions north, south, east, and west. The center of the root node of a tree is the north pole. If the root node is placed at the top border, north is always upwards, south towards the bottom, west towards the left, and east towards the right side of the layout. If the root node is placed at the left border, north is left and south is right. In radial mode, the root is placed in the center, and so the notation of north and south depends on where a node is placed relative to the root. The north side of any node is the side that is closer to the root and the south side is the side that is farther away from the root.

Several alignment options are provided. In particular, the free layout mode allows the tip-over alignment, which means that subtrees are arranged serially rather than in parallel. If the subtrees starting at one node are normally arranged horizontally, the tip-over alignment arranges them vertically. The tree layout provides layout modes that automatically adapt the tip-over alignment to best fit the layout to a given aspect ratio.

The following sample drawings are produced by the Tree Layout algorithm. The left drawing uses the level layout mode. The flow direction of the links is towards the bottom, and the nodes are south-justified (that is, they are aligned to the bottom) within each level. The right drawing is the same tree in free layout mode (which always uses north level alignment):
Click on the image to see it in normal size.

Here is another sample drawing in free layout mode with the tip-over alignment at some leaf nodes:
Click on the image to see it in normal size.

The following are two sample drawings in the two radial layout modes. The normal radial mode in the left drawing places the nodes of the same level on a circle around the root node. The alternating radial mode in the right drawing places the nodes of the same level alternating on two circles around the root node. This results in better usage of the space.
Click on the image to see it in normal size.

In nonradial layout modes, the Tree Layout algorithm supports different styles of links in the same drawing. The following sample drawing shows orthogonal and straight-line links. It also shows nodes that are aligned to the center (see the red nodes), to the east (green), and to the west (blue) of their children. The drawing was created by the free layout mode with the link flow direction to the right, and so north is to the left.
Click on the image to see it in normal size.

The Tree Layout algorithm supports node neighboring in all modes. The following sample drawing shows a tree layout with the flow direction towards the top. Some nodes are not placed as children but rather as neighbors at the same level as the corresponding parent node. The red links, which are perpendicular to the flow direction, are between nodes that were specified as neighbored.
Click on the image to see it in normal size.
See the corresponding chapter of the User's Manual for details on the algorithm, the types of graphs for which this algorithm can be used, the features and limitations, code samples, and so on.

Note the following points:
If no root node is specified, the layout algorithm takes the direction of links into account to calculate a root node. Other than that, the direction of links does not affect the layout.
The layout algorithm has an incremental mode that is designed to be stable when incremental changes are made. If nodes are added or removed after a layout, the next layout uses a heuristic to try to adjust the layout only minimally and to avoid major structural reorganization.
In incremental mode, the initial position of the nodes (at the moment you start the layout) affects the resulting layout because the algorithm tries to preserve the relative order of the children on incremental changes.

example.para: The following example shows how to apply the Tree Layout.
example.code:
Imports System Imports ILOG.Diagrammer Imports ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic Imports ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout
Dim group As Group = New Group
' Fill the group with nodes and links here
Dim layout As TreeLayout = New TreeLayout group.GraphLayout = layout group.PerformGraphLayout

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the Tree Layout algorithm.
member.remarks:
To indicate the graphic container you want to lay out, use the method .
To indicate the graph model you want to lay out, use the method .
To perform the layout, use the method .
To modify the layout parameters, use the different methods provided in this class and its superclass.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.#ctor(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout)
member.summary: Creates a new layout instance by copying an existing one.
member.remarks:
This constructor is used by the method. Any subclass should provide a copy constructor.
The parameters of the source layout are copied using the method .
member.param: The layout instance that is copied.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.Init
member.summary: Initializes instance variables.

remarks.p: You should not call this method directly. The method is called internally by the constructor without arguments and by the copy constructor. The method must be overridden by subclasses that need to initialize additional instance variables.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.Copy
member.summary: Copies the layout instance.

remarks.p: This method copies the layout instance by calling the copy constructor.

When performing a recursive layout of a nested graph, this method is used by to "clone" the layout instance of a parent graph. Note that the parameters which are specific to a node or a link are not copied. Only the global parameters are copied. The layout position is not copied.

member.returns: A copy of the layout instance.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.CopyParameters(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout)
member.summary: Copies the parameters from a given layout instance.

remarks.p: Note that the parameters which are specific to a node or a link are not copied. Only the global parameters are copied. The layout position is not copied.

member.param: The layout instance from which the parameters are copied.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.Layout
member.summary: Computes the layout using the Tree Layout algorithm.
member.remarks: To start the layout, call the method .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.Detach
member.summary: Detaches the graph model from the layout instance.
member.remarks:
When you attach a new graph model to the layout instance, you do not need to detach the old graph model because this is done automatically when you call . The detach method performs cleaning operations on the graph model. In addition to the cleaning operations in the base class, the Tree Layout removes the alignment, root preference, and node neighboring specifications of individual nodes, and the link style specifications of individual links.
Note that you must call this method when you no longer need the layout instance. Otherwise, some objects may not be garbage collected.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.CleanNode(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel,System.Object)
member.summary: Cleans a node.
member.remarks:
This method removes any data that has been stored by the layout algorithm on a node. In addition to the cleaning operations in the base class, Tree Layout removes the root node preference and the alignment and east/west attachment settings from the nodes.
Subclasses can override this method to remove additional information stored in the nodes.
member.param: The graph model to which belongs.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.CleanLink(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel,System.Object)
member.summary: Cleans a link.
member.remarks:
This method removes any data that has been stored by the layout algorithm on a link. In addition to the cleaning operations in the base class, Tree Layout removes the link style settings from the nodes.
Subclasses can override this method to remove additional information stored in the links.
member.param: The graph model to which belongs.

members.member:
Indicates that this layout class allows the user to specify fixed nodes.
Fixed nodes are not moved during the layout if the property
is set to . Links that are incident to fixed nodes are not reshaped during the layout. Fixed nodes are ignored by the Tree Layout algorithm, which may lead to node overlaps. The effect is very similar to the effect when the node is filtered during layout.
'/> Always .

Indicates that this layout class allows the user to specify fixed links.
Fixed links are not reshaped during the layout if the property
is set to . Fixed links are ignored by the Tree Layout algorithm, which may lead to overlaps. The effect is very similar to the effect when the link is filtered during layout.
'/>
Always .

Indicates that this layout class can stop the layout computation in a proper manner when the user-defined allowed time is exceeded.
If the allowed time elapses before termination of the Tree Layout algorithm, the nodes and links are not moved and remain at the same position as before the start of the algorithm. The result code in the layout report is in this case.
'/>
Always .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.SupportsStopImmediately
member.summary: Indicates that this layout class can interrupt the current run of the layout immediately in a controlled way.
member.remarks: If the algorithm is stopped before termination of the Tree Layout algorithm, the nodes and links are not moved and remain at the same position as before the start of the algorithm. The result code in the layout report is in this case.
member.returns: Always .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.StopImmediately
member.summary: Stops the running layout algorithm as soon as possible.
member.remarks: The Tree Layout algorithm has several steps. During the first steps, the layout algorithm can be stopped and the method returns . In the very last step, the layout algorithm cannot be stopped and the method returns .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.SupportsPercentageComplete
member.summary: Indicates that this layout class can estimate the percentage of completion during the run of the layout.
member.returns: Always .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.SupportsLayoutOfConnectedComponents
member.summary: Indicates that this layout class can use the generic connected component layout mechanism of the GraphLayout base class.
member.remarks:
This mechanism cuts the attached graph into connected components, applies itself to each connected component separately, and then uses the layout instance returned by the property
to position the connected components. By default, this layout is an instance of that can be customized as needed.
The generic connected component layout mechanism has the disadvantage that it moves connected components completely. Fixed nodes within a component do not preserve their old positions, and the resulting layout may be unstable on incremental changes in incremental mode, depending on which layout instance is used for the component layout.
If the generic connected component layout mechanism is disabled, the algorithm uses its own specialized internal mechanism instead of the generic mechanism to lay out each component as a separate tree. This is usually faster and more stable on incremental changes than the generic mechanism. In addition, it enables the user to set the position of the layout.
member.returns: Always .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.SupportsLinkConnectionBox
member.summary: Indicates that this layout class can use a link connection box provider to calculate the end points of links.
member.remarks:
The link connection box provider is an object that provides the rectangle to which the links are connected for each node and the tangential shift offset at each side for the connection points. This is useful if the connection points of the links at a node should be relative to a rectangle that is smaller or larger than the real bounding box of the node.
Link connection points are not calculated for links that have the no-reshape link style, that are fixed, or that are not tree links. Only the connection points of reshapeable tree links are calculated.
If a connection box provider object is set at the property , the layout algorithm uses this object together with the connector style to calculate the connection points for links.
If the link clip mode is set additionally, the layout algorithm calculates the initial connection points at the node boxes with the link connection box provider and the connector style and tells the graph model to obtain the final connection points by clipping against the shape of the nodes via the reshape mode of . This works well particularly if the node box obtained by the link connection box provider is smaller than the real bounding box of the node.
member.returns: Always .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.SetAspectRatio(ILOG.Diagrammer.Rectangle2D)
member.summary: Sets the aspect ratio for the layout from a given rectangle.
member.remarks: This can be useful if the graph contains just one single tree and should be fit into the input rectangle.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.SetAspectRatio(ILOG.Diagrammer.IDiagramView)
member.summary: Sets the aspect ratio for the layout from a given view.
member.remarks: This can be useful if the graph contains just one single tree and should be fit into the input view.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.SetLinkStyle(System.Object,ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutLinkStyle)
member.summary: Sets the style of the shape of an individual link.
member.remarks:
This link style is used only if the global link style is set to and the link is part of the spanning tree. If the global link style is not , all links of the spanning tree have the style that is specified as the global link style. Links that are not part of the spanning tree have the link style .
Valid values are:
- the link has an orthogonal shape, that is, a shape consisting of a sequence of orthogonal line segments. This option is not available for the radial layout modes.
- the link has a straight-line shape.
- no reshape is performed on the link.
The default value is .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.GetLinkStyle(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the style of the shape of an individual link.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.SetEastWestNeighboring(System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Creates an east-west neighboring of two nodes.
member.remarks:
The is placed as the first neighbor on the same level to the west of the . This implies, conversely, that the is the first neighbor on the same level to the east of the .
For instance, in free layout mode and with the flow direction towards the bottom, the east node is placed as the immediate neighbor to the right of the west node at approximately the same y coordinate. A link between both nodes is routed as a straight horizontal line between both nodes. In radial layout mode, the east node is placed as the immediate neighbor in the same circle as the west node. A link between both nodes is routed tangentially to the node circle as a straight line.
Note that each node can have at most one east neighbor and one west neighbor. For technical reasons, children of tip-over alignments have special area requirements, and, therefore, they can have a west neighbor but not an east neighbor. This means that if the parent node of the has tip-over alignment, the east-west neighboring is ignored. Similarly, children of tip-over-both-sides alignments cannot have an east neighbor or a west neighbor.
East-west neighboring is possible even though there is no link between both nodes. The layout algorithm considers both nodes as if they were conceptually connected by a link.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.SetWestEastNeighboring(System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Creates an east-west neighboring of two nodes.
member.remarks:
The is placed as the first neighbor on the same level to the west of the . This implies, conversely, that the is the first neighbor on the same level to the east of the .
This method is identical to with a reversed argument order, and is provided for convenience. Note that, for instance, when the flow direction is towards the bottom, east is to the right of west, and therefore resembles more the argument order of SetWestEastNeighboring. When the flow direction is towards the top, east is to the left of west, and therefore resembles more the argument order of SetEastWestNeighboring.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.GetEastNeighbor(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the specified east neighbor node of the input node, or if none was specified.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.GetWestNeighbor(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the specified west neighbor node of the input node, or if none was specified.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.SetRoot(System.Object)
member.summary: Allows you to specify the root(s) of the tree.
member.remarks:
If more than one connected component exists, it is possible to select a root for each component. If no root is specified, an appropriate node is automatically selected as root. For a directed tree, the canonical root node with degree 0 is selected unless otherwise specified.
Setting the root node by this method is identical to setting the root preference of this node to 10000.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.GetSpecRoots
member.summary: Returns the nodes that were specified as root.
member.remarks: Note that this does not necessarily mean that these nodes are selected as real roots, because the specification may have conflicts (for example, each connected component can only have one root, thus specifying two roots for the same connected component causes a conflict). To retrieve the nodes that were really used as roots during the layout, call the method .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.IsSpecRoot(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns if the input node was specified as root.
member.remarks: Note that this does not necessarily mean that this node is selected as real root, because the specification may have conflicts (for example, each connected component can only have one root, thus specifying two roots for the same connected component causes a conflict). To check whether the node was really used as root during the layout, call the method .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.GetCalcRoots
member.summary: Returns the nodes that were used as roots during layout.
member.remarks: This can be called after the layout. If more than one connected component exists, each component has a root. If no root was specified, the layout algorithm automatically selects an appropriate node. If too many roots were specified, some specified roots will not become calculated roots during layout.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.IsCalcRoot(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns if the input node was used as root during layout.
member.remarks: This can be called after the layout. If more than one connected component exists, each component has a root. If no root was specified, the layout algorithm automatically selects an appropriate node. If too many roots were specified, some specified roots will not become calculated roots during layout.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.SetRootPreference(System.Object,System.Int32)
member.summary: Specifies the preference of the node to become root node.
member.remarks:
The higher the preference, the more likely the node will be selected as root node.
If a negative value is passed as input, the preference of the node is unspecified. In this case, the algorithm calculates a preference so that for directed trees the canonical root nodes with degree 0 have the highest preference.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.GetRootPreference(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the specified preference of the node to become root node.
member.remarks: The higher the preference, the more likely the node will be selected as root node. If no preference is specified for the node, it returns -1.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.SetPosition(ILOG.Diagrammer.Point2D,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets the position of the layout.
member.remarks:
This can be used if connected component processing is disabled, or if the graph is fully connected. It has no effect otherwise.
If no position is specified, the layout algorithm keeps the position of the first root node unchanged.
member.param: If , it specifies the position of the first root node. This is useful in incremental mode. If , it specifies the position of the top-left border of the layout.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.GetCalcForwardTreeLinks
member.summary: Returns the forward links that were used as part of the spanning tree during the layout.
member.remarks:
This can be called after the layout if the link categorization option was set to before the layout by the property .
The forward tree links have the property that the "from" node is the parent of the "to" node in the tree layout. These links are reshaped by the layout algorithm.
If the graph was not a tree, some links will not be part of the spanning tree that forms the base structure for the layout. If the graph was not a directed tree, some links need to be reversed to form the spanning tree. These links are not part of this enumeration.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.GetCalcBackwardTreeLinks
member.summary: Returns the backward links that were used in the reverse direction as part of the spanning tree during layout.
member.remarks:
This can be called after the layout if the link categorization option was set to before the layout by the property .
The backward tree links have the property that the "to" node is the parent of the "from" node in the tree layout. These links are reshaped by the layout algorithm.
If the graph was not a tree, some links will not be part of the spanning tree that forms the base structure for the layout. These links are not part of this enumeration. Also, the links that need not to be reversed but form the spanning tree are not part of this enumeration.

members.member:
Returns the links that were neither forward nor backward links in the spanning tree during layout.
This can be called after the layout if the link categorization option was set to before the layout by the property .
The non-tree tree links have the property that neither the "from" node is the parent of the "to" node nor the "to" node is the parent of the "from" node in the tree layout. These links are not reshaped by the layout algorithm.
If the graph was not a tree, some links will not be part of the spanning tree that forms the base structure for the layout. Only these links are part of this enumeration. If necessary, they can be treated by a link routing layout algorithm after the tree layout (for example, by ).
Note that links that are removed by a layout filter, and links that are specified as fixed links or that are adjacent to fixed nodes, are not part of this enumeration even though they are also not part of the spanning tree.
'/>

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.SetAlignment(System.Object,ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayoutAlignment)
member.summary: Sets the alignment option of an individual node.
member.remarks:
This alignment option is used only if the global alignment is set to . Otherwise, all nodes have the alignment that is specified as the global alignment.
Valid values are:
- the node is centered with respect to the centers of its children.
- the node is centered with respect to the border of its children.
- the node is aligned to the border of its easternmost child.
- the node is aligned to the border of its westernmost child.
- a parent is outside the border of the children, while the children are placed sequentially instead of in parallel.
- similar to but the children are arranged in pairs at both sides of the link segment that starts at the parent node. This alignment option is not possible in the radial or level layout modes.
The default value is .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.GetAlignment(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the local alignment option of the node.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.OnLayoutStepPerformed(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Fires a graph layout LayoutStepPerformed event.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.OnConstraintsChanged
member.summary: Invoked when the content of the property change.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.LinkStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the global style of the shapes of links.
member.remarks:
Valid values are:
- all links have an orthogonal shape, that is, a shape consisting of a sequence of orthogonal line segments. This option is not available for the radial layout modes.
- all links have a straight-line shape.
- no reshape is performed on any link.
- each link can have a different link style. The style of each individual link can be set by the method so that different link shapes can occur in the same graph.
Unless the global link style is , all links have the same shape style.
The default value is .
member.value: The global style of the shapes of links.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.ConnectorStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the style of the connectors.
member.remarks:
Valid values are:
- the link connection points are placed in the center of the border of the node bounding box to which the link is attached.
- each link pointing to the center of the node is clipped at the bounding box of the node. This style affects straight links; it behaves like centered connection points for orthogonal links.
- the link connection points are evenly spaced along the border of the node bounding box.
- the connector style is selected depending on the link style.
The default value is .
The connector style is ignored in the radial layout modes because clipped pins are always used in this case. The placement of connection points also depends on the link clip interface and the connection box interface, in the following way:
First, the bounding box of an end node is obtained. If a link connection box interface was set via , the bounding box and offsets are delivered by that interface. Otherwise, the node bounding box delivered by the graph model (see ) is used.
Next, the initial connection point of the link is placed at this bounding box in the manner specified by the connector style.
Finally, if the link clip mode was set via , the layout tells the graph model to obtain the final connection points by clipping against the shape of the nodes via the reshape mode of .
member.value: The style of the connectors.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.FlowDirection
member.summary: Gets or sets the direction of the flow.
member.remarks:
Valid values are:
- the root is on the left and the links flow to the right.
- the root is on the right and the links flow to the left.
- the root is at the top and the links flow to the bottom.
- the root is at the bottom and the links flow to the top.
Note that except for the radial layout modes, the compass direction is identical to the flow direction.
In the radial layout modes, all links flow radially from the center of the root outward. If connected component processing is disabled, the flow direction affects only the arrangement of disconnected trees in the radial modes.
The default value is .
member.value: The direction of the flow.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.LayoutMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the layout mode.
member.remarks:
Valid values are:
- all links flow roughly in the flow direction. Nodes of different tree branches (that is, nodes with a different parent node) are not justified to each other; therefore, the level alignment parameter is ignored. Tip-over alignment is possible if specified as alignment. All link styles are possible. The aspect ratio is ignored.
- all links flow roughly in the flow direction. Nodes are organized in levels and are justified to their borders or centered according to the level alignment parameter. Tip-over alignment is not possible, but all link styles are possible. The aspect ratio is ignored.
- similar to the mode . However, in mode , the algorithm tries to optimize the layout to automatically fit best to the specified aspect ratio. Using a fast heuristic, it chooses the local alignment for some nodes but keeps the alignment of all other nodes as specified. This heuristic is a fast compromise between the modes , , and .
- similar to the mode . The algorithm tries to optimize the layout to automatically fit best to the specified aspect ratio. This slow heuristic tries to tip over beginning with the leaves and then chooses the best layout. It checks the alignment mode , but not . It keeps the alignment of all nodes close to the root as specified.
- similar to the mode . The algorithm tries to optimize the layout to automatically fit best to the specified aspect ratio. This slow heuristic tries to tip over beginning with the roots and then chooses the best layout. It checks the alignment mode , but not . It keeps the alignment of all nodes close to the leaves as specified.
- similar to the mode . The algorithm tries to optimize the layout to automatically fit best to the specified aspect ratio. This slow heuristic tries to tip over beginning with the roots and with the leaves, and then chooses the best layout. It checks the alignment mode , but not . It keeps the alignment of all nodes in the middle between roots and leaves as specified.
- the root node is in the center, the links flow radially away from the center, and the nodes are placed in circular layers around the root node according to the level alignment. Tip-over alignment and orthogonal link styles are not possible. Clipped connection points are used as the connector style. If an aspect ratio is specified, the layers are ellipses around the center.
- this is the same as mode , with the exception that children of the same node are placed alternating in different circular layers when this results in a smaller radius and better usage of the space. Tip-over alignment and orthogonal link styles are not possible. Clipped connection points are used as the connector style. If an aspect ratio is specified, the layers are ellipses around the center.
The default value is .
Note that the tip-over layout modes work best if the node sizes are respected during layout.
member.value: The layout mode.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.IncrementalMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the incremental mode.

remarks.p: If the incremental mode is enabled, the algorithm tries to preserve the relative order of the children on incremental changes. The logical order of children of nodes in the tree is calculated from their coordinates. In this case, the layout is stable when incremental changes are made. If nodes are added or removed after a layout, the next layout uses a heuristic to try to adjust the layout only minimally and to avoid major structural reorganization.
If the incremental mode is disabled, the algorithm calculates the logical order of children of nodes in the tree by using the order in which nodes are returned by .
The incremental mode is enabled by default.

member.value: The incremental mode.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.AllLevelsAlternating
member.summary: Gets or sets whether at all levels, nodes are forced into alternating circular layers.

remarks.p: This option has only an effect in layout mode . Alternating placement means that the nodes of one level are placed alternating in two circular layers. Nonalternating placement means that the nodes of one level are placed in one circular layer. Normally, the layout analyses which levels must use the alternating placement in order to optimize space. If the alternating placement of a level does not improve the space usage, the nonalternating placement is used for the level even in alternating radial layout mode.
This option allows to change this behavior: if the option is enabled, all levels use the alternating placement even if the alternating placement uses more space than the nonalternating placement.
The option is disabled by default.

member.value: Whether at all levels, nodes are forced into alternating circular layers.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.RespectNodeSizes
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the algorithm must try to respect the size of the nodes.
member.remarks:
If the argument is , the spacing parameters are interpreted as the minimum distance between the node borders. If the argument is , the spacing parameters are interpreted as the minimum distance between the node centers.
If respecting node sizes is disabled, the level alignment option has no effect.
This is an expert option. The default is . It makes sense to switch this option off only if all nodes already have approximately the same size and the spacing parameters are larger than the largest node. If the option is switched off, large nodes may otherwise overlap. In particular, it is recommended keeping the option enabled if orthogonal links are used.
member.value: Whether the algorithm must try to respect the size of the nodes.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.LevelAlignment
member.summary: Gets or sets the alignment within the levels.
member.remarks:
Valid values are:
This feature sets the alignment of the nodes within each level. It can be used in layout modes , , and . It has an effect only if the respect node sizes option is enabled.
If the nodes are center-justified, all nodes of the same level are placed with their centers along a line. Otherwise, all nodes of the same level are placed with the specified border justified to a line. For instance, if the link flow direction is to the right, the alignment means that the nodes are justified to the left and the alignment means that the nodes are justified to the right.
In the radial layout modes, the alignment means that the nodes are aligned along a circle with the border that is closer to the root, and the alignment means that the nodes are aligned along a circle with the border that is farther away from the root.
The default value is .
member.value: The alignment within the levels.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.Alignment
member.summary: Gets or sets the global alignment option.
member.remarks:
Valid values are:
- a parent is centered above its children, taking the center of the children into account.
- a parent is centered above its children, taking the border of the children into account. This differs from the alignment if the respect node sizes option is enabled.
- a parent is aligned to the border of its easternmost child.
- a parent is aligned to the border of its westernmost child.
- a parent is outside the border of the children, while the children are placed sequentially instead of in parallel. This alignment option is not possible in the radial or level layout modes.
- similar to , but the children are arranged in pairs at both sides of the link segment that starts at the parent node. This alignment option is not possible in the radial or level layout modes.
- each node can have a different alignment option. The alignment of each individual node can be set by the method so that different alignments can occur in the same graph.
The default value is .
member.value: The global alignment option.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.SiblingOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimal offset between siblings, that is, between nodes that have the same parent in the tree structure.

remarks.p: If the flow direction is towards the top or bottom and the layout mode is not radial, this is a horizontal offset. If the flow direction is towards the left or right and the layout mode is not radial, this is a vertical offset. If the layout mode is radial, this is an offset tangential to the circles or ellipses.
If the respect node sizes option is enabled, this is the minimal offset between node borders; otherwise, it is the minimal offset between node centers.
The default value is 40.

member.value: The minimal offset between siblings, that is, between nodes that have the same parent in the tree structure.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.ParentChildOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimal offset between a parent and its children.

remarks.p: If the flow direction is towards the top or bottom and the layout mode is not radial, this is a vertical offset. If the flow direction is towards the left or right and the layout mode is not radial, this is a horizontal offset. If the layout mode is radial, this is an offset radial to the circle or ellipses.
If the respect node sizes option is enabled, this is the minimal offset between node borders; otherwise, it is the minimal offset between node centers.
The default value is 40.

member.value: The minimal offset between a parent and its children.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.BranchOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimal offset between neighbor nodes that belong to different branches in the tree.
member.remarks:
This is the offset between neighbor nodes that are not siblings. The offset is in the opposite direction of the link flow.
If the flow direction is towards the top or bottom and the layout mode is not radial, this is a horizontal offset. If the flow direction is towards the left or right and the layout mode is not radial, this is a vertical offset. If the layout mode is radial, this is an offset tangential to the circles or ellipses.
If the respect node sizes option is enabled, this is the minimal offset between node borders; otherwise, it is the minimal offset between node centers.
The default value is 40.
member.value: The minimal offset between neighbor nodes that belong to different branches in the tree.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.TipOverBranchOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimal offset in the flow direction between neighbor nodes that belong to different branches in the tree.
member.remarks:
This offset is used to separate the branches if their common parent node has tip-over alignment. It has no effect if the layout mode is radial or if no tip-over alignment occurs.
If the flow direction is towards the top or bottom, this is a vertical offset. If the flow direction is towards the left or right, this is a horizontal offset.
If the respect node sizes option is enabled, this is the minimal offset between node borders; otherwise, it is the minimal offset between node centers.
The default value is 40.
member.value: The minimal offset in the flow direction between neighbor nodes that belong to different branches in the tree.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.AspectRatio
member.summary: Gets or sets the aspect ratio for the layout.
member.remarks:
This is the ratio width / height of the desired layout region.
The effect of the aspect ratio depends on the layout mode:
In layout modes and , the nodes are placed in circular layers if the aspect ratio is 1. Otherwise, they are placed in elliptical layers.
In layout modes , , , and , the nodes are placed as in in free mode, but local tip-over alignments are automatically added to better fit the layout to the aspect ratio.
The aspect ratio has no effect in other layout modes.
member.value: The aspect ratio for the layout.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.OverlapPercentage
member.summary: Gets or sets the percentage for which a node is considered smaller in the flow direction.
member.remarks:
This allows nodes to be placed closer together. However, in layout modes , , , , and , outgoing links of a node may, in rare cases, cross the neighbor leaf nodes if the overlap percentage is high. To avoid this, set the parameter to 0%.
The default value is 30%, which is a good compromise for many graphs between wasting space and the risk of having links cross nodes.
This is an expert option. In all normal cases, it is not necessary to change the option. It is recommended choosing an orthogonal fork percentage that is always larger than the overlap percentage to obtain a good layout.
This option has no effect if the respect node sizes option is disabled.
member.value: The percentage for which a node is considered smaller in the flow direction.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.MaxChildrenAngle
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximal angle for children that are placed in radial mode.
member.remarks:
This is the maximal angle between the two rays from the parent to its two outermost children. The angle must be between 0 and 360 degrees. The angle 0 means that the angle is unspecified,
The default value is 0.
In radial mode, children of a single node may cover nearly completely one circular layer. This sometime appears to be unbalanced, in particular because the links from the node to its outermost children are likely to cross other nodes. To avoid this effect, a maximal angle can be specified so that the children are placed more in the same direction and are not spread too widely around the parent. This angular restriction is applied to all children except the children of the root node. As a side effect, specifying a small maximal children angle enlarges the radius of the circles.
It is recommended choosing a value between 30 and 180 degrees for good results. The algorithm uses a heuristic that has precision deviations below 30 degrees and above 180 degrees. If an aspect ratio is specified, the layout algorithm uses ellipses instead of circles. In this case, precision deviations may occur as well.
This is an expert option. It has no effect in layout modes other than radial.
member.value: The maximal angle for children that are placed in radial mode.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.FirstCircleEvenlySpacing
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the nodes on the first circle must be evenly spaced in radial mode.

remarks.p: By default, all nodes are placed as close as possible according to the offset parameters. In radial mode, this may cause the first circle to be only partially filled (that is, all nodes are placed close together at one part of the circle and there is a larger gap in another part of the circle).

To avoid this effect, you can enable the evenly spacing of the first circle. In this case, the children of the root node are placed such that their centers are approximately evenly spaced on the first circle, filling the entire circle. This may, however, cause the final result to waste much more space on the other circles.
It is disabled by default.
This is an expert option. It has no effect in layout modes other than radial. If there is east-west neighboring of the nodes in the first circle, these neighbors will not be equally spaced.

member.value: Whether the nodes on the first circle must be evenly spaced in radial mode.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.OrthForkPercentage
member.summary: Gets or sets the percentage of the parent-child offset that determines the location where the orthogonal link routing places the bends in order to fork the routing towards the children.
member.remarks:
This has an effect only if the orthogonal link style is chosen.
The default value is 45%.
This is an expert option. In all normal cases, it is not necessary to change the option. It is recommended choosing an orthogonal fork percentage that is always larger than the overlap percentage to obtain a good layout.
member.value: The percentage of the parent-child offset that determines the location where the orthogonal link routing places the bends in order to fork the routing towards the children.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.Position
member.summary: Gets or sets the position of the layout.
member.remarks:
This can be used if connected component processing is disabled, or if the graph is fully connected. It has no effect otherwise.
The meaning of the position depends on the flag . If the flag is , it specifies the position of the first root node. This is useful in incremental mode. If the flag is , it specifies the position of the top-left border of the layout.
If no position is specified, the layout algorithm keeps the position of the first root node unchanged.
member.value: The position of the layout.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.RootPosition
member.summary: Gets or sets the meaning of the specified position.
member.remarks: The specified position is the one that can be obtained from . If passed the specified position means the position of the root node. Otherwise, it means the position of the top-left border of the layout. This can be used if connected component processing is disabled, or if the graph is fully connected. It has no effect otherwise.
member.value: The meaning of the specified position.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.InvisibleRootUsed
member.summary: Gets or sets whether an invisible root is used to combine components that are disconnected from each other.
member.remarks:
The roots that are specified by or are the roots of each individual component. If an invisible root is used, all roots of each individual component are added as children to an invisible dummy node and the layout is performed on the resulting connected graph. By doing this, the components are arranged in the same global structure. In particular, this is useful for the radial layout modes to fit all components into the same global circular layer structure instead of generating an individual circular layer structure for each component.
Note that the layout is no longer stable on incremental changes if an invisible root is used. The layout heuristic cannot preserve the relative order of the components in this case. This means that the order of the components may change in subsequent layouts, and hence the next layout may look very different from the previous layout.
The default value is .
member.value: Whether an invisible root is used to combine components that are disconnected from each other.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.TreeLayout.CategorizingLinks
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the layout algorithm stores the categorization of links into forward, backward, and non-tree links.
member.remarks:
If , the next run of the layout algorithm makes the link categorization available through the methods , , and . If , the link categorization is not made available. This saves memory and is faster. In this case, the methods , , and will return empty enumerations.
The default value is .
member.value: Whether the layout algorithm stores the categorization of links into forward, backward, and non-tree links.

members.member:
Gets or sets whether all non-tree links that don't have the no-reshape link style and that are not fixed and are not incident to fixed nodes are reshaped to be straight.
Otherwise, the non-tree links are not changed at all.
This option is disabled by default. When disabled, the tree layout only routes the links of the spanning tree, but no other link. When enabled, the tree layout iterates over the links obtained by and makes them straight.
It obeys the link clip interface and the link connection box interface when making the non-tree links straight. The tree layout can only obey the link style and the connector style of the tree links but not of the non-tree links. In particular, it is not able to route non-tree links orthogonally. Only tree-links can be routed orthogonally. Usually it is recommended to apply an additional link layout to the non-tree links if there are any. However, if the non-tree links should just be straight, this option comes in handy since an additional link layout can be omitted in this case.
'/>
Whether all non-tree links that don't have the no-reshape link style and that are not fixed and are not incident to fixed nodes are reshaped to be straight.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Rect
member.summary: Represents a graphic object that displays a rectangle.
member.remarks: A object is a graphic object that displays a rectangle. The property defines the geometry of objects. The rectangle can be drawn with round corners through the property.

example.para: The following sample creates a light blue rounded rectangle with a black border.
example.code: Function CreateRect() As Rect Dim rect As Rect = New Rect(0, 0, 100, 100) rect.Radius = New Size2D(10, 10) rect.Fill = New SolidFill(Color.LightBlue) rect.Stroke = New Stroke(Color.Black, 2) Return rect End Function

example.code: Function CreateLine() As Line Dim line As Line = New Line line.StartPoint = New Point2D(100, 100) line.EndPoint = New Point2D(200, 200) line.Stroke = New Stroke(Color.Black, 2, DashStyle.Dash) Return line End Function

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.EdgeMode
member.summary: Defines the edge mode for the filter.
member.remarks: Use the value of this enumeration to define the edge mode for the convolution in the property of the class.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.EdgeMode.Duplicate
member.summary: Indicates that the input image is extended along each of its borders as necessary by duplicating the color values at the given edge of the input image.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.EdgeMode.Wrap
member.summary: Indicates that the input image is extended by taking the color values from the opposite edge of the image.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.EdgeMode.None
member.summary: Indicates that the input image is extended with pixel values of zero for R, G, B and A.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeConvolveMatrix
member.summary: Defines a matrix convolution filter effect.
member.remarks: A convolution combines pixels in the input image with neighboring pixels to produce a resulting image. A wide variety of imaging operations can be achieved through convolutions, including blurring, edge detection, sharpening, embossing and beveling.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeConvolveMatrix.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new filter effect.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeConvolveMatrix.#ctor(ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.Kernel)
member.summary: Initializes a new filter effect with the specified kernel.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeConvolveMatrix.#ctor(ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.Kernel,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Initializes a new filter effect with the specified kernel, divisor and bias.

member.summary: Initializes a new from serialization information.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeConvolveMatrix.Clone
member.summary: Creates a copy of the filter effect.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeConvolveMatrix.ToString
member.summary: Returns a short description of this filter effect.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeConvolveMatrix.Kernel
member.summary: Gets or sets the kernel matrix.
member.value: A object that represents the kernel matrix of the convolution.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeConvolveMatrix.Divisor
member.summary: Gets or sets the divisor of the convolve operation.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeConvolveMatrix.Bias
member.summary: Gets or sets the bias of the convolve operation.
member.value: After applying the kernel matrix to the input image to yield a number and applying the divisor, the bias attribute is added to each component. One application of bias is when it is desirable to have .5 gray value be the zero response of the filter. The default value is zero.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeConvolveMatrix.EdgeMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the edge mode that determines how to extend the input image as necessary with color values so that the matrix operations can be applied when the kernel is positioned at or near the edge of the input image.
member.value: One of the values that determines how to extend the input image as necessary with color values so that the matrix operations can be applied when the kernel is positioned at or near the edge of the input image. The default value is .

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeConvolveMatrix.PreserveAlpha
member.summary: Indicates whether the convolution preserve the alpha channel or not.
member.value: A value of indicates that the convolution will apply to all channels, including the alpha channel. A value of indicates that the convolution will only apply to the color channels. In this case, the filter will temporarily unpremultiply the color component values, apply the kernel, and then re-premultiply at the end.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeConvolveMatrix.Inputs
member.summary: This member overrides FilterEffect.Inputs

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeConvolveMatrix.In
member.summary: Gets or sets the source of this filter effect.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.Internal.GraphModelUtil.GetPointAt(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel,System.Object,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the point of a link at a specified index.
member.remarks: Returns the point of a link at a specified index. The values of indexes start from zero, which must correspond to the connection point of the link on its origin node. The last point on the link must correspond to the connection point of the link on its destination node. The method must work for normal links and intergraph links.
member.param: The index of the bend or connection point of the link.

member.summary: Reshapes the points of a link.

member.summary: Returns the points of a link as InternalPoint.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.Internal.GraphModelUtil.GetNodesAndLinks(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel)
member.summary: Returns the nodes and links of the graph model.
member.remarks: Returns the nodes and links of the graph model. Modifying the resulting collection does not modify the graph model.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.Internal.GraphModelUtil.GetLinks(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel,System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the links incident to a node of the graph model.
member.remarks: Returns the links incident to a node of the graph model. These are those links that have as origin or destination the input node. Modifying the resulting collection does not modify the graph model.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.Internal.GraphModelUtil.GetNeighbors(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel,System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the neighbor nodes of a node.
member.remarks:
Returns the neighbor nodes of a node. These are the nodes that have a common normal link with . This method does not consider intergraph links.
In the case where a link that is incident to is a self-link (that is, a link whose origin and destination are the same node), the result does not contain .
In the case of multiple links between and one of its neighbors, the neighbor is contained in the result the number of times equal to the number of links.
Modifying the resulting collection does not modify the graph model.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.Internal.GraphModelUtil.GetNodeDegree(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel,System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the node degree.
member.remarks: Returns the node degree. This is the number of neighbors of the . However, if a node is multiple times a neighbor, it is counted only once.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.Internal.GraphModelUtil.GetOpposite(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel,System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the opposite node on a link.
member.remarks: Returns the opposite node on a link. This method works for intergraph links as well. Notice that for intergraph links, the input node and the returned node may not be nodes of this graph model (that is, may return ).
member.returns: The other end node.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.Internal.GraphModelUtil.IsLinkBetween(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel,System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Tests whether a normal link exists between two nodes.
member.remarks: Tests whether a normal link exists between two nodes. The method does not check for intergraph links.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LinkLayoutLinkStyle
member.summary: Defines the link style options for the link layout algorithms.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LinkLayoutLinkStyle.Orthogonal
member.summary: Orthogonal link style.
member.remarks: In this style, the links have an orthogonal shape, that is, a shape consisting of a sequence of alternating horizontal and vertical line segments. This style can be used as global mode affecting all links, or as local mode affecting only individual links.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LinkLayoutLinkStyle.Direct
member.summary: Direct link style.
member.remarks: In this style, the links get a nearly straight-line shape. The shape of the links is a polyline composed of a straight-line segment between the end nodes with two short horizontal or vertical segments at its ends. This style can be used as global mode affecting all links, or as local mode affecting only individual links.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LinkLayoutLinkStyle.Mixed
member.summary: Mixed link style.
member.remarks: In this style, each link can have a different link style.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LinkLayoutLinkStyle.NoReshape
member.summary: No reshape style.
member.remarks: In this style, the link is not reshaped.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.RandomLayout
member.summary: The main class for the Random Layout algorithm.

remarks.p: This is the simplest layout algorithm. The nodes are moved at randomly computed positions inside a user-defined region which can be specified by the property .
Sample drawing produced by the Random Layout algorithm:
See the corresponding chapter of the User's Manual for details on the algorithm, the types of graphs for which this algorithm can be used, the features and limitations, code samples, and so on.

Note that the initial position of the nodes (at the moment you start the layout) does not affect the resulting layout. However, nodes specified as fixed are not moved if you set the property
to .

example.para: The following example shows how to apply the Random Layout.
example.code:
Imports System Imports ILOG.Diagrammer Imports ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic Imports ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout
Dim group As Group = New Group
' Fill the group with nodes and links here
Dim layout As RandomLayout = New RandomLayout group.GraphLayout = layout group.PerformGraphLayout

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.RandomLayout.Copy
member.summary: Copies the layout instance.

remarks.p: This method copies the layout instance by calling the copy constructor.
When performing a recursive layout on a nested graph, this method is used by to "clone" the layout instance of a parent graph.

Note that the parameters which are specific to a node or a link are not copied. The other parameters, including the layout region specification and the link clip and link connection box interfaces, are also copied.
If a method of the type SupportsXXX is associated with a parameter, the parameter is copied only if the corresponding method returns .

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout
member.summary: The main class for the Grid Layout algorithm.

remarks.p: The Grid Layout algorithm has two major modes: grid and row/column. (For details, see the property .) In grid mode, the layout arranges the nodes of a graph in the cells of a grid (matrix). If a node is too large to fit into one grid cell (with a margin), it occupies multiple cells. The size of the grid cells can be specified using the properties and . The margins can be specified using the properties , , , and .

The following sample drawing shows a layout in the grid mode where the grid size has been specified so that each node fits into one grid cell. (Usually such layouts are more esthetic and appear to be more regular, but a larger area is left empty around the smallest nodes. This is generally the best option when all the nodes have the same size.)
The following sample drawing shows a layout in the grid mode where the grid size has been specified so that some nodes fit into one grid cell and other nodes occupy multiple cells. (Usually such layouts take less space if the nodes have a heterogeneous size.)
The following diagram shows the dimensional parameters of the layout in grid mode.

In row/column mode, the layout arranges the nodes of a graph either by rows or by columns (according to the specified option). The width of the rows is controlled by the width of the layout region parameter. The height of the columns is controlled by the height of the layout region parameter. The margins can be specified using the properties , , , and . The minimum horizontal distance between nodes is equal to the sum of the left and right margins. The minimum vertical distance between nodes is equal to the sum of the top and bottom margins.
For graphs with nodes of heterogeneous size, the row/column mode often allows a more compact layout than the grid mode.

The following sample drawing shows a layout in the row mode.
The following sample drawing shows a layout in the column mode.
The following diagram shows the dimensional parameters of the layout in row mode (the parameters for the column mode are analogous).
The algorithm is primarily designed for graphs without (visible) links between the nodes. If links exist, they are ignored by the Grid layout.

An incremental mode is provided (see ). If the incremental mode is enabled, the stability of the layout is preserved as much as possible when new nodes are added, existing ones removed, or node sizes modified. This means that the nodes are placed at the same location, or in the same order, as in the previous layout whenever possible. In this mode, the layout algorithm processes the changes incrementally rather than redoing the entire layout for every change.

Nodes that the layout algorithm is not allowed to move can be specified using the method . (See also .) In grid mode, nonfixed nodes are placed in such a way that they do not overlap the grid cells occupied by other fixed or nonfixed nodes. In row/column mode, nonfixed nodes are placed in such a way that they do not overlap fixed or nonfixed nodes. Of course, fixed nodes can overlap other fixed nodes.

The layout algorithm can take into account a different node size than the size corresponding to the bounding box of the node. Using , you can specify an object that provides the box that has to be taken into account for each node. The following diagram shows the dimensional parameters of the layout in grid mode (the row/column case mode is analogous) when a node box that is different from the bounding box of the node is used:

example.para: The following example shows how to apply the Grid Layout.
example.code:
Imports System Imports ILOG.Diagrammer Imports ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic Imports ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout
Dim group As Group = New Group
' Fill the group with nodes here
Dim layout As GridLayout = New GridLayout group.GraphLayout = layout group.PerformGraphLayout

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.NoIndex
member.summary: No index code.
member.remarks: This value is returned by the method when a node has no index value.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.AutomaticOrdering
member.summary: Automatic ordering option.
member.remarks: When set to , the algorithm is free to choose the order in such a way that it tries to reduce the total area occupied by the layout.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.NoOrdering
member.summary: No ordering option.
member.remarks: When set to , the nodes are arranged in an arbitrary order.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.DescendingHeight
member.summary: Ordering by height option.
member.remarks: When set to , the nodes are arranged by height, starting at the upper-left corner with the tallest node. Ordering the nodes by height can save vertical space and produce a more compact layout.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.AscendingHeight
member.summary: Ordering by ascending height option.
member.remarks: When set to , the nodes are arranged by ascending height, starting at the upper-left corner with the node of the smallest height. Ordering the nodes by height can save vertical space and produce a more compact layout.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.AscendingWidth
member.summary: Ordering by ascending width option.
member.remarks: When set to , the nodes are arranged by ascending width, starting at the upper-left corner with the node of the smallest width.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.DescendingWidth
member.summary: Ordering by descending width option.
member.remarks: When set to , the nodes are arranged by width, starting at the upper-left corner with the node of the highest width.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.AscendingArea
member.summary: Ordering by ascending area option.
member.remarks: When set to , the nodes are arranged by ascending area, starting at the upper-left corner with the node of the smallest area.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.DescendingArea
member.summary: Ordering by descending area option.
member.remarks: When set to , the nodes are arranged by area, starting at the upper-left corner with the node of the highest area.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.AscendingIndex
member.summary: Ordering by ascending index option.
member.remarks: When set to , the nodes are arranged in the order of their indexes, starting at the upper-left corner with the node with the smallest index. Nodes that do not have an index are placed after the nodes for which an index is specified. Ordering by index allows you to specify a particular order for the nodes.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.DescendingIndex
member.summary: Ordering by descending index option.
member.remarks: When set to , the nodes are arranged in the order of their indexes, starting at the upper-left corner with the node with the highest index. Nodes that do not have an index are placed after the nodes for which an index is specified. Ordering by index allows you to specify a particular order for the nodes.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.Detach
member.summary: Detaches the graph model from the layout instance.
member.remarks:
When you attach a new graph model to the layout instance, you do not need to detach the old graph model because this is done automatically when you call .
The method performs cleaning operations on the graph model. In addition to the cleaning operations in the base class, the Grid Layout algorithm removes the alignment specifications of individual nodes.
Note that you must call this method when you no longer need the layout instance. Otherwise, some objects may not be garbage collected.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.SupportsLayoutRegion
member.summary: Indicates that this layout class can control the size of the graph drawing to fit a user-defined region (a rectangle) or a user-defined view.

remarks.p: If the layout mode (see ) is , the width of the layout region determines the maximum width of the layout (the maximum number of columns).
If the layout mode is , the height of the layout region determines the maximum height of the layout (the maximum number of rows).
If the layout mode is , the width of the layout region determines the maximum width of the rows.
If the layout mode is , the height of the layout region determines the maximum height of the columns.

However, if the width of a node is larger than the maximum width of the layout or the height of the node is larger than the maximum height of the layout, the bounding box of the node will be placed partially out of the specified layout region.
In all layout modes, the coordinates of the top-left corner of the layout region determines the coordinates of the top-left border of the layout.

member.returns: always .

members.member:
Indicates that this layout class allows the user to specify fixed nodes.
Fixed nodes are not moved during the layout if the property
is set to . Nonfixed nodes are placed in such a manner that overlaps with fixed nodes are avoided.
'/> Always .

Indicates that this layout class can stop the layout computation in a proper manner when the user-defined allowed time is exceeded.
If the allowed time elapses before termination of the Grid Layout algorithm, the result code in the layout report is .
'/>
Always .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.SupportsStopImmediately
member.summary: Indicates that this layout class can control the current run by interrupting the run of the layout immediately.
member.remarks: If the algorithm is stopped before termination, the result code in the layout report is .
member.returns: Always .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.SetHorizontalAlignment(System.Object,ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayoutHorizontalAlignment)
member.summary: Sets the horizontal alignment style of an individual node.
member.remarks:
This alignment style is used only if the global horizontal alignment is set to . Otherwise, all nodes have the alignment style that is specified as the global alignment style.
The parameter controls the horizontal alignment of nodes either inside their grid cell if the layout mode (see ) is or , or inside the columnrs if the layout mode is .
This parameter is not used if the layout mode (see ) is .
Valid values are:
- the node is centered in its grid cell or column.
- the node is aligned to the left border of the cell or column.
- the node is aligned to the left border of the cell or column.
The default value is .

member.summary: Returns the local horizontal alignment style of the node.

member.summary: Sets the vertical alignment style of an individual node.
member.remarks:
This alignment style is used only if the global vertical alignment is set to . Otherwise, all nodes have the alignment style that is specified as the global alignment style.
The parameter controls the vertical alignment of nodes either inside their grid cell if the layout mode (see ) is or , or inside the rows if the layout mode is .
This parameter is not used if the layout mode (see ) is .
Valid values are:
- the node is centered in its grid cell or column.
- the node is aligned to the top border of the cell or column.
- the node is aligned to the bottom border of the cell or column.
The default value is .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.GetVerticalAlignment(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the local vertical alignment style of the node.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.SetIndex(System.Object,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the index of a node.
member.remarks:
When the layout is performed, the nodes for which indexes have been specified are arranged in the order corresponding to their index (starting in the upper-left corner with the smallest index). The nodes for which indexes have not been specified are arranged after them. You can specify the class field as an index value if you want to reset an index you previously specified.
Note that must not be negative. The values of the indexes for consecutive nodes are not necessarily consecutive. Only the order of the values is important.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.GetIndex(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the index associated with a node.
member.remarks: It returns if has no index.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.LayoutMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the layout mode.
member.remarks:
Valid values are:
- The nodes are placed in the cells of a grid (matrix) that has a fixed maximum number of columns. This number is equal to the width of the layout region parameter divided by the horizontal grid offset (see ).
- The nodes are placed in the cells of a grid (matrix) that has a fixed maximum number of rows. This number is equal to the height of the layout region parameter divided by the vertical grid offset (see ).
- The nodes are placed in rows. The maximum width of the rows is equal to the width of the layout region parameter. The height of each row is the maximum height of the nodes contained in the row (plus margins).
- The nodes are placed in columns. The maximum height of the columns is equal to the height of the layout region parameter. The width of each column is the maximum width of the nodes contained in the column (plus margins).
The default value is .
member.value: The layout mode.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.IncrementalMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the incremental mode.

remarks.p: If the incremental mode is enabled, the stability of the layout is preserved as much as possible when new nodes are added, existing ones removed, or node sizes modified. This means that the nodes are placed at the same location or in the same order as in the previous layout whenever possible. In this mode, the layout algorithm processes the changes incrementally rather than redoing the entire layout for every change.
To preserve the stability, the incremental mode can keep some regions free. Therefore, the total area of the layout can be larger than when nonincremental mode is used.

Note that the layout is redone from scratch after a change in one of the following parameters:
layout region
grid offset
layout mode
margins
The default value is (disabled).

member.value: The incremental mode.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.HorizontalAlignment
member.summary: Gets or sets the global horizontal alignment style.
member.remarks:
This property controls the horizontal alignment of nodes either inside their grid cell if the layout mode (see ) is or , or inside the columns if the layout mode is . This parameter is not used if the layout mode (see ) is .
Valid values are:
- the node is centered in its grid cell or column.
- the node is aligned to the left border of the cell or column.
- the node is aligned to the left border of the cell or column.
- each node can have a different alignment option. In this case, the horizontal alignment of each individual node can be set by the method
so that different alignments can occur in the same layout.
The default value is .
member.value: The global horizontal alignment style.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.VerticalAlignment
member.summary: Gets or sets the global vertical alignment style.
member.remarks:
This property controls the vertical alignment of nodes either inside their grid cell if the layout mode (see ) is or , or inside the rows if the layout mode is . This parameter is not used if the layout mode (see ) is .
Valid values are:
- the node is centered in its grid cell or column.
- the node is aligned to the top border of the cell or column.
- the node is aligned to the bottom border of the cell or column.
- each node can have a different alignment option. In this case, the vertical alignment of each individual node can be set by the method
so that different alignments can occur in the same layout.
The default value is .
member.value: The global vertical alignment style.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.NodeComparator
member.summary: Gets or sets the comparator used for sorting the nodes.
member.remarks:
The valid values are the following:
- The algorithm is free to choose the order in such a way that it tries to reduce the total area occupied by the layout.
- No ordering is performed.
- The nodes are ordered in the descending order of their height.
- The nodes are ordered in the ascending order of their height.
- The nodes are ordered in the descending order of their width.
- The nodes are ordered in the ascending order of their width.
- The nodes are ordered in the descending order of their area.
- The nodes are ordered in the ascending order of their area.
- The nodes are ordered in the ascending order of their index (see ).
- The nodes are ordered in the descending order of their index (see ).
- The nodes are ordered in an arbitrary way.
any other implementation of the interface - The nodes are ordered according to this custom comparator.
The default value is .
The ordering of the nodes starts at the upper-left corner.
Note that in incremental mode (see ) or when nodes are fixed (see ) the order of the nodes is not guaranteed to obey the comparator, since this specification competes with the other constraints.
Note also that, if the layout mode is or , the order options are applied only for nodes whose size (including margins) is smaller than the grid cell size (see and ).
member.value: The comparator used for sorting the nodes.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.HorizontalGridOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the spacing of the grid lines on the horizontal axis.

remarks.p: The default value is 40.
This parameter is not used if the layout mode (see ) is or .

member.value: The spacing of the grid lines on the horizontal axis.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.VerticalGridOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the spacing of the grid lines on the vertical axis.

remarks.p: The default value is 40.
