member.value: The spacing of the grid lines on the vertical axis.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.TopMargin
member.summary: Gets or sets the top margin parameter.

remarks.p: If the layout mode is or , the top margin is the minimum distance between the top border of a node (or its user-specified box - see ) and the top border of the grid cell.
If the layout mode is or , the minimum vertical distance between two nodes (or their user-specified boxes) is the sum of the top and bottom margins.
The default value is 5.

member.value: The top margin parameter.

remarks.p: If the layout mode is or , the bottom margin is the minimum distance between the bottom border of a node (or its user-specified box - see ) and the bottom border of the grid cell.
If the layout mode is or , the minimum vertical distance between two nodes (or their user-specified boxes) is the sum of the top and bottom margins.
The default value is 5.

member.value: The bottom margin parameter.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.LeftMargin
member.summary: Gets or sets the left margin parameter.

remarks.p: If the layout mode is or , the left margin is the minimum distance between the left border of a node (or its user-specified box - see ) and the left border of the grid cell.
If the layout mode is or , the minimum horizontal distance between two nodes (or their user-specified boxes) is the sum of the left and right margins.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GridLayout.MaxNumberOfNodesPerRowOrColumn
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of nodes per row or per column.

remarks.p: In mode, the number is the maximum number of nodes per row. In mode, the number is the maximum number of nodes per column.

The layout places as many nodes on each row or column as possible given the size of the nodes, the dimensional parameters (layout region and margins) and the specified maximum number of nodes per row or column.

The minimum value is 1. The default value is Int32.MaxValue, that is, the number of nodes placed in each row or column is bounded only by the size of the nodes and the dimensional parameters. The parameter has no effect if the layout mode is or .

member.value: The maximum number of nodes per row or per column.

The default value is . You can set this property with a argument to restore the default behavior.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.TextureImageXmlSerializer

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.TextureFill
member.summary: Defines a sub-class of the class that allows to fill or stroke a graphic object by tiling an image.
member.remarks: A is used to fill or stroke a graphic object using an image that can be replicated horizontally and vertically to fill the areas to be painted. The property represents the image that will be tiled. The property defines the location and size of the tiles. The tiling theoretically extends a series of such rectangles to infinity in X and Y (positive and negative), with rectangles starting at (x + m*width, y + n*height) for each possible integer value for m and n. When the value of property is (the default), the value of the property must be interpreted in the coordinate system of the graphic object being painted. In this coordinate system (0,0) is mapped to the top-left corner of the graphic object and (1,1) to the bottom-right corner of the graphic object. Thus when the property is (0,0,1,1) the image is stretched to fit the graphic object bounding box.

example.para: The following example creates a rectangle filled with a texture.
example.code: Function CreateRectangleWithTextureFill() As Rect Dim rectangle As Rect = New Rect(0, 0, 100, 100) Dim myFill As TextureFill = New TextureFill myFill.Bounds = New Rectangle2D(0, 0, 1, 1) myFill.Image = TextureFill.Wood1 rectangle.Fill = myFill Return rectangle End Function
example.para: This example will produce the following image:

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Windows.Forms.CustomColorDialog
member.summary: Represents a common dialog box that displays available colors along with controls that enable the user to define custom colors.
member.remarks: Use the property to get or set the edited color.

example.para: The following example shows how to use the dialog box.
example.code: Dim dialog As CustomColorDialog = New CustomColorDialog dialog.Color = Color.Red If (dialog.ShowDialog = DialogResult.Ok) Then System.Console.WriteLine(("Selected Color : " + dialog.Color.ToString())) End If

To adjust the value range of the scroll bar control, set the and properties. To adjust the distance the scroll box moves, set the and properties. To adjust the starting point of the scroll box, set the property when the control is initially displayed.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.HScrollBar
member.summary: Represents a standard Windows horizontal scroll bar.
member.remarks: You can use this control to implement scrolling in a custom graphic object or for user input of numeric data. The and properties determine the range of values the user can select. The property determines the effect of clicking within the scroll bar but outside the scroll box. The property determines the effect of clicking the scroll arrows at each end of the control.

example.para: The following example creates a scrollbar, the ValueChanged event is handled to print the scrollbar value.
example.code:
Function CreateHScrollBar() As HScrollBar Dim scrollbar As HScrollBar = New HScrollBar scrollbar.Rectangle = New Rectangle2D(0, 0, 400, 30) scrollbar.Minimum = 0 scrollbar.Maximum = 200 scrollbar.LargeChange = 50 scrollbar.Value = 50 AddHandler scrollbar.ValueChanged, AddressOf OnValueChanged Return scrollbar End Function
Sub OnValueChanged(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As EventArgs) Console.WriteLine("The scrollbar value has changed to " + CType(sender, ScrollBar).Value) End Sub

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Windows.Forms.DiagramPageSetupDialog
member.summary: Defines a dialog box that allows you to configure the printing of a diagram.
member.remarks: Use the property to get or set the document to configure.

example.para: The following sample shows how to configure a .
example.code: Dim container As Group = New Group Dim ellipse As Ellipse = New Ellipse(0, 0, 100, 100) container.Objects.Add(ellipse) Dim document As DiagramPrintDocument = New DiagramPrintDocument(container) Dim dialog As DiagramPageSetupDialog = New DiagramPageSetupDialog dialog.Document = document dialog.ShowDialog()

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Windows.Forms.GenericValueEditor
member.summary: Represents a Windows control that allows you to edit a value of any type.

remarks.p: The GenericValueEditor control allows the user to edit values of a specific type. Use the property to access the edited value.
The type of objects to edit is defined by the property of this control. The GenericValueEditor uses the and installed on that type to edit and validate values.

When the associated with the edited type has the style DropDown (see ), then this control will display a down arrow button that drops the custom editor. When the associated with the edited type has the style Modal, then this control will display a ... button that opens the modal dialog.

When no is associated with the edited type or the associated editor is of style None, then the behavior of the control depends on the edited type. If the type is enumerated, then the control acts like a combo box of the enumerated values. If the type is not an enumerated type, then the control acts like a text box.

If the editor associated with the edited type can display a representation of the edited value (see UITypeEditor.GetPaintValueSupported), then a small rectangle showing this representation will be displayed in addition to the textual value.

You can decide to transform this control into an UpDownControl by setting the property to . In this case, if the edited type is an enumerated type then the Up and Down buttons will allow you to navigate into the enumerated values of this type, otherwise you may handle the and events.

example.para: The following code sample shows how to create a GenericValueEditor for editing a stucture.
example.code: Private Funtion GetColorEditor(ByVal startColor As Color) as GenericValueEditor Dim editor as GenericValueEditor = New GenericValueEditor() editor.EditedType = GetType(Color) editor.Value = startColor Return editor End Function

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Windows.Forms.GenericValueEditor.PaintValueOnly
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to show only the rectangle that displays a representation of the edited value.
member.value: if the control shows only the rectangle that displays a representation of the edited value; otherwise. The textual value is then not visible.
member.remarks: When the editor can paint a representation of the value (see UITypeEditor.GetPaintValueSupported) this control will show both a textual value and a rectangle that displays a representation of the value. Setting this property to will hide the textual value. Not all editors can paint a representation of the edited value. If the editor cannot paint the edited value, then the value of this property is meaningless.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Windows.Forms.GenericValueEditor.Editor
member.summary: Gets or sets the type editor for this control.
member.value: A instance that defines the way this control will edit the value.

remarks.p: When the editor has the style DropDown (see ), then this control will display a down-arrow button that drops the custom editor. When the editor has the style Modal, then this control will display a ... button that opens the modal dialog.

When no editor is set or the editor is of style None, then the behavior of the control depends on the edited type. If the type is enumerated then the control acts like a combo box of the enumerated values. If the type is not an enumerated type, then the control acts like a text box.

If the editor can display a representation of the edited value (see UITypeEditor.GetPaintValueSupported), then a small rectangle showing this representation will be displayed in addition to the textual value.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Ellipse
member.summary: Represents a graphic object that displays an ellipse.
member.remarks: A object is a graphic object that displays an ellipse. The property defines the geometry of objects.

example.para: The following sample creates a light blue ellipse with a black border.
example.code: Function CreateEllipse() As Ellipse Dim ellipse As Ellipse = New Ellipse(0, 0, 100, 100) ellipse.Fill = New SolidFill(Color.LightBlue) ellipse.Stroke = New Stroke(Color.Black, 2) Return ellipse End Function

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.ScaleBase.LabelFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets the format of the labels.
member.value: A that represents the format used to compute ticks labels. The default format is G.
member.remarks:
The label strings are computed as follows:
For each major tick, a label object (determined by the property) is displayed.
Each label object is formatted using the property, using the .NET framework composite formatting feature. The label can be a simple format string like F2), or a complete format item like {0,10:F2}.
See the .NET framework documentation for a full description of formatting strings and items.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.ScaleBase.LabelType
member.summary: Determines what type of labels are displayed on the major ticks of the scale.
member.value: One of the values. The default value is .
member.remarks:
The possible values are:
The labels are numbers computed from the , and properties.
The labels are dates computed from the , and properties. The values of the properties are interpreted as a number of seconds.
The labels are taken from the collection contained in the property. If the collection is smaller than the number of scale ticks, no labels are displayed for the extra ticks. If the collection is longer, the extra labels are ignored.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.ScaleBase.LogBase
member.summary: Gets or sets the logarithm base used to create a logarithmic scale.
member.value: A that represents the logarithm base used to create a logarithmic scale. The default value is 0.

remarks.para: Set this property to a value greater that 1 to create a logarithmic scale. The most commonly used logarithm base is 10. If this property is equal to 0 (the default value) or less than 1, the scale is linear.

Note: when the scale is logarithmic, the values of the and properties are ignored, because the intervals vary along the scale. You can only specify that the ticks must not be drawn by setting one or both of and to 0.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.LinearScaleTickDirection.Left
member.summary: Draws the ticks on the left of the scale's base line, looking in the direction of the line (for example, if the scale is horizontal and the end point is on the right of the start point, the ticks are above the base line).

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.LinearScaleTickDirection.Right
member.summary: Draws the ticks on the right of the scale's base line, looking in the direction of the line (for example, if the scale is horizontal and the end point is on the right of the start point, the ticks are below the base line).

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.LinearScale
member.summary: Represents a scale based on a straight line.
member.remarks: The class represents a scale based on a straight line. The line of the scale is defined through the and properties. The scale displays labels above or below the line depending on the property. Labels can display numbers, dates or simple text depending on the property. Many options allow layouting and formatting the labels such as the that specifies the appearance properties of the labels, that specifies a spacing between the labels and the tick lines, that specifies a format for the labels or and to control the size of the tick lines.

example.para: The following sample creates a linear scale displaying numeric ticks from 0 to 50.
example.code: Function CreateLinearScale() As LinearScale Dim scale As LinearScale = New LinearScale scale.LabelType = ScaleLabelType.Numeric scale.StartPoint = New Point2D(0, 0) scale.EndPoint = New Point2D(200, 0) scale.LabelAppearance.Font = New Font("Microsoft Sans Serif", 12F) scale.LabelDistance = 12F scale.Maximum = 50F scale.MinorTickSize = 0F Return scale End Function

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.CircularScale
member.summary: Represents a scale based on an elliptical arc.
member.remarks: The class represents a scale based on an elliptical arc. The ellipse that defined the scale is contained in the rectangle defined in the property. The segment of arc is defined through the and properties. The scale displays labels inside or outside the elliptical arc depending on the property. Labels can display numbers, dates or simple text depending on the property. Many options allow layouting and formatting the labels such as the that specifies the appearance properties of the labels, that specifies a spacing between the labels and the tick lines, that specifies a format for the labels or and to control the size of the tick lines.

example.para: The following sample creates a circular scale displaying a segment of arc of 270 degrees and numeric ticks from 0 to 50.
example.code: Function CreateCircularScale() As CircularScale Dim scale As CircularScale = New CircularScale scale.LabelType = ScaleLabelType.Numeric scale.Rectangle = New Rectangle2D(0, 0, 200F, 200F) scale.StartAngle = 0F scale.SweepAngle = 270F scale.LabelAppearance.Font = New Font("Microsoft Sans Serif", 12F) scale.LabelDistance = 12F scale.Minimum = 0F; scale.Maximum = 50F scale.MinorTickSize = 0F Return scale End Function

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.HierarchicalNodeGroup
member.summary: The class HierarchicalNodeGroup allows to create a group of nodes that is subject to a constraint.
member.remarks: A node group itself is not a constraint. But some constraints allow node groups as input rather than single nodes. For instance, it is possible to force a group of nodes to be placed in a higher level than another group of nodes. Or it is possible to force all nodes of the group to be placed no more than a certain number of levels apart.

member.param: A list containing the nodes that belong to this group. The list is copied into the new HierarchicalNodeGroup. When a group becomes subject of a constraint, the constraint applies to all nodes of the group.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.AspectRatioAlignment
member.summary: Defines the types of alignments when a graphic content must be displayed in a viewport.
member.remarks: Use the values of this enumeration to set the property of a object.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.AspectRatioAlignment.None
member.summary: Do not force uniform scaling. Scale the graphic content of the given element non-uniformly if necessary such that the element's bounding box exactly matches the viewport rectangle.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.AspectRatioAlignment.XMinYMin
member.summary: Force uniform scaling. Align the min-x of the element's viewBox with the smallest X value of the viewport. Align the min-y of the element's viewBox with the smallest Y value of the viewport.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.AspectRatioAlignment.XMidYMin
member.summary: Force uniform scaling. Align the midpoint X value of the element's viewBox with the midpoint X value of the viewport. Align the min-y of the element's viewBox with the smallest Y value of the viewport.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.AspectRatioAlignment.XMaxYMin
member.summary: Force uniform scaling. Align the min-x+width of the element's viewBox with the maximum X value of the viewport. Align the min-y of the element's viewBox with the smallest Y value of the viewport.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.AspectRatioAlignment.XMinYMid
member.summary: Force uniform scaling. Align the min-x of the element's viewBox with the smallest X value of the viewport. Align the midpoint Y value of the element's viewBox with the midpoint Y value of the viewport.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.AspectRatioAlignment.XMidYMid
member.summary: (the default) - Force uniform scaling. Align the midpoint X value of the element's viewBox with the midpoint X value of the viewport. Align the midpoint Y value of the element's viewBox with the midpoint Y value of the viewport.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.AspectRatioAlignment.XMaxYMid
member.summary: Force uniform scaling. Align the min-x+width of the element's viewBox with the maximum X value of the viewport. Align the midpoint Y value of the element's viewBox with the midpoint Y value of the viewport.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.AspectRatioAlignment.XMinYMax
member.summary: Force uniform scaling. Align the min-x of the element's viewBox with the smallest X value of the viewport. Align the min-y+height of the element's viewBox with the maximum Y value of the viewport.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.AspectRatioAlignment.XMidYMax
member.summary: Force uniform scaling. Align the midpoint X value of the element's viewBox with the midpoint X value of the viewport. Align the min-y+height of the element's viewBox with the maximum Y value of the viewport.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.AspectRatioAlignment.XMaxYMax
member.summary: Force uniform scaling. Align the min-x+width of the element's viewBox with the maximum X value of the viewport. Align the min-y+height of the element's viewBox with the maximum Y value of the viewport.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Transform
member.summary: Defines a two dimensional affine transform that performs a linear mapping from 2D coordinates to other 2D coordinates.
member.remarks:
Such a coordinate transformation can be represented by a 3-row by 3-column matrix with an implied last row of [ 0 0 1 ]. This matrix transforms source coordinates (x,y) into destination coordinates (x',y') by considering them to be a column vector and multiplying the coordinate vector by the matrix according to the following process:
[ x'] [ m11 m12 dx ] [ x ] [ m11*x + m12*y + dx ] [ y'] = [ m21 m22 dy ] [ y ] = [ m21*x + m22*y + dy ] [ 1 ] [ 0 0 1 ] [ 1 ] [ 1 ]

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.Polygon
member.summary: Defines a graphic object with a polygon shape.
member.remarks: is a graphic object that displays a polygon. The points of the polygon are defined by the property.

example.para: The following sample shows how to create a blue polygon with a dashed border.
example.code: Function CreatePolygon() As Polygon Dim polygon As Polygon = New Polygon polygon.Points.AddRange(New Point2D() { _ New Point2D(0, 0), _ New Point2D(100, 50), _ New Point2D(200, 0), _ New Point2D(300, 50)}) polygon.Stroke = New Stroke(Color.Black, 2, DashStyle.Dash) polygon.Fill = New SolidFill(Color.Blue) Return polygon End Function

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic.PolygonAnchor.Position
member.summary: The position of the connection point along the path of the polygon.

A value of 0 means the point of the polygon, a value of 1 means the point of the polygon computed using the and properties, and an intermediate value means a point whose linear distance along the polygon path is equal to the total length of the path multiplied by the position.

member.summary: Gets or sets the edge count for the anchor.

member.remarks: This property is used to locate the end vertex for the anchor. Depending on the property, this property will be added to or removed from the index to get the actual end vertex. Then, the connection point is computed by using the property, which gives the location of the connection point along the segments between the start and end vertices.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.MultipleLayout
member.summary: The main class for the Multiple Layout algorithm.

remarks.p: This is not a layout algorithm but rather a facility to compose two layout algorithms and treat them as one algorithm object. This is more convenient if two layout algorithms must be applied to subgraphs in a predetermined order.

The multiple layout offers only a few layout parameters that are global to all two sublayouts (such as the allowed time), but you can specify the other layout parameters individually for each sublayout by accessing and directly.
If complex combinations of graph layouts are needed in a nested graph, you should use the Recursive Multiple Layout (see ) that utilizes the Multiple Layout inside a Recursive Layout.

example.para:
The following example shows how to use the Multiple Layout for applying, in the appropriate order, first Tree layout and then a Link layout for the nontree links in a nested graph. It would be unfortunate to call
multiple times to achieve this, because the tree layout of the parent graph would be finished before the link layout of its subgraph has started; hence the link layout of the subgraph invalidates the tree layout of the parent graph again. To avoid this effect, the Tree layout and Link layout of the subgraph should be finished before any layout of the parent graph has started. This is achieved using the following code.
example.code: MultipleLayout layout = new MultipleLayout( new TreeLayout(), new ShortLinkLayout());
Dim layout As MultipleLayout = New MultipleLayout( _ New TreeLayout, New ShortLinkLayout)
example.para: The following example shows how to construct a MultipleLayout from another MultipleLayout, which is useful if more than two graph layouts are necessary.
example.code: Dim layout As MultipleLayout = New MultipleLayout( _ New MultipleLayout(layout1, layout2), _ New MultipleLayout(layout3, layout4))

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.MultipleLayout.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the Multiple Layout algorithm.
member.remarks:
To indicate the graphic container you want to lay out, use the method Attach(GraphicContainer).
To indicate the graph model you want to lay out, use the method Attach(IGraphModel).
To perform the layout, use the method PerformLayout.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.MultipleLayout.#ctor(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout,ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the Multiple Layout algorithm that composes the input layouts.
member.remarks: If PerformLayout is called on this instance, then layout1 is performed first, and layout2 is performed second. If a recursive layout is called for a nested graph on this instance, all two layouts are applied to each subgraph. However, notice that layout1 and layout2 are finished for a subgraph before the layout1 of the parent graph is started.
member.param: The first layout to be performed.
The second layout to be performed.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.MultipleLayout.Init
member.summary: Initializes instance variables.

remarks.p: You should not call this method directly. The method is called internally by the constructor without arguments and by the copy constructor. The method must be overridden by subclasses that need to initialize additional instance variables.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.MultipleLayout.#ctor(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.MultipleLayout)
member.summary: Creates a new layout instance by copying an existing one.
member.remarks:
This constructor is used by the method. Any subclass should provide a copy constructor.
The parameters of the source layout are copied using the method .
member.param: The layout instance that is copied.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.MultipleLayout.Copy
member.summary: Copies the layout instance.

remarks.p: This method copies the layout instance by calling the copy constructor.

When performing a recursive layout on a nested graph, this method is used by to "clone" the layout instance of a parent graph. Note that the parameters which are specific to a node or a link are not copied. The persistence flags are copied. The sublayout instances and their global layout parameters are copied.

member.returns: A copy of the layout instance.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.MultipleLayout.CopyParameters(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout)
member.summary: Copies the parameters from a given layout instance.

remarks.p: Note that the parameters which are specific to a node or a link are not copied. The activation and persistence flags are copied. The sublayout instances and their global layout parameters are copied.

member.param: The layout instance from which the parameters are copied.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.MultipleLayout.Attach(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel)
member.summary: Allows you to specify the graph model you want to lay out.
member.remarks: In addition to the functionality in the base class, the Multiple Layout attaches its sublayouts.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.MultipleLayout.Detach
member.summary: Detaches the graph model from the layout instance.
member.remarks:
When you attach a new graph model to the layout instance, you do not need to detach the old graph model because this is done automatically when you call . The Detach method performs cleaning operations on the graph model. In addition to the cleaning operations in the base class, the Multiple Layout detaches its sublayouts.
Note that you must call this method when you no longer need the layout instance. Otherwise, some objects may not be garbage collected.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.MultipleLayout.CreateLayoutReport
member.summary: Returns a new instance of the layout report.
member.remarks: The current implementation creates an instance of .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.MultipleLayout.Layout
member.summary: Computes the layout using the Multiple Layout algorithm.
member.remarks: To start the layout, call the method .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.MultipleLayout.StopImmediately
member.summary: Stops the running layout algorithm as soon as possible.

remarks.p: This method can be used if multiple threads are used for layout and GUI control. The GUI control thread calls this method to notify the layout thread that the layout run must be stopped. The layout algorithm will perform some final cleanup operations before terminating. Therefore, the layout thread will continue until the cleanup operations are finished. The GUI thread, however, returns immediately from this method.
If the layout algorithm is stopped before completion, the result code of the layout report is .

member.returns: if the algorithm can be stopped at this time.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.MultipleLayout.SupportsPercentageComplete
member.summary: Indicates whether the layout class can estimate the percentage of completion during the run of the layout.
member.remarks:
If the sublayouts support this feature, the percentage value is calculated from the sublayouts. If the sublayouts do not support this feature, the Multiple Layout algorithm can indicate by discrete percentage values (typically 50% and 100%) whether the first graph layout or the second graph layout are already finished.
The calculated percentage values are not very precise.
member.returns: Always .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.MultipleLayout.SupportsStopImmediately
member.summary: Indicates whether the layout class can immediately interrupt the current run of the layout in a controlled way.
member.remarks: If the first graph layout and the second graph layout support this feature, then it returns .

members.member:
Indicates whether the layout class can stop the layout computation when a user-defined allowed time is exceeded.
If the first graph layout and the second graph layout support this feature, then it returns .
'/>

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.MultipleLayout.SupportsLayoutOfConnectedComponents
member.summary:
Indicates whether the layout class can cut the attached graph into connected components, apply itself on each connected component separately, and then use the layout instance returned by the property
to position the connected components.
member.remarks: If the first graph layout and the second graph layout support this feature, then it returns .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.MultipleLayout.OnSubGraphLayoutStepPerformed(System.Object,ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutStepPerformedEventArgs)
member.summary: This method is called by the first graph layout and the second graph layout. It forwards the layout event to this Multiple Layout.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.MultipleLayout.FirstGraphLayout
member.summary: Gets or sets the first layout to be applied.
member.remarks: You should set the layout before attaching the graph model.
member.value: The first layout.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.MultipleLayout.FirstGraphLayoutActive
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the first graph layout is active.
member.remarks:
This allows you to temporarily disable the first graph layout. The first graph layout is active by default. However, if you want to perform a layout using only the second graph layout, you can set the first layout inactive. The first layout remains attached when inactive, but it is not performed when calling
on the Multiple layout instance.
member.value: if the first graph layout is active, or otherwise.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.MultipleLayout.FirstGraphLayoutPersistent
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the first graph layout is persistent.

remarks.p: If the first graph layout is persistent, it is serialized when serializing the Multiple layout. This is the default.

member.value: Determines whether the first graph layout is persistent.

This allows you to temporarily disable the second graph layout. The second graph layout is active by default. However, if you want to perform a layout using only the first graph layout, you can set the second layout inactive. The second layout remains attached when inactive, but it is not performed when calling

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.INodeSideFilter
member.summary: An interface used to define complex requirements concerning the connection of the links to the different sides of the nodes.

remarks.p: The filter is used by some layout algorithms to provide the user the capability to allow or prohibit the links to be connected on given sides (top/bottom/right/left) of the nodes.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.INodeSideFilter.Accept(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.IGraphModel,System.Object,System.Boolean,System.Object,ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.NodeSide)
member.summary: Allows or prohibits the connection of on a given side of the .

remarks.p: Returns when the specified end of can be connected on on the side defined by the argument . Returns otherwise.
The values for are defined in . Valid values are Top, Bottom, Left, and Right.

This method is called by those layout algorithms that allow you to specify a node side filter. You can implement this method in order to define complex requirements concerning the connection of the links to the different sides of nodes. For example, if you want all links to be connected to any side except the top side of the nodes, you could use:
return (side != NodeSide.Top);

member.param: The graph model to which the node belongs.
The link to be connected to the node.
If is , the method determines whether the link origin can be connected. Otherwise, the method determines whether the link destination can be connected.
The side of the node. The values are defined in . Valid values are Top, Bottom, Left, and Right.
member.returns: if the connection is allowed and otherwise.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutReportCode
member.summary: The status codes of the layout indicate the current status of the layout algorithm.
member.remarks: The codes can be retrieved by after layout was finished, or inside a handler for the LayoutStepPerformed event.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutReportCode.InitialCode
member.summary: The initial value of the code.
member.remarks: The property returns this value if no different code was ever set.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutReportCode.EmptyGraph
member.summary: The layout was not performed because the graph is empty.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutReportCode.NotNeeded
member.summary: The layout was not performed because there was no significant change in the graph since the last time the layout was performed successfully.
member.remarks: This normally means that there was no change in the topology (no nodes and no links were added or removed), no change in position (no nodes and no links were moved), and no change in parameter values.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutReportCode.LayoutDone
member.summary: The layout was performed normally.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutReportCode.StoppedAndValid
member.summary:
The layout was performed but stopped because either the layout time elapsed or
was called, and the result can be considered a valid layout.
member.remarks:
Iterative layout algorithms that can be stopped at any iteration set this result code if they do not run to completion (see
and ).

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutReportCode.StoppedAndInvalid
member.summary:
The layout was performed but stopped because either the layout time elapsed or
was called, and the result cannot be considered a valid layout.
member.remarks:
Noniterative layout algorithms set this result code if they do not run to completion (see
and ). The nodes and links are either at intermediate positions (that is, the positions seem to be placed randomly) or have not changed at all, depending on the specific behavior of the layout algorithm.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutReportCode.LayoutStarted
member.summary: The layout was started.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutReportCode.LayoutFinished
member.summary: The layout was finished.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayoutReportCode.ExceptionDuringLayout
member.summary: An exception has been raised during layout.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.Filters.FeComposite
member.summary: Defines a filter effect that combines two input images using one of the Porter-Duff compositing operations: over, in, atop, out, xor.
member.remarks: This filter performs the combination of the two input images pixel-wise in image space using one of the Porter-Duff [PORTERDUFF] compositing operations: over, in, atop, out, xor. Additionally, a component-wise arithmetic operation (with the result clamped between [0..1]) can be applied. The arithmetic operation is useful for combining the output from the 'feDiffuseLighting' and 'feSpecularLighting' filters with texture data. It is also useful for implementing dissolve. If the arithmetic operation is chosen, each result pixel is computed by means of the following formula: result = k1*i1*i2 + k2*i1 + k3*i2 + k4

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.Internal.ConnectedComponentAdapter.GetLinkPoints(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the points that define a link.
Reshapes a link.
member.remarks:
The method must work for normal links and intergraph links.
The link style represents the style of the shape of the link. The details of the shape of the link are given by the further arguments of the method. If the new shape of the link must be a straight-line link without any intermediate points, call the method with an empty array for the points argument, or with the value 0 for the length argument. In this case, the values of the arguments startIndex and length are ignored.
The mode parameters determine how the and should be used:
The or parameter contains no meaningful value. The layout does not specify how the corresponding origin or destination point of the link should be determined.
The or parameter contains a meaningful value. The layout wants to move the corresponding origin or destination point of the link to the specified point.
The or parameter contains no meaningful value. The layout wants to keep the previous corresponding origin or destination point of the link fixed, relative to the node position.
The or parameter contains no meaningful value. The layout wants to clip the corresponding origin or destination point of the link against the border of the node.
The or parameter contains a meaningful value. The layout wants to clip the corresponding origin or destination point of the link against the border of the node, but the link should go though the specified point.
member.param: The style of the shape of the link.
The connection point of the link on the origin node.
The mode that indicates how the should be used.
The array of intermediate points. Ignored if length is 0."/>
The starting position in the array of points.
The connection point of the link on the destination node.
The mode that indicates how the should be used.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ReshapeLinkMode
member.summary: The reshape modes used for .
member.remarks:
These modes occur when the graph layout calls . There are five possibilities for the origin point and for the destination point of a link:
- The layout provides no information about the end points of the link at all. The graph model can decide whatever it wants. When using a , the layout does not change the current anchor of the link.
The layout wants to move the origin and/or destination point of the link to the provided position. When using a , the layout adapts the anchor of the link so that it is movable.
The layout wants to keep the original origin and/or destination point of the link fixed. No new point is provided. When using a , the layout adapts the anchor of the link so that it is not movable.
The layout wants to clip the original origin and/or destination point of the link against the node border. No new point is provided. When using a , the layout adapts the anchor of the link so that the link is clipped towards the center of the node.
The layout wants to clip the original origin and/or destination point of the link against the node border towards the provided point. When using a , the layout adapts the anchor of the link so that the link goes through the provided point and is clipped at the node border.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ReshapeLinkMode.Ignore
member.summary: The method does not provide any information for the origin or destination point of the link. The anchor of the link does not need to be changed in any way.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ReshapeLinkMode.Move
member.summary: The method should move the origin or destination point of the link to the provided position.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ReshapeLinkMode.Fix
member.summary: The method should keep the origin or destination point of the link fixed. The same position (relative to the node position) as before layout should be used.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ReshapeLinkMode.Clip
member.summary: The method should clip the origin or destination point at the border of the node shape. No specific position is provided.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ReshapeLinkMode.MoveAndClip
member.summary: The method should first move the origin or destination point to the provided position and the clip it at the border of the node shape.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ReshapeLinkStyle
member.summary: The link style options used for .
member.remarks: These options specify the shape of the link. The graph model can set the properties of the link so that the link can best represent this style.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ReshapeLinkStyle.Ignore
member.summary: Keep the previous style: The link should not change its style.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ReshapeLinkStyle.Straight
member.summary: Straight line link style: The link has no bends.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ReshapeLinkStyle.Orthogonal
member.summary: Orthogonal link style: The link can have horizontal or vertical segments.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ReshapeLinkStyle.Polyline
member.summary: Polyline link style: The link can have arbitrary segments and bends.

member.name: F:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ReshapeLinkStyle.Direct
member.summary: Direct link style: The link has two bends and a long straight middle segment.

member.name: T:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout
member.summary: This class is the main class for the Short Link Layout algorithm.

remarks.p: This algorithm reshapes the links of a graph without moving the nodes. By default, the algorithm computes orthogonal links (that is, links composed of alternating horizontal and vertical segments). Optionally, direct links can be computed. (See and .)

The links are placed freely in the plane by choosing the best shape from a fixed number of link shapes. Orthogonal links can a maximum of 4 bends. Direct links have 3 bends.
This layout algorithm is recommended when any of the following apply:
Most of the links are short, and it is not fatal if long links overlap some nodes.
The link routes must be placed freely and cannot be restricted to a grid.
It is important to limit the number of bends.
Otherwise, the may be more suitable.
Here are sample drawings produced by the Short Link Layout algorithm:
See the corresponding chapter of the User's Manual for details on the algorithm, the types of graphs for which this algorithm can be used, the features and limitations, code samples, and so on.

Note the following points:
The algorithm never moves any nodes. It only reshapes links.
The algorithm normally routes normal links. It has a special mode to route the intergraph links of the graph model.
The algorithm has an incremental mode and a nonincremental mode. In nonincremental mode, the initial shape of the links (at the moment you start the layout) does not affect the resulting layout. However, links specified as fixed while
is enabled or links that have the link style are not reshaped. The incremental mode cannot be used for intergraph links.
In incremental mode, the initial shape of the link does affect the resulting layout. The algorithm tries to preserve the shape of links that already fit the layout situation.
The algorithm supports self-links and multiple links between the same pair of nodes.

example.para: The following example shows how to apply the Short Link Layout.
example.code:
Imports System Imports ILOG.Diagrammer Imports ILOG.Diagrammer.Graphic Imports ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout
Dim group As Group = New Group
' Fill the group with nodes and links here
Dim layout As ShortLinkLayout = New ShortLinkLayout group.LinkLayout = layout group.PerformGraphLayout

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the Short Link Layout algorithm.
member.remarks:
To indicate the graphic container you want to lay out, use the method .
To indicate the graph model you want to lay out, use the method .
To perform the layout, use the method .
To modify the layout parameters, use the different methods provided in this class and its superclass.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.Init
member.summary: Initializes instance variables.

remarks.p: You should not call this method directly. The method is called internally by the constructor without arguments and by the copy constructor. The method must be overridden by subclasses that need to initialize additional instance variables.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.#ctor(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout)
member.summary: Creates a new layout instance by copying an existing one.
member.remarks:
This constructor is used by the method. Any subclass should provide a copy constructor.
The parameters of the source layout are copied using the method .
member.param: The layout instance that is copied.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.Copy
member.summary: Copies the layout instance.

remarks.p: This method copies the layout instance by calling the copy constructor.
When performing a recursive layout on a nested graph, this method is used by to "clone" the layout instance of a parent graph.
Note that the parameters which are specific to a node or a link are not copied. The other parameters, including the customization interfaces, are also copied.

member.returns: A copy of the layout instance.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.CopyParameters(ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.GraphLayout)
member.summary: Copies the parameters from a given layout instance.

remarks.p: Note that the parameters which are specific to a node or a link are not copied. The other parameters, including the customization interfaces, are also copied.
If a method of the type SupportsXXX is associated with a parameter, the parameter is copied only if the corresponding method returns .

member.param: The layout instance from which the parameters are copied.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.Detach
member.summary: Detaches the graph model from the layout instance.
member.remarks:
When you attach a new graph model to the layout instance, you do not need to detach the old graph model because this is done automatically when you call .
The method performs cleaning operations on the graph model. In addition to the cleaning operations in the base class, the Short Link Layout removes the link style specifications of individual links.
Note that you must call this method when you no longer need the layout instance. Otherwise, some objects may not be garbage collected.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.Layout
member.summary: Computes the layout using the Short Link Layout algorithm.
member.remarks: To start the layout, call the method .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.GetAuxiliaryLongLinkLayout
member.summary: Returns the instance of that is used for avoiding overlaps between links and nodes when returns .
member.remarks:
This method allows you to get this auxiliary layout instance and to customize its parameters if needed. In particular, you can reduce or increase the grid size (see
and ).
Notice that you should not modify the origin and destination point mode, nor to disable the preservation of fixed links. Notice also that an is attached to the only if needed, therefore
getAuxiliaryLongLinkLayout().getGraphModel()
can return .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.SetLinkStyle(System.Object,ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.LinkLayoutLinkStyle)
member.summary: Sets the style of the shape of an individual link.
member.remarks:
This link style is used only if the global link style is set to . Otherwise, all links have the style that is specified as the global link style.
Valid values are:
- the link gets an orthogonal shape, that is, a shape consisting of a sequence of orthogonal line segments.
- the link gets a straight-line shape.
- the link is not reshaped.
The default value is .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.GetLinkStyle(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the style of the shape of an individual link.

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.SetOriginPointMode(System.Object,ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ConnectionPointMode)
member.summary: Sets the mode for the connection point on an individual link on the origin node.
member.remarks:
This mode is used only if the global from-point mode is set to . Otherwise, the connection points on the origin nodes have, for all the links, the mode that is specified as the global origin point mode.
Valid values are:
- The layout is free to choose, for this link, the appropriate position of the connection point on the origin node, except for "pinned" connection points (see ).
- The layout must keep, for this link, the current position of the connection point on the origin node. This can be useful, in particular, if the node has fixed connection points where the link is attached and the connection points should not be moved by the layout algorithm.
Note that, in this mode, the layout algorithm has less freedom for the choice of a link shape. Hence, this mode usually produces more crossings and overlaps than the mode .
The default value is .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.GetOriginPointMode(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the origin point mode of an individual link.

- The layout must keep, for this link, the current position of the connection point on the destination node. This can be useful, in particular, if the node has fixed connection points where the link is attached and the connection points should not be moved by the layout algorithm.
Note that, in this mode, the layout algorithm has less freedom for the choice of a link shape. Hence, this mode usually produces more crossings and overlaps than the mode .
The default value is .

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.SetConnectorStyle(System.Object,ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayoutConnectorStyle)
member.summary: Sets the connector style of an individual node.
member.remarks:
This connector style is used only if the global connector style is set to . Otherwise, all nodes have the connector style that is specified as the global connector style.
Valid values are:
- The link connection points are spaced along the node border at a distance equal to the link offset (see ).
- The link connection points are evenly spaced along the node border, preserving a margin which is determined by .
- Uses the connector style except if this pushes a connection point outside the border the link is attached to, in which case it uses the connector style .
The default value is .

members.member:
Sets the link reshape mode of an individual link used during incremental layout for unmodified links, that is links that have been already laid out in the previous layout execution and for which the bounding box (see nor the "link connection box" (see
@link #getLinkConnectionBoxInterface}) of their origin and destination nodes have not been modified.
This link reshape mode is used only if the incremental mode is enabled and the global link reshape mode is set to . If the global mode is not , all links have the mode that is specified as the global link reshape mode.
Valid values are:
- The incremental layout preserves preserves the shape type of the link. This means that both the number of bends and the node sides to which the link is connected are preserved.
- The incremental layout preserves the node sides to which the links are connected.
- The incremental layout preserves the connection points of the links.
- The links are not reshaped at all during incremental layout. Only newly added links are rerouted.
- The incremental layout is allowed to freely reshape the links. This is equivalent to a non-incremental behavior for the argument. (Of course, settings that may have been done using , and are still obeyed.)
The default mode is . The link.
The link reshape mode to set.

- The incremental layout preserves the node sides to which the links are connected.

- The links are not reshaped at all during incremental layout. Only newly added links are rerouted.
- The incremental layout is allowed to freely reshape the links. This is equivalent to a non-incremental behavior for the argument. (Of course, settings that may have been done using , and are still obeyed.)

member.name: M:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.SupportsLinkConnectionBox
member.summary: Indicates that this layout class can use a link connection box interface to calculate the end points of a link.
member.remarks:
The link connection box interface is an object that provides the rectangle to which the links are connected for each node, and the tangential shift offset at each side for the connection points.
The link connection box is used instead of the bounding box of each node (see and ) during the routing of links.
member.returns: Always .

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.LinkOverlapNodesForbidden
member.summary: Gets or sets whether it is forbidden for the layout to reshape links such that they overlap nodes.

remarks.p: The default value of this parameter is .
If overlaps are not forbidden, the algorithm tries to avoid overlaps anyway, but may create overlaps, for instance in order to avoid crossings of the link with other links.
If overlaps are forbidden, the algorithm uses the auxiliary link layout (see for laying out, in an orthogonal shape, those links that overlap nodes.

Notice that the auxiliary long link works on a grid and the default grid size may need to be reduced to allow this algorithm to avoid the overlaps (see
and ).
Notice also that forbidding the overlaps can slow down the layout and can produce additional link bends and link crossings.

member.value: Whether it is forbidden for the layout to reshape links such that they overlap nodes.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.NodeBoxProvider
member.summary: Gets or sets an object that provides the rectangle defining the position and size of each node.

remarks.p: You can set this property to to go back to the default behavior.

member.value: An object that provides the rectangle defining the position and size of each node.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.NodeSideFilter
member.summary: Gets or sets the node-side filter, that is, an object that allows or prohibits the connection of the links on a given side of the nodes.

remarks.p: If a node-side filter is not installed, and the connection points of the links are not fixed (see , ), the layout algorithm is free to choose any side of the nodes, except for "pinned" connection points (see ).
When a filter is installed, the layout algorithm asks the filter at which side of its end node each link is allowed to attach to.

Note the following points:
A filter should always allow a link to connect to at least one side of a node; otherwise the link cannot be routed.
If the connection point on the origin or destination node is specified as fixed (see , , , ), the filter is not used for the origin or the destination node, respectively.
When side constraints are added using the filter, the layout algorithm has less freedom for the choice of a link shape. Hence, laying out with a side filter usually produces more crossings and overlaps than laying out without side filter.
You can set this property to to return to the default behavior.

member.value: The node-side filter.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.LinkStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the global style of the shape of the links.
member.remarks:
Valid values are the following:
: the shape of the links is a polyline composed of a straight-line segment between the end nodes with two horizontal or vertical segments at its extremities (their length is controlled by and may be 0).
: the shape of the links is a polyline composed of alternating horizontal and vertical segments.
: each link can have a different link style. The style of each individual link can be set by the method
so that different link shapes can occur in the same graph.
Unless the global link style is , all links have the same style of shape.
The default value is .
member.value: The global style of the shape of the links.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.SelfLinkStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the global style of the shape of the self-links.
member.remarks:
Self-links are links that have the same origin and destination node.
Valid values are the following:
: the shape of the links is a polyline composed of three alternating horizontal and vertical segments, connected to the same side of the node.
: the shape of the links is a polyline composed of four alternating horizontal and vertical segments, connected to two adjacent sides of the node.
The default value is .
member.value: The global style of the shape of the self-links.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.OriginPointMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the global mode for the connection point of the links on the origin nodes.
member.remarks:
Valid values are:
- For all links, the layout is free to choose the appropriate position of the connection point on the origin node, except for "pinned" connection points (see ).
- For all links, the layout must keep the current position of the connection point on the origin node. This can be useful, in particular, if the node has fixed connection points where the link is attached and the connection points should not be moved by the layout algorithm.
Note that, in this mode, the layout algorithm has less freedom for the choice of a link shape. Hence, this mode usually produces more crossings and overlaps than the mode .
- Each link can have a different mode for the connection point on the origin node. The mode of each individual link can be set by the method .
Unless the global mode is , the connection points on the origin node have the same mode for all the links.
The default value is .
member.value: The global mode to set.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.DestinationPointMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the global mode for the connection point of the links on the destination nodes.
member.remarks:
Valid values are:
- For all links, the layout is free to choose the appropriate position of the connection point on the destination node, except for "pinned" connection points (see ).
- For all links, the layout must keep the current position of the connection point on the destination node. This can be useful, in particular, if the node has fixed connection points where the link is attached and the connection points should not be moved by the layout algorithm.
Note that, in this mode, the layout algorithm has less freedom for the choice of a link shape. Hence, this mode usually produces more crossings and overlaps than the mode .
- Each link can have a different mode for the connection point on the destination node. The mode of each individual link can be set by the method .
Unless the global mode is , the connection points on the destination node have the same mode for all the links.
The default value is .
member.value: The global mode to set.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.ConnectorStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the global style of connectors.
member.remarks:
Valid values are the following:
- The link connection points are spaced along the node border at a distance equal to the link offset (see ).
- The link connection points are evenly spaced along the node border, preserving a margin which is determined by .
- Uses the connector style except if this pushes a connection point outside the border the link is attached to, in which case it uses the connector style .
: each node can have a different connector style. The style of each individual node can be set by the method
so that different connector styles can occur in the same graph.
Unless the global connector style is , all links have the same connector style.
The default value is .
The connector style is used to place the connection points of links that have the free origin or destination point mode and no specified port index. Links with fixed point mode do not change their connection point at the origin node. The placement of connection points also depends on the connection box interface, in the following way:
First, the bounding box of an end node is obtained. If a link connection box interface was set via , the bounding box and offsets are delivered by that interface. Otherwise, the node bounding box delivered by the graph model (see ) is used.
Next, the connection point of the link is placed at this bounding box in the manner specified by the connector style.
member.value: The connector style.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.EvenlySpacedConnectorMarginRatio
member.summary: Gets or sets the margin ratio for the evenly spaced connector style.
member.remarks:
This option has no effect if the connector style is used.
In evenly spaced connector style (see ), the connection points of the links are evenly spaced along the node border, preserving a margin to each extremity of the node border. The size of this margin is controlled by the margin ratio, and is computed by multiplying with the ratio the offset between the links.
The input value must be a positive or zero value. A ratio of 0 means no margin; a ratio of 1 means a margin equal to the offset between the links; a ratio of 0.5 means a margin equal to half the offset between the links; a ratio of 2 means a margin equal to twice the offset between the links and so on. There is no upper bound for the ratio; however, the margin which is obtained has an upper bound equal to (node-side-dimension - total-width-of-links) / 2. The default value is 0.5.
member.value: The margin ratio for the evenly spaced connector style.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.LinkBundlesMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the link bundles mode.
member.remarks:
The valid modes are the following:
: Several links connected to the same side of a node share the same connection point, that is, the middle of the node side. The final segments of the links overlap. No bundles are created and the link offset parameter is ignored.
: The connection points of several links connected to the same side of a node are distributed according to the link offset value. With the orthogonal link style, the algorithm additionally ensures that the first and last segments of the links are always orthogonal to the side of the node to which they are connected.
: The algorithm additionally tries to avoid overlapping the second segment and the segment next to the last. Note that with the direct link style, this mode is equivalent to .
The default value is .
member.value: The link bundles mode.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.IncrementalMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the incremental layout mode.
member.remarks:
If the argument is , the layout tries to create a layout with similar shapes for links already laid in the last layout, in order to preserve the "mental map" of the user as much as possible. The exact incremental behavior is controlled by the "incremental link reshape" mode. For details, see
and .
The incremental mode works only if the intergraph links mode is disabled or if there are no intergraph links. Also, the incremental mode has no effect if the layout parameters have been changed since the previous layout.
The incremental mode is disabled by default.
member.value: Set to to enable the incremental layout mode, or to disable it.

@link #getLinkConnectionBoxInterface}) of their origin and destination nodes have not been modified.
This mode has no effect if the incremental mode is disabled.
Valid values are:

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.InterGraphLinksMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the routing of intergraph links.
member.remarks:
If the argument is , the intergraph links are routed; otherwise, only the normal links are routed. An intergraph link is a link stored in a given graph that has an origin or destination not stored in this graph. If the combined intergraph link routing is enabled in addition, this means that normal links and intergraph links are routed together; otherwise only the intergraph links are routed.
The default value is .
If the intergraph link mode is enabled and the graph actually contains some intergraph links, there are some restrictions:
The incremental mode has no effect.
If layout is performed on a nested (or ), the top-level graph must have a view attached because of the coordinate transformations of the subgraphs. If you create your own subclass of instead of to route intergraph links, you must ensure that all graph models of all subgraphs use the same coordinate system through appropriate coordinate transformations.
member.value: The routing of intergraph links.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.CombinedInterGraphLinksMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the routing of normal links in addition to intergraph links.
member.remarks:
If intergraph link routing is disabled, the mode has no effect. If intergraph link routing is enabled and the argument is , both normal links and intergraph links are routed in the same pass. Otherwise, only the intergraph links are routed.
The default value is .
member.value: The routing of normal links in addition to intergraph links.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.SameShapeForMultipleLinks
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the layout algorithm must ensure that all multiple links have the same type of shape, that is a shape with the same number of bends and with parallel segments.

remarks.p: Multiple links are links that have the same origin and destination nodes.
If the argument is , additional work is done to ensure that multiple links will be reshaped in the same manner.
The default value is .

Note that for some categories of links it cannot be guaranteed that they will be given the same type of shape as the other links with the same origin and destination nodes:
In incremental mode (see , for newly inserted links.
Fixed links (see .
Links with at least one of their connection points fixed (see , , , ).

member.value: Set to to enable the same shape option, or to disable it.

member.name: P:ILOG.Diagrammer.GraphLayout.ShortLinkLayout.BypassDistance
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum distance between the origin and destination node for which a link shape going directly from one node to another is allowed.
member.remarks:
The algorithm tries to avoid link shapes that directly connect the sides of the end nodes that are closer than the bypass value.
If the specified value is strictly negative, the value of the parameter is used as the bypass distance. This allows the automatic adjustment of the bypass distance according to the current value of . This behavior is suitable in most cases. However, you can specify a non-negative value in order to override the default behavior.
The default value is a negative value.
member.value: The minimum distance for a direct connection.

remarks.p: The default value is 2.
